'''Sibiu''' ({{IPA-ro|siËˆbiw}}, antiquated, ''Sibiiu''; {{lang-de|Hermannstadt}}, [[Transylvanian Saxon dialect]]: ''HÃ¤rmeschtat'', {{lang-hu|Nagyszeben}}) is a city in [[Transylvania]], [[Romania]], with a population of 147,245.&lt;ref name=&quot;INSSER&quot;/&gt; Located some {{convert|215|km|abbr=on}} north-west of [[Bucharest]],&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.geobytes.com/citydistancetool.htm City Distance Tool] at geobytes.com&lt;/ref&gt; the city straddles the [[Cibin River]], a tributary of the river [[Olt River|Olt]]. Now the capital of [[Sibiu County]], between 1692 and 1791 and 1849-1865 Sibiu was the capital of the [[Principality of Transylvania (disambiguation)|Principality of Transylvania]].

Sibiu is one of the most important cultural centres of Romania and was designated the [[European Capital of Culture]] for the year 2007, along with the city of [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]].&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sibiu2007.ro/index_en.php Sibiu Cultural Capital Website]&lt;/ref&gt; Formerly the centre of the [[Transylvanian Saxons]], the old city of Sibiu was ranked as &quot;Europe's 8th most idyllic place to live&quot; by [[Forbes]] in 2008.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news| url=http://www.forbes.com/2008/11/18/europe-homes-dollar-forbeslife-cx_po_1118realestate_slide_4.html | work=Forbes | first1=Edward | last1=Beckett | first2=Parmy | last2=Olson | title=In Pictures: Europe's Most Idyllic Places To Live}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The city administers the [[PÄƒltiniÈ™]] ski resort.

== History ==
{{see also|Timeline of Sibiu}}
The first official record referring to the '''Sibiu''' area comes from 1191, when Pope [[Celestine III]] confirmed the existence of the free [[prepositure]] of the [[Transylvanian Saxons|German settlers]] in Transylvania, the prepositure having its headquarters in Sibiu, named ''Cibinium'' at that time.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.turism.sibiu.ro/en/istorie.htm The History of Sibiu]&lt;/ref&gt;

In the 14th century, it was already an important trade centre. In 1376, the craftsmen were divided in 19 [[guild]]s. Sibiu became the most important ethnic German city among the seven cities that gave Transylvania its German name ''SiebenbÃ¼rgen'' (literally ''seven citadels'').&lt;ref&gt;[http://thedockyards.com/the-history-of-the-transylvanian-saxons/ The History of the Transylvanian Saxons], thedockyards.com&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://europeupclose.com/article/sibiu-hermannstadt-romanian-city-german-traditions/ Sibiu, or Hermannstadt? A Romanian City with German TraditionsPublished/Revised June 11, 2014], europeupclose.com&lt;/ref&gt;  It was home to the [[Universitas Saxorum]] (Community of the Saxons), a network of pedagogues, ministers, intellectuals, city officials, and councilmen of the German community forging an ordered legal corpus and political system in Transylvania since the 1400s.&lt;ref&gt;[http://expelledgermans.org/transylvaniasaxons.htm The vanished Romanian German community through Hitler's population transfer, soviet deportation, &amp; mass emigration], expelledgermans.org&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.alanier.at/Sachsen.html The Saxonsâ€™ Land, or the Royal Domain (Fundus Regius)], alanier.at&lt;/ref&gt; During the 18th and 19th centuries, the city became the second &lt;!-- to what? --&gt; and later the first most important centre of Transylvanian [[Romanians|Romanian ethnics]]. The first Romanian-owned bank had its headquarters here (The ''Albina'' Bank), as did the [[AsociaÈ›ia TransilvanÄƒ pentru Literatura RomÃ¢nÄƒ È™i Cultura Poporului RomÃ¢n|ASTRA]] (Transylvanian Association for Romanian Literature and Romanian's People Culture). After the [[Romanian Orthodox]] Church was granted status in the [[Habsburg Empire]] from the 1860s onwards, Sibiu became the [[Metropolitan bishop|Metropolitan seat]], and the city is still regarded as the third most important centre of the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]]. Between the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848]] and 1867 (the year of the ''[[Ausgleich]]''), Sibiu was the meeting-place of the [[Transylvanian Diet]], which had taken its most representative form after the Empire agreed to extend voting rights in the region.

After [[World War I]], when [[Austria-Hungary]] was dissolved, Sibiu became part of Romania; the majority of its population was still ethnic German (until 1941) and counted a large Romanian community, as well as a smaller Hungarian one. Starting from the 1950s and until after 1990, most of the city's ethnic Germans emigrated to [[Germany]] and [[Austria]]. Among the roughly 2,000 who have remained is [[Klaus Johannis]], the {{As of|2014|alt=current}} President of Romania.

==Geography==
[[File:Sibiu region.png|thumb|Topographic map of the Sibiu region]]
Sibiu is situated near the geographical center of Romania at {{Coord|45.792784|N|24.152069|E|region:RO_type:city}}. Set in the Cibin Depression, the city is about 20&amp;nbsp;km from the [[FÄƒgÄƒraÈ™ Mountains]], 12&amp;nbsp;km from the [[Cibin Mountains]], and about 15&amp;nbsp;km from the [[Lotrului Mountains]], which border the depression in its southwestern section. The northern and eastern limits of Sibiu are formed by the TÃ¢rnavelor Plateau, which descends to the Cibin Valley through GuÈ™teriÈ›ei Hill.
 
The Cibin river as well as some smaller streams runs through Sibiu. The geographical position of Sibiu makes it one of the most important transportation hubs in Romania with important roads and railway lines passing through it.

== Climate ==
Sibiu's climate is [[temperate]]-[[Continental climate|continental]] with average temperatures of {{convert|8|to|9|C|F}}. The average rainfall is 662 l/m&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;, and there are about 120 days of hard frost annually.

==Demographics==
As of [[Demographic history of Romania|2011 census]] data, Sibiu has a population of 147,245, a decrease from the figure recorded at the 2002 census,&lt;ref name=&quot;INSSER&quot;/&gt; making it the 14th largest [[List of cities and towns in Romania|city]] in Romania. The ethnic breakdown was as follows:&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sibiu.insse.ro/phpfiles/tab2_1_tot_etnie_SIBIU.pdf 2011 census data]&lt;/ref&gt;
* [[Romanians]] 95.9%
* [[Hungarians]] 1.6%
* [[Ethnic German|Germans]] ([[Transylvanian Saxon]]s) 1.1%
* [[Roma in Romania|Roma]] 0.4%

===Population by religious denomination===

Today, most of the population is of the Romanian Orthodox religion. [[Protestant]]s and [[Roman Catholic]]s represent about 5% of the population.

== Politics ==
{{outdated section|date=August 2016}}
[[File:2004 sibiu council.png|thumb|right|Sibiu city council composition:
{{legend|#000|[[Democratic Forum of Germans in Romania]]}}
{{legend|#cc3333|[[Social Democratic Party (Romania)|Social Democratic Party]]}}
{{legend|#f2e125|[[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]]}}
{{legend|#ff9900|[[Democratic Party (Romania)|Democratic Party]]}}]]

Although ethnic Germans make up less than 2% of Sibiu's population, [[Klaus Johannis]], the former president of the [[Democratic Forum of Germans in Romania]] (FDGR/DFDR) and current president of Romania, served as mayor of Sibiu from 2000 to 2014.  When he was elected mayor in 2000, he was the first German mayor of a city in Romania since [[World War II]].{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} Johannis was overwhelmingly reelected in 2004 (with 88.7% of votes) and 2008 (with 83.3% of the votes cast) and his party gained an absolute majority in the city council in that year. The German Forum also won the elections for mayor in the second and third most important towns in Sibiu county, [[MediaÈ™]] and [[CisnÄƒdie]], as well as one third (11 out of 33) of the seats in the county council.

== Economy ==

Sibiu is an important economic hub for Romania, with a high rate of foreign investments. It is also an important hub for the manufacturing of automotive components and houses factories belonging to [[ThyssenKrupp]] Bilstein-Compa, Takata, Continental, and [[NTN Corporation|NTN-SNR]] ball bearings. 
Other local industries are machine components, textiles, agro-industry, and electrical components ([[Siemens AG|Siemens]]).

The city also contains Romania's second largest stock exchange, the [[Sibiu Stock Exchange]].&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sibex.ro/?l=en Sbiu Stock Exchange Website]&lt;/ref&gt;

The main industrial activities of Sibiu take place in two industrial zones located on the outskirts of the city:
*East industrial zone, alongside the railway to [[BraÈ™ov]] and [[RÃ¢mnicu VÃ¢lcea]]
*West industrial zone, near the exit to [[SebeÈ™]], close to the [[Sibiu International Airport|Airport]]

A commercial zone located in the [[È˜elimbÄƒr]] commune plays an important role in the economy of Sibiu. It houses a mall and other large retailers.

Another factor that plays an important role in the economy of the city is tourism, which has been increasing at a steady rate since 2007.

=== Employment breakdown by economic sector ===
* Industry - 40%
* Commerce - 17%
* Construction - 8%
* Health - 8%
* Transport - 7%
* Education - 5%
* Other Services - 15%

==Transport==

Sibiu is well served in terms of transport and infrastructure. In 2010 a city bypass was opened, significantly reducing the road traffic inside the city.

[[Tursib]]&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.tursib.ro Tursib] - Official Site&lt;/ref&gt; is the city's internal transportation system operator.

===Air===
[[File:Sibiu International Airport Location.png|thumb|Sibiu International Airport Location]]
[[File:Blue-air-sibiu-airport.jpg|thumb||200px|right|Sibiu Airport, Blue Air flight.]]
[[File:Transportation-sibiu.jpg|thumb||200px|right|[[Public bus]] transportation in Sibiu]]
Sibiu has one of the most modern [[Sibiu International Airport|international airports]] in Romania, with direct connections to [[Germany]], [[Austria]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]] as well as to other Romanian cities.

=== Road ===
Sibiu is an important node in the European road network, being on two different European routes (E68 and E81). At a national level, Sibiu is located on three different main national roads, DN1, DN7 and DN14.
 
The [[A1 motorway (Romania)|Romanian Motorway A1]] will link the city with [[PiteÈ™ti]] and the Romanian western border, near [[Arad, Romania|Arad]]. The remaining 161&amp;nbsp;km of motorway towards Arad, out of a total of 281&amp;nbsp;km, are under construction and expected to be completed by 2016, while the timeline for the segment towards PiteÈ™ti is targeted for completion for the year 2020. Sibiu' s [[ring road]] as part of [[A1 motorway (Romania)|A1 motorway]] was completed on December 1, 2010.

Sibiu is also an important hub for the international bus links with the biggest passenger transporter in Romania, [[Atlassib]], based here. Transport companies are also providing coach connections from Sibiu to a large number of locations in Romania.

=== Rail ===
Sibiu is situated on the [[Romanian Railways|CFR-Romanian Railways]] Main Line 200 (Brasov - FÄƒgÄƒraÈ™ - Sibiu - Simeria - Arad - Romanian Western Border) and on Line 206 (Sibiu - MediaÈ™).

The city is served by three rail stations: the Main Station, the Little Station (''Gara MicÇŽ'') and Sibiu TurniÈ™or. It has an important diesel-powered locomotives depot and a freight terminal.

Numerous Inter City trains (nicknamed Blue Arrows) connect Sibiu to other major cities in Romania: Cluj-Napoca, BraÈ™ov, Craiova, TimiÈ™oara and Bucharest.

=== Cycling ===
Over the last 6 years, Sibiu has enjoyed a revival of cycling. The bicycle way in the city span for 43 kilometers.

Bicycle rentals have offered a boost for the local economy with several small rental centers and a bigger rental center that is administered by the I'Velo Bike Sharing group.

==Culture==
Sibiu is one of Romania's most culturally lively cities. It has 3 theatres and a philharmonic orchestra along with other smaller private theatrical venues and a theatre studio housed by the Performing Arts and Acting section of [[Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu|Lucian Blaga University]], where students hold monthly representations.

The [[Radu Stanca National Theatre]]&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sibfest.ro Radu Stanca National Theatre] - Official Site&lt;/ref&gt; is one of the leading Romanian theatres. With origins dating back to 1787, it attracts some of the best-known Romanian directors, such as [[GÃ¡bor Tompa]] and [[Silviu PurcÄƒrete]]. It has both a Romanian-language and a German-language section, and presents an average of five shows a week.

The [[Gong Theatre]] is specialised in puppetry, mime and non-conventional shows for children and teenagers. It also presents shows in both Romanian and German.

The [[State Philharmonic of Sibiu]]&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.filarmonicasibiu.ro/ State Philharmonic of Sibiu] - Official Site&lt;/ref&gt; presents weekly classical music concerts, and educational concerts for children and teenagers. The concerts take place in the newly restored [[Thalia Hall]], a concert and theatre hall dating from 1787, situated along the old city fortifications. Weekly [[organ (music)|organ]] concerts are organised at the [[Sibiu Lutheran Cathedral|Evangelical Cathedral]] during summers, and thematic concerts are presented by the Faculty of Theology choir at the [[Sibiu Orthodox Cathedral|Orthodox Cathedral]].

The [[Sibiu International Theatre Festival]] is an annual festival of performing arts.

===Museums and parks===

[[File:Brukenthal-sibiu.jpg|thumb|Brukenthal National Museum, Sibiu.]]
[[File:Sibiu-park-bicycle.jpg|thumb|Bicycle riders in Sub Arini park, in Sibiu.]]

Sibiu's museums are organised around two entities: the [[Brukenthal National Museum]] and the [[ASTRA National Museum Complex]]. The Brukenthal Museum consists of an Art Gallery and an Old Books Library located inside the Brukenthal Palace, a History Museum located in the old town hall building, a Pharmacy Museum located in one of the first [[apothecary]] shops in Europe, dating from the 16th century, a Natural History Museum and a Museum of Arms and Hunting Trophies.

The [[ASTRA National Museum Complex]] focuses on [[ethnography]], and consists of a Traditional Folk Civilisation Museum, a 96-[[hectare]] open-air museum located in Dumbrava Forest south of Sibiu, a Universal Ethnography Museum, a Museum of Transylvanian Civilisation and a Museum of Saxon Ethnography and Folk Art. Also planned is a Museum of the Culture and Civilisation of the Romany People.

The [[Dumbrava Sibiului Natural Park]] stretches over 960 hectares and it is situated 4&amp;nbsp;km away from the center of the city in the southwest direction along the road towards RÄƒÅŸinari. Also, here you can find the Zoological Garden and Ethnography Museum.

There is a [[Sibiu Steam Locomotives Museum|Steam Locomotives Museum]] close to the railway station, sheltering around 40 [[steam locomotive|locomotives]], two of which are functional.

The first park in the city was The Promenade, later called &quot;The Disabled Promenade.&quot; established in 1791, today part of Parcul CetÄƒÈ›ii (Citadel Park). Current arrangement of the park, including the space between the walls, dates from 1928.

The Sub Arini Park, established in 1856 is one of the biggest and best maintained parks in Romania. There are other green spaces in the city center, the best known being Astra Park, established in 1879.

Other parks:

Tineretului Park, ReconstrucÈ›iei Park, Corneliu Coposu Park, PetÃ¶fi SÃ¡ndor Park, PiaÈ›a Cluj Park, È˜trand Park, Cristianului Park, ÈšiÈ›eica Park, Vasile Aaron Park, Lira Park.

The distribution of green space is good compared to other Romanian cities.

===Events===
Several festivals are organised yearly in Sibiu, the most prestigious of them being the [[Sibiu International Theatre Festival]], organized each spring at the end of May. Medieval Festival organized every year in August, reviving the medieval spirit of [[Transylvania]]. 
The [[Artmania Festival]] is held every Summer since 2006 and as of 2008 the Rockin' Transilvania Festival is also held in Sibiu. 
The oldest [[Jazz Festival of Sibiu|Jazz Festival]] in Romania is organized here, as well as the &quot;Carl Filtsch&quot; festival for young classical piano players, the &quot;Astra Film&quot; documentary film festival, the Transylvania calling Festival a Multi Cultural 6 day Open Air Music festival! 26â€“31 July 2007, a  medieval arts festival and many more smaller cultural events.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sibiu.ro/ro/cultura2005.htm 2006 Cultural Programme]&lt;/ref&gt;

===European Cultural Capital===
The designation as a [[European Capital of Culture|European Cultural Capital]] for 2007, owed greatly to the excellent collaboration with [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]], but also to what many regard as a miraculous social rebirth taking place in the city during the last years. The Cultural Capital status was expected to bring about an abrupt increase in quantity and quality of cultural events in 2007.

==Tourism==
In 2007, Sibiu was the [[European Capital of Culture]] (together with [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]]). This was the most important cultural event that has ever happened in the city, and a great number of tourists came, both domestic and foreign.

[[File:Kirchehammersdorf.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Villages with fortified churches in Transylvania|Fortified church]] of GuÈ™teriÈ›a neighbourhood]]
The city of Sibiu and its surroundings are one of the most visited areas in Romania. It holds one of the best preserved historical sites in the country, many of its medieval fortifications having been kept in excellent state. Its old center has begun the process for becoming a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] in 2004. Sibiu and its surrounding area have many significant museums, with 12 institutions housing art collections, paintings, and exhibits in decorative arts, archeology, anthropology, history, industrial archeology and history of technology and natural sciences.

The city also lies close to the [[FÄƒgÄƒraÈ™ Mountains]] - a very popular trekking destination, close to the [[PÄƒltiniÈ™]] and Arena Platos ski resorts - popular winter holiday destinations, and it is at the heart of the former Saxon communities in Transylvania renowned for its [[Villages with fortified churches in Transylvania|fortified churches]].

===Main sights===
[[File:Podul.JPG|left|thumb|200px|Bridge of Lies and the Evangelical Church in the background]]
[[File:PiaÈ›a Mare Sibiu - vedere cÄƒtre biserica romano-catolicÄƒ.jpg|thumb|200px|Christmas Fair in the Grand Square]]
[[File:Sibiu - Turnul Dulgherilor.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Coopers Tower]]
[[File:Catedrala Ortodoxa din Sibiu.JPG|left|thumb|200px|[[Sibiu Orthodox Cathedral]]]]
[[File:Sibiu Turnul Gros (4).jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Thalia Hall|The Thick Tower]]]]

Much of the city's aspect is due to its position, easily defensible, but allowing horizontal development. The old city of Sibiu lies on the right bank of the Cibin River, on a hill situated at about 200 m from the river. It consists of two distinct entities: the ''Upper Town'' and the ''Lower Town''. Traditionally, the Upper Town was the wealthier part and commercial outlet, while the Lower Town served as the manufacturing area.

'''The Lower Town'''
(German: ''Unterstadt'', Romanian: ''OraÈ™ul de jos'') comprises the area between the river and the hill, and it developed around the earliest fortifications. The streets are long and quite wide for medieval city standards, with small city squares at places. The architecture is rather rustic: typically two-storey houses with tall roofs and gates opening passages to inner courts.

Most of the exterior fortifications were lost to industrial development and modern urban planning in the mid-late 19th century; only four towers still exist. A building associated with newer urbanism of the period is the ''IndependenÈ›a'' Highschool.

This area has the oldest church in the city, dating back to 1292.

'''The Upper Town'''
(German: ''Oberstadt'', Romanian: ''OraÈ™ul de sus'') is organised around three city squares and a set of streets along the line of the hill. As the main area for [[Bourgeoisie|burgher]] activities, the area contains most points of interest in the city.

'''Grand Square'''
(German: ''GroÃŸer Ring'', Romanian: ''PiaÈ›a Mare'' ) is, as its name suggests, the [[List of town squares by size|largest square]] of the city, and has been the center of the city since the 15th century. 142&amp;nbsp;m long and 93&amp;nbsp;m wide, it is one of the largest ones in Transylvania.

[[Brukenthal Palace]], one of the most important [[Baroque]] monuments in Romania, lies on the north-western corner of the square. It was erected between 1777 and 1787 as the main residence for the Governor of Transylvania [[Samuel von Brukenthal]]. It houses the main part of the ''National Brukenthal Museum'', opened in 1817, making it one of the oldest museums in the world. Next to the palace is the ''Blue House'' or ''Moringer House'', an 18th-century Baroque house bearing the old coat of arms of Sibiu on its faÃ§ade.

On the north side is the [[Jesuit]] Church, along with its dependencies, the former residence of the Jesuits in Sibiu. Also on the north side, at the beginning of the 20th century an ''[[Art Nouveau]]'' building was constructed on the west part, now it houses the mayor's office.

Next to the Jesuit Church on the north side is the ''Council Tower'', one of the city's symbols. This former fortification tower from the 13th century has been successively rebuilt over the years. The building nearby used to be the City Council's meetingplace; beneath it lies an access way between the ''Grand Square'' and the ''Lesser Square''.

On the south and east sides are two- or three-storey houses, having tall attics with small windows known as the ''city's eyes''. Most of these houses are dated 15th to 19th centuries, and most of them are Renaissance or Baroque in style.

'''Lesser Square'''
(''Small Square'', German: ''Kleiner Ring'') as its name implies, is a smaller square situated in the northern part of the Upper Town. After the 2007 rehabilitation there has been an increase in the number of small businesses such as pubs and restaurants in this area.

The square is connected to the other two squares and to other streets by small, narrow passages. The main access from the Lower City is through Ocnei Street, which divides the square in two. The street passes under the ''Liar's Bridge'' - the first bridge in Romania to have been cast in iron (1859).&lt;ref&gt;[http://welcometoromania.ro/Sibiu/Sibiu_Podul_Mincinosilor_e.htm The Bridge of Lies]&lt;/ref&gt;

To the right of the bridge is another symbol of the city, ''The House of the Arts'', an 14th-century arched building formerly belonging to the Butchers' Guild. On the left side of the bridge is the ''Luxemburg House'', a Baroque four-storey building.

'''Huet Square'''
is the third of the three main squares of Sibiu. Its most notable feature is the [[Sibiu Lutheran Cathedral|Evangelical Lutheran Cathedral]] in its center. It is the place where the earliest fortifications have been built in the late 12th century or early 13th century. The buildings around this square are mainly [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]]. On the west side lies the Brukenthal Highschool, in place of a former 14th-century school.

'''The Fortifications'''
of Sibiu made the city one of the most important fortified cities in Central Europe. Multiple rings were built around the city, most of them out of clay bricks. The south-eastern fortifications are the best kept, and all three parallel lines are still visible. The first is an exterior earth mound, the second is a 10-meter-tall red brick wall, and the third line comprises towers linked by another 10-meter-tall wall. All structures are connected via a labyrinth of tunnels and passageways, designed to ensure transport between the city and lines of defense.

In the 16th century more modern elements were added to the fortifications, mainly leaf-shaped [[bastion]]s. Two of these survived to this day, as the ''Haller Bastion'' (all the way down Coposu Boulevard) and &quot;Soldisch Bastion&quot;.

'''The Passage of the Stairs''',
leads down to the lower section of Sibiu. It descends along some fortifications under the support arches. It is the most picturesque of the several passages linking the two sides of the city.

==Health==

Sibiu is one of the important medical centers of Romania, housing many important medical facilities:
* County Hospital
* Academic Emergency Hospital;
* Hospital of Pediatrics;
* Military Emergency Hospital;
* CFR Hospital (Romanian Railways Hospital);
* &quot;Dr. Gheorghe Preda&quot; Psychiatry Hospital
* other smaller private clinics

The city also houses one of the largest private hospitals in the country, Polisano.

==Education==

Sibiu is an important centre of higher education, with over 23,000 students in four public and private higher institutions.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.ulbsibiu.ro/en/despre_ulbs/ About Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.mediafax.ro/social/reportaj-sefa-de-promotie-la-academia-fortelor-terestre-a-fost-o-lupta-intre-a-rezista-si-a-avea-vointa-foto-12957248 Land Forces Military Academy] at mediafax.ro&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.roger-univ.ro/universitate/prezentare-urgs.html About Sibiu Romanian-German University]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.uamsibiu.ro/universitate/istoric/ About Alma Mater University]&lt;/ref&gt;

The [[Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu]] was founded in 1990, with five faculties: Engineering and Sciences; Language Sciences; History and Law; Medicine; Food and Textile Processing Technology. Nowadays, there are 10 faculties and departments.

Sibiu also houses the [[Nicolae BÄƒlcescu Land Forces Academy]] and the Military Foreign Language Center as well as two private universities, ''Romanian-German University'' and ''Alma Mater University''.

[[File:Liceul Samuel von Brukenthal.jpg|thumb|Samuel von Brukenthal High School]]

In Sibiu there are 20 educational institutions on the secondary level, the most important of which are:
*[[Gheorghe LazÄƒr National College (Sibiu)|Gheorghe LazÄƒr National College]] - sciences and informatics, first opened in 1692 as a [[List of Jesuit institutions|Jesuit College]]
*[[Samuel von Brukenthal National College]] - German language high school
*[[Octavian Goga]] National College - social sciences, sciences and informatics
*[[Onisifor Ghibu]] Theoretical Highschool - informatics, social sciences and sports
*[[Andrei È˜aguna]] National College - training for schoolteachers, informatics, social sciences and sports
*[[Constantin Noica]] Theoretical Highschool - social sciences and sciences
*Daniel Popovici Barcianu Highschool - agricultural and economic sciences
*[[George BariÅ£|George Baritiu]] National College - economic sciences
*[[Nicolae Iorga]] Elementary school
*[[Marie of Romania|Regina Maria]] Elementary school

      <text xml:space="preserve" bytes="20553">{{About|the classical medium|the software company|Oracle Corporation|other uses}}
[[File:John William Waterhouse oracle 1884.png|right|thumb|''[[Consulting the Oracle]]'' by [[John William Waterhouse]], showing eight priestesses in a temple of prophecy.]]

In [[classical antiquity]], an '''oracle''' was a person or agency considered to provide wise and insightful counsel or [[prophecy|prophetic]] [[prediction]]s or [[precognition]] of the future, inspired by the [[Pantheon (religion)|gods]]. As such it is a form of [[divination]].

==Description==
The word oracle comes from the [[Latin]] verb ''Å?rÄ?re'' &quot;to speak&quot; and properly refers to the priest or priestess uttering the prediction. In extended use, ''oracle'' may also refer to the site of the oracle, and to the  oracular utterances themselves, called ''khrÄ“smoi'' (Ï‡Ï?Î·ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Î¯) in  Greek.

Oracles were thought to be portals through which the gods spoke directly to people. In this sense they were different from seers (''manteis'', Î¼Î¬Î½Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‚) who interpreted signs sent by the gods through bird signs, animal entrails, and other various methods.&lt;ref name=flower&gt;Flower, Michael Attyah. ''The Seer in Ancient Greece.'' Berkeley: University of California Press, 2008.&lt;/ref&gt;

The most important oracles of Greek antiquity were [[Pythia]], priestess to [[Apollo]] at [[Delphi]], and the oracle of [[Dione (Titaness/Oceanid)|Dione]] and [[Zeus]] at [[Dodona]] in [[Epirus]].
Other temples of Apollo were located at [[Didyma]] on the coast of [[Asia Minor]], at [[Ancient Corinth|Corinth]] and [[Bassae]] in the Peloponnese, and at the islands of [[Delos]] and [[Aegina]] in the Aegean Sea. The [[Sibylline Oracles]] are a collection of oracular utterances written in Greek [[hexameters]] ascribed to the [[Sibyls]], prophetesses who uttered divine revelations in frenzied states.

==Origins==
[[Walter Burkert]] observes that &quot;Frenzied women from whose lips the god speaks&quot; are recorded in the [[Near East]] as in [[Mari, Syria|Mari]] in the second millennium BC and in Assyria in the first millennium BC.&lt;ref&gt;Walter Burkert.''Greek Religion''. Harvard University Press.1985.p 116-118&lt;/ref&gt; In Egypt the goddess [[Wadjet]] (eye of the moon) was depicted as a snake-headed woman or a woman with two snake-heads. Her oracle was in the renowned temple in [[Per-Wadjet]] (Greek name [[Buto]]). The oracle of Wadjet may have been the source for the oracular tradition which spread from Egypt to Greece.&lt;ref&gt;[[Herodotus]], ''[[Histories (Herodotus)|The Histories]]'', ii 55, and vii 134.&lt;/ref&gt; Evans linked Wadjet with the [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] [[Snake Goddess|snake goddess]], a [[chthonic deity]] and one of the aspects of the Great Mother.&lt;ref&gt;Cristopher L.C. Whitcomp.''Minoan Snake goddess''.8.''Snakes, Egypt, Magic and wome''&lt;/ref&gt;

In Greece the old oracles were devoted to the [[Mother Goddess]]. At the oracle of [[Dodona]] she will be called [[Dione (Titaness/Oceanid)|DiÅ?nÄ“]] (the feminine form of ''DiÃ³s'', [[genitive]] of [[Zeus]], [[PIE]] *''Dyaeus''; or of ''dÄ«os'', &quot;godly&quot;, literally &quot;heavenly&quot;), who  represents the earth-fertile soil, probably the chief female goddess of the [[PIE]] pantheon. [[Python (mythology)|Python]], daughter (or son) of [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]] was the earth dragon of [[Delphi]] represented as a [[serpent (symbolism)|serpent]] and became the chthonic deity, enemy of [[Apollo]], who slew her and possessed the oracle.&lt;ref&gt;''Hymn to Pythian Apollo''.363,369&lt;/ref&gt;

==Pythia==
{{quote|&lt;poem&gt;When the Prytanies' seat shines white in the island of Siphnos,
White-browed all the forumâ€”need then of a true seer's wisdomâ€”
Danger will threat from a wooden boat, and a herald in scarlet.&lt;/poem&gt;|The Pythoness, in ''[[Histories (Herodotus)|The Histories]]'', [[Herodotus]].&lt;ref&gt;Herodotus, ''The Histories'', as translated in: {{cite book |title=The History of Herodotus: A New English Version |volume=II |author1-link=George Rawlinson|first1=George|last1=Rawlinson |first2=Henry Creswicke|last2=Rawlinson |first3=John Gardner|last3=Wilkinson |page=376 |date=1862 |location=London |publisher=John Murray |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ijENAAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA376&amp;dq=treasury+Siphnos&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=wMbcT-OUEYWp8AOf1IGwCw&amp;ved=0CGEQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&amp;q=treasury%20Siphnos&amp;f=false |accessdate=3 August 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;}}

The Pythia was the mouthpiece of the oracles of the god [[Apollo]].&lt;ref&gt;Plato, G.M.A. Grube, J.M. Cooper - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3WFKMKNkzcAC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=The+Trial+and+Death+of+Socrates+%28Third+Edition%29:+Euthyphro,+Apology,+Crito,+Death+Scene+from+Phaedo&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=y3U5VfnNEMuwPP_ugYgM&amp;ved=0CCYQuwUwAA#v=onepage&amp;q=The%20Trial%20and%20Death%20of%20Socrates%20(Third%20Edition)%3A%20Euthyphro%2C%20Apology%2C%20Crito%2C%20Death%20Scene%20from%20Phaedo&amp;f=false ''The Trial and Death of Socrates'' (Third Edition): &quot;Euthyphro, Apology, Crito, Death Scene from Phaedo&quot;] (page 24 - footnote 7) Hackett Publishing, 2000; ISBN 1603846476 [Retrieved 2015-04-25]&lt;/ref&gt;

[[Pythia]], the oracle at [[Delphi]], was said to be [[infallible]].{{citation needed|reason=The original reference provided no reasoning or basis for this claim.|date=October 2014}} Pythia only gave prophecies the seventh day of each month, seven being the number most associated with [[Apollo]], during the nine warmer months of the year; thus, Delphi was the major source of [[divination]] for the ancient Greeks. Many wealthy individuals bypassed the hordes of people attempting a consultation by making additional animal sacrifices to please the oracle lest their request go unanswered. As a result, [[divination#Divination in Ancient Greece|seers]] were the main source of everyday divination.

The temple was changed to a center for the worship of Apollo during the classical period of Greece and priests were added to the temple organizationâ€”although the tradition regarding prophecy remained unchangedâ€”and the priestesses continued to provide the services of the oracle exclusively. It is from this institution that the English word, oracle, is derived.

The Delphic Oracle exerted considerable influence throughout Hellenic culture. Distinctively, this female was essentially the highest authority both civilly and religiously in male-dominated [[ancient Greece]]. She responded to the questions of citizens, foreigners, kings, and philosophers on issues of political impact, war, duty, crime, lawsâ€”even personal issues.&lt;ref&gt;Broad, W. J. (2007), p.43&lt;/ref&gt;

The semi-Hellenic countries around the Greek world, such as [[Lydia]], [[Caria]], and even [[Egypt]] also respected her and came to Delphi as [[supplicant]]s.

[[Croesus]], king of Lydia beginning in 560 B.C., tested the oracles of the world to discover which gave the most accurate prophecies. He sent out emissaries to seven sites who were all to ask the oracles on the same day what the king was doing at that very moment. Croesus proclaimed the oracle at Delphi to be the most accurate, who correctly reported that the king was making a lamb-and-tortoise stew, and so he graced her with a magnitude of precious gifts.&lt;ref&gt;Broad, W. J. (2007), p.51-53&lt;/ref&gt; He then consulted Delphi before attacking [[Achaemenid Empire|Persia]], and according to Herodotus was advised: &quot;If you cross the river, a great empire will be destroyed&quot;. Believing the response favorable, Croesus attacked, but it was his own empire that ultimately was destroyed by the Persians.

She allegedly also proclaimed that there was no man wiser than [[Socrates]], to which Socrates said that, if so, this was because he alone was aware of his own ignorance. After this confrontation, Socrates dedicated his life to a search for knowledge that was one of the founding events of western [[philosophy]]. He claimed that she was &quot;an essential guide to personal and state development.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;Broad, W. J. (2007), p.63. Socrates also argued that the oracle's effectiveness was rooted in her ability to abandon herself completely to a higher power by way of insanity or &quot;sacred madness.&quot;&lt;/ref&gt; This Oracle's last recorded response was given in 362 AD, to [[Julian the Apostate]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=Carol G.|title=Paths from Ancient Greece|year=1988|publisher=[[Brill Publishers]]|page=47|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JIdcStQg4g0C&amp;pg=PA47#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The oracle's powers were highly sought after and never doubted. Any inconsistencies between prophecies and events were dismissed as failure to correctly interpret the responses, not an error of the oracle.&lt;ref&gt;Broad, W. J. (2007), p.15&lt;/ref&gt;  Very often prophecies were worded ambiguously, so as to cover all contingencies â€“ especially so ''ex post facto''.  One famous such response to a query about participation in a military campaign was &quot;You will go you will return never in war will you perish&quot;.  This gives the recipient liberty to place a comma before or after the word &quot;never&quot;, thus covering both possible outcomes.  Another was the response to the Athenians when the vast army of king [[Xerxes I]] was approaching Athens with the intent of razing the city to the ground.  &quot;Only the wooden palisades may save you&quot;{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}, answered the oracle, probably aware that there was sentiment for sailing to the safety of southern Italy and reestablishing Athens there.  Some thought that it was a recommendation to fortify the [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]] with a wooden fence and make a stand there.  Others, [[Themistocles]] among them, said the oracle was clearly for fighting at sea, the metaphor intended to mean war ships.  Others still insisted that their case was so hopeless that they should board every ship available and flee to [[Italy]], where they would be safe beyond any doubt.  In the event, variations of all three interpretations were attempted: some barricaded the Acropolis, the civilian population was evacuated over sea to nearby [[Salamis Island]] and to [[Troizen]], and the war fleet [[Battle of Salamis|fought victoriously at Salamis Bay]].  Should utter destruction have happened, it could always be claimed that the oracle had called for fleeing to Italy after all.

==Dodona==
[[Dodona]] was another oracle devoted to the [[Mother Goddess]] identified at other sites with [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]] or [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]], but here called [[Dione (Titaness/Oceanid)|Dione]]. The shrine of Dodona was the oldest Hellenic oracle, according to the fifth-century historian Herodotus and in fact dates to pre-Hellenic times, perhaps as early as the second millennium BC when the tradition probably spread from Egypt. Zeus displaced the Mother goddess and assimilated her as [[Aphrodite]].

It became the second most important oracle in ancient Greece, which later was dedicated to [[Zeus]] and to [[Heracles]] during the classical period of Greece. At Dodona Zeus was worshipped as Zeus Naios or Naos (god of springs [[Naiads]], from a spring which existed under the oak), and Zeus Bouleos (cancellor). Priestesses and priests interpreted the rustling of the oak leaves to determine the correct actions to be taken. The oracle was shared by Dione and Zeus.

==Trophonius==
[[Trophonius]] was an oracle at [[Lebadea]] of [[Boeotia]] devoted to the chthonian Zeus Trophonius. Trophonius is derived from the Greek word &quot;trepho&quot; (nourish) and he was a Greek hero, or demon or god. [[Demeter]]-[[Europa (mythology)|Europa]] was his nurse.&lt;ref&gt;[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]].''Guide to Greece'' 9.39.2â€“5.&lt;/ref&gt; Europa (in Greek: broad-eyes) was a Phoenician princess whom Zeus, having transformed himself into a white bull, abducted and carried to Creta, and is equated with [[Astarte]] as a moon goddess by ancient sources.&lt;ref&gt;[[Lucian of Samosata]].[[De Dea Syria]].4&lt;/ref&gt; Some scholars connect Astarte with the Minoan snake goddess, whose cult as Aphrodite spread from Creta to Greece.&lt;ref&gt;R.Wunderlich.''The secret of Creta''.Efstathiadis Group.Athens 1987.p 134&lt;/ref&gt;

==&quot;Oracles&quot; in other cultures==
{{Main|Divination}}
The term &quot;oracle&quot; is also applied in modern English to parallel institutions of divination in other cultures.
Specifically, it is used in the context of  [[Christianity]] for the concept of [[divine revelation]], and in the context of [[Judaism]] for the [[Urim and Thummim]] breastplate, and in general any utterance considered [[prophecy|prophetic]].&lt;ref&gt;[[OED]] s.v. &quot;oracle ''n.''&quot;&lt;/ref&gt;

===China===
{{Main|Oracle bone|I Ching}}
[[File:Shang dynasty inscribed scapula.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Oracle bone]] of the [[Shang dynasty]], ancient China]]
In China, [[oracle bones]] were used for divination in the late [[Shang dynasty]], (c. 1600â€“1046 BC). Diviners applied heat to these bones, usually ox scapulae or tortoise plastrons, and interpreted the resulting cracks.

A different divining method, using the stalks of the [[Achillea millefolium|yarrow plant]], was practiced in the subsequent [[Zhou dynasty]] (1046â€“256 BC).  Around the late 9th century BC, the divination system was recorded in the ''[[I Ching]]'', or &quot;Book of Changes&quot;, a collection of linear signs used as oracles.  In addition to its oracular power, the ''I Ching'' has had a major influence on the philosophy, literature and statecraft of China since the Zhou period.

===Celtic polytheism===
In [[Celtic polytheism]], divination was performed by the priestly caste, either the [[druid]]s or the [[vates]]. This is reflected in the role of &quot;seers&quot; in [[Dark Age Wales]] (''[[dryw]]'') and [[History of Ireland 400â€“800|Ireland]] (''[[fÃ¡ith]]'').

===Hinduism===
In ancient [[India]], the oracle was known as Akashwani or Ashareera vani (a person without body or unseen) or Asariri (Tamil), literally meaning &quot;voice from the sky&quot; and was related to the message of god. Oracles played key roles in many of the major incidents of the epics [[Mahabharata]] and [[Ramayana]]. An example is that [[Kamsa]] (or Kansa), the evil uncle of lord [[Krishna]], was informed by an oracle that the eighth son of his sister [[Devaki]] would kill him. However, there are no references in any Indian literature of the oracle being a specific person. 

There are still a few existing and publicly accessible oracles in India. Examples include the Copper Oracle (Tamrapothi) and Silver Oracle (Rupapothi) of Shri Achyutanda Das. These oracles are accessible to everyone at Pothi Ashram located in Kakatpur, Odisha, India.

===Tibetan Buddhism===
In [[Tibet]], oracles have played, and continue to play, an important part in religion and government. The word &quot;oracle&quot; is used by Tibetans to refer to the spirit that enters those men and women who act as [[Mediumship|media]] between the natural and the spiritual realms. The media are, therefore, known as ''kuten'', which literally means, &quot;the physical basis&quot;.

The [[Dalai Lama]], who lives in exile in northern India, still consults an oracle known as the ''[[Nechung Oracle]]'', which is considered the official state oracle of the government of Tibet. The Dalai Lama has according to centuries-old custom, consulted the Nechung Oracle during the new year festivities of [[Losar]].&lt;ref&gt;Gyatso, Tenzin (1988). ''Freedom in Exile: the Autobiography of the Dalai Lama of Tibet.'' Fully revised and updated. Lancaster Place, London, UK: Abacus Books (A Division of Little, Brown and Company UK). ISBN 0-349-11111-1. p.233&lt;/ref&gt; Nechung and Gadhong are the primary oracles currently consulted; former oracles such as Karmashar and Darpoling are no longer active in exile. The Gadhong oracle has passed away leaving Nechung to be the only primary oracle.  Another oracle the Dalai Lama consults is the ''[[Tenma goddesses|Tenma Oracle]]'', for which a young Tibetan woman by the name of Khandro La is the medium for the mountain goddesses Tseringma along with the other 11 goddesses. The Dalai Lama gives a complete description of the process of [[trance]] and [[spirit possession]] in his book ''Freedom in Exile''.&lt;ref&gt;http://www.tibet.com/Buddhism/nechung_hh.html&lt;/ref&gt;
Dorje Shugden oracles were once consulted by the Dalai Lamas until the 14th Dalai Lama banned the practice, even though he consulted Dorje Shugden for advice to escape and was successful in it.  Due to the ban, many of the abbots that were worshippers of Dorje Shugden have been forced to go against the Dalai Lama.

===Pre-Columbian Americas===
In the migration myth of the Mexitin, i.e., the early [[Aztec]]s, a [[mummy]]-bundle (perhaps an [[effigy]]) carried by four priests directed the trek away from the cave of origins by giving oracles. An oracle led to the foundation of [[Mexico-Tenochtitlan]]. The [[Yucatec Maya]]s knew oracle priests or ''chilanes'', literally 'mouthpieces' of the deity. Their written repositories of traditional knowledge, the Books of [[Chilam Balam]], were all ascribed to one famous oracle priest who correctly had predicted the coming of the Spaniards and its associated disasters.

===Sub-Saharan Africa===
The [[Igbo people]] of southeastern [[Nigeria]] in [[Africa]] have a long tradition of using oracles.  In Igbo villages, oracles were usually female [[priest]]esses to a particular deity, usually dwelling in a cave or other secluded location away from urban areas, and, much as the oracles of ancient Greece, would deliver prophecies in an ecstatic state to visitors seeking advice. Two of their ancient oracles became especially famous during the pre-colonial period: the Agbala oracle at [[Awka]] and the Chukwu oracle at [[Arochukwu]].&lt;ref&gt;Webster J.B. and Boahen A.A., ''The Revolutionary Years, West Africa since 1800'', Longman, London, p. 107â€“108.&lt;/ref&gt; Though the vast majority of Igbos today are [[Christianity|Christian]], many of them still use oracles.

Amongst the related [[Yoruba people]]s of the same country, the [[Babalawo]]s (and their female counterparts, the Iyanifas) serve collectively as the principal aspects of the tribe's World-famous [[Ifa divination]] system. Due to this, they customarily officiate at a great many of its traditional and religious ceremonies.

===Norse mythology===
In [[Norse mythology]], [[Odin]] took the severed head of the god [[Mimir]] to [[Asgard]] for consultation as an oracle.  The ''[[Havamal]]'' and other sources relate the [[sacrifice]] of Odin for the oracular [[Runes]] whereby he lost an eye (external sight) and won wisdom (internal sight; [[insight]]).

===Hawaii===
In [[Hawaii]], oracles were found at certain [[heiau]]. These oracles were found in towers covered in white kapa. In here, priests received the will of gods. These towers were called &quot;'Anu'u.&quot; An example of this can be found at Ahu'ena heiau in [[Kona District, Hawaii|Kona]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://gohawaii.about.com/od/bigislandofhawaiiphotos/ig/kailua-kona/kailua_kona_038.htm|title='Anu'u (oracle tower) and Ki'i Akua (temple images) at 'Ahu'ena Heiau in Kailua-Kona on Hawaii's Big Island|author=John Fischer|work=About.com Travel}}&lt;/ref&gt;

'''Kentucky Fried Chicken''' ('''KFC''') is a [[fast food restaurant]] chain that specializes in [[fried chicken]] and is headquartered in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]], United States. It is the world's second largest restaurant chain (as measured by sales) after [[McDonald's]], with almost 20,000 locations globally in 123 countries and territories {{as of|lc=y|December 2015}}. The company is a subsidiary of [[Yum! Brands]], a restaurant company that also owns the [[Pizza Hut]] and [[Taco Bell]] chains.

KFC was founded by [[Colonel Sanders|Harland Sanders]], an entrepreneur who began selling fried chicken from his roadside restaurant in [[Corbin, Kentucky]], during the [[Great Depression]]. Sanders identified the potential of the restaurant [[franchising]] concept, and the first &quot;Kentucky Fried Chicken&quot; franchise opened in [[Utah]] in 1952. KFC popularized chicken in the fast food industry, diversifying the market by challenging the established dominance of the [[hamburger]]. By branding himself as &quot;Colonel Sanders&quot;, Harland became a prominent figure of American cultural history, and his image remains widely used in KFC advertising. However, the company's rapid expansion overwhelmed the aging Sanders and, in 1964, he sold it to a group of investors led by [[John Y. Brown, Jr.]] and [[Jack C. Massey]].

KFC was one of the first fast food chains to expand internationally, opening outlets in [[Canada]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Mexico]], and [[Jamaica]] by the mid-1960s. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, KFC experienced mixed fortunes domestically, as it went through a series of changes in corporate ownership with little or no experience in the restaurant business. In the early 1970s, KFC was sold to the [[distilled spirit|spirits]] distributor [[Heublein]], who were taken over by the [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company|R.J. Reynolds]] food and [[tobacco]] conglomerate, who sold the chain to [[PepsiCo]]. The chain continued to expand overseas however, and in 1987 KFC became the first Western restaurant chain to open in China. The chain has since expanded rapidly in China, which is now the company's single largest market. PepsiCo [[Corporate spin-off|spun off]] its restaurants division as Tricon Global Restaurants, which later changed its name to Yum! Brands.

KFC's original product is [[pressure frying|pressure fried]] chicken pieces, seasoned with Sanders' recipe of 11 herbs and spices. The constituents of the recipe represent a notable [[trade secret]]. Larger portions of fried chicken are served in a cardboard &quot;bucket&quot;, which has become a well known feature of the chain since it was first introduced by franchisee [[Pete Harman]] in 1957. Since the early 1990s, KFC has expanded its menu to offer other chicken products such as [[chicken fillet burger]]s and [[wrap (sandwich)|wrap]]s, as well as [[salad]]s and [[side dish]]es, such as [[French fries]] and [[coleslaw]], desserts, and [[soft drink]]s, the latter often supplied by [[PepsiCo]]. KFC is known for its former and current [[slogan]] &quot;Finger Lickin' Good&quot;, which was replaced by &quot;Nobody does chicken like KFC&quot; and &quot;So good&quot; in the interim.
{{TOC limit|3}}

==History==
{{Main article|History of KFC}}

[[File:Col Sanders Restaurant.png|thumb|right|upright=1.25|The [[Harland Sanders CafÃ© and Museum]]]]
[[Colonel Sanders|Harland Sanders]] was born in 1890 and raised on a farm outside [[Henryville, Indiana]] (near [[Louisville, Kentucky]]).&lt;ref name=autogenerated44&gt;{{cite news|last=Whitworth|first=William|title=Kentucky-Fried|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1970/02/14/1970_02_14_040_TNY_CARDS_000295737|accessdate=February 23, 2013|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=February 14, 1970}}&lt;/ref&gt; When Sanders was five years old, his father died, forcing his mother to work at a [[canning]] plant.&lt;ref name=&quot;Klotter2005&quot;&gt;{{cite book|authorlink=James C. Klotter|last=Klotter|first=James C. |title=The Human Tradition in the New South|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X2UtXHKGj0sC&amp;pg=PA210|accessdate=June 29, 2013|year=2005|publisher=[[Rowman &amp; Littlefield]]|isbn=978-0-7425-4476-5|page=129}}&lt;/ref&gt; This left Sanders, as the eldest son, to care for his two younger siblings.&lt;ref name=&quot;Klotter2005&quot;/&gt; After he reached seven years of age, his mother taught him how to cook.&lt;ref name=autogenerated44 /&gt; After leaving the family home at the age of 13, Sanders passed through several professions, with mixed success.&lt;ref name=celebritychef3&gt;{{cite book|last=Sanders|first=Harland|title=The Autobiography of the Original Celebrity Chef|year=2012|publisher=KFC|location=Louisville|page=15|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/colcookbook/us/pdf/English_FullBook.pdf}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1930, he took over a [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] [[filling station]] on [[U.S. Route 25 in Kentucky|US Route 25]] just outside [[North Corbin, Kentucky]], a small town on the edge of the [[Appalachian Mountains]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Ozersky2012&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Ozersky|first=Josh|title=Colonel Sanders and the American Dream|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qh5AEnwoJuIC|accessdate=September 27, 2013|date=April 2012|publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]|isbn=978-0-292-74285-7|pages=19â€“24}}&lt;/ref&gt; It was here that he first served to travelers the recipes that he had learned as a child: fried chicken and other dishes such as steaks and [[country ham]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Ozersky2012&quot; /&gt; After four years of serving from his own dining room table, Sanders purchased the larger filling station on the other side of the road and expanded to six tables.&lt;ref name=&quot;Aaseng2001&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Aaseng|first=Nathan|title=Business Builders in Fast Food|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vwyiE8Gd8GQC&amp;pg=PA116|accessdate=March 13, 2013|date=January 2001|publisher=Oliver Press|isbn=978-1-881508-58-8|page=116}}&lt;/ref&gt; By 1936, this had proven successful enough for Sanders to be given the honorary title of [[Kentucky colonel]] by [[List of Governors of Kentucky|Governor]] [[Ruby Laffoon]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Smith2011&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew F.|title=Fast Food and Junk Food: An Encyclopedia of What We Love to Eat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wq3tvL_uIHcC&amp;pg=PA612|date=December 2, 2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-39394-5|page=612}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1937 he expanded his restaurant to 142 seats, and added a [[motel]] he purchased across the street, naming it [[Harland Sanders CafÃ© and Museum|Sanders Court &amp; CafÃ©]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Hollis1920&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Hollis|first=Tim|title=Dixie Before Disney: 100 Years of Roadside Fun|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecaVOl1wzg0C&amp;pg=PT19|year=1999|publisher=[[University Press of Mississippi]]|isbn=978-1-61703-374-2|pages=19â€“20}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Sanders was unhappy with the 35 minutes it took to prepare his chicken in an iron frying pan, but he refused to [[deep fry]] the chicken, which he believed lowered the quality of the product.&lt;ref name=autogenerated52&gt;{{cite book|last=Sanders|first=Harland|title=The Incredible Colonel|year=1974|publisher=Creation House|location=Illinois|pages=98â€“131|isbn=978-0-88419-053-0}}&lt;/ref&gt; If he pre-cooked the chicken in advance of orders, there was sometimes wastage at day's end.&lt;ref name=autogenerated44 /&gt; In 1939, the first commercial [[pressure cooker]]s were released onto the market, mostly designed for steaming vegetables.&lt;ref name=&quot;Binney2012&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Binney|first=Ruth|title=Wise Words and Country Ways for Cooks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kfQg_xASoTEC&amp;pg=PA202|date=April 1, 2012|publisher=David &amp; Charles|isbn=978-0-7153-3420-1|page=202}}&lt;/ref&gt; Sanders bought one, and modified it into a [[pressure fryer]], which he then used to fry chicken.&lt;ref name=&quot;history&quot; /&gt; The new method reduced production time to be comparable with deep frying, while, in the opinion of Sanders, retaining the quality of pan-fried chicken.&lt;ref name=autogenerated52 /&gt;

In July 1940, Sanders finalised what came to be known as his &quot;Original Recipe&quot; of 11 herbs and spices.&lt;ref name=july1940&gt;{{cite news|last=Schreiner|first=Bruce|title=KFC still guards Colonel's secret|url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/072305/bus_19314459.shtml|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6LFY4JpRe|archivedate=November 19, 2013|accessdate=September 19, 2013|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=July 23, 2005}}&lt;/ref&gt; Although he never publicly revealed the recipe, he admitted to the use of salt and pepper, and claimed that the ingredients &quot;stand on everybody's shelf&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;Kleber1992&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Kleber|first=John E. |title=The Kentucky Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8eFSK4o--M0C&amp;pg=PA796|accessdate=March 13, 2013|date=May 18, 1992|publisher=[[University Press of Kentucky]]|isbn=978-0-8131-2883-2|page=796}}&lt;/ref&gt; After being recommissioned as a Kentucky colonel in 1950 by Governor [[Lawrence Wetherby]], Sanders began to dress the part, growing a [[goatee]] and wearing a black [[frock coat]] (later switched to a white suit), a [[string tie]], and referring to himself as &quot;Colonel&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;Kleber1992&quot; /&gt; His associates went along with the title change, &quot;jokingly at first and then in earnest&quot;, according to biographer [[Josh Ozersky]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Ozersky&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Ozersky|first=Josh|title=Colonel Sanders and the American Dream|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qh5AEnwoJuIC|accessdate=April 7, 2013|year=2012|publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]|isbn=978-0-292-74285-7|page=25}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Colonel Harland Sanders in character.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Harland Sanders in character as &quot;The Colonel&quot;]]

The Sanders Court &amp; CafÃ© generally served travelers, so when the route planned in 1955 for [[Interstate 75]] bypassed [[Corbin, Kentucky|Corbin]], Sanders sold his properties and traveled the US to franchise his chicken recipe to restaurant owners.&lt;ref name=&quot;JakleSculle1999&quot;&gt;{{cite book|author1=John A. Jakle|author2=Keith A. Sculle|title=Fast Food: Roadside Restaurants in the Automobile Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0nYcgnWKWXgC|accessdate=March 13, 2013|year=1999|publisher=[[JHU Press]]|isbn=978-0-8018-6920-4|page=219}}&lt;/ref&gt; Independent restaurants would pay four (later five) [[cent (currency)|cents]] on each chicken as a franchise fee, in exchange for Sanders' &quot;secret blend of herbs and spices&quot; and the right to feature his recipe on their menus and use his name and likeness for promotional purposes.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated15&quot; /&gt; In 1952 he had already successfully franchised his recipe to his friend [[Pete Harman]] of [[South Salt Lake, Utah]], the operator of one of the city's largest restaurants.&lt;ref name=mashed&gt;{{cite news|author1=Patty Henetz|author2=Jenifer K. Nii|title=Colonel's landmark KFC is mashed|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/595057690/Colonels-landmark-KFC-is-mashed.html|accessdate=November 13, 2013|newspaper=[[Deseret Morning News]]|date=April 21, 2004}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Don Anderson, a sign painter hired by Harman, coined the name &quot;Kentucky Fried Chicken&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated26&quot; /&gt; For Harman, the addition of KFC was a way of differentiating his restaurant from competitors; a product from Kentucky was exotic, and evoked imagery of [[Southern hospitality]].&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated26&quot; /&gt; Harman trademarked the phrase &quot;It's finger lickin' good&quot;, which eventually became the company-wide slogan.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated15&quot; /&gt; He also introduced the &quot;bucket meal&quot; in 1957 (14 pieces of chicken, five [[bread roll]]s and a [[pint]] of [[gravy]] in a cardboard bucket).&lt;ref name=Darden1&gt;{{cite book|last=Darden|first=Robert|title=Secret Recipe: Why Kfc Is Still Cooking After 50 Years|date=January 1, 2004|publisher=Tapestry Press|isbn=978-1-930819-33-7|pages=12, 57â€“58, 101, 159, 175, 211}}&lt;/ref&gt; Serving their signature meal in a paper bucket was to become an iconic feature of the company.&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt;

By 1963 there were 600 KFC restaurants, making the company the largest fast food operation in the United States.&lt;ref name=&quot;JakleSculle1999&quot; /&gt; KFC popularized chicken in the fast food industry, diversifying the market by challenging the established dominance of the [[hamburger]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Smith2007&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Andrew F.|title=The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AoWlCmNDA3QC|accessdate=March 11, 2013|page=341|date=May 1, 2007|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=978-0-19-530796-2}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 1964, Sanders sold the company to a group of investors led by [[John Y. Brown Jr.]] and [[Jack C. Massey]] for US$2 million (around US$15 million in 2013).&lt;ref name=&quot;Smith2011&quot; /&gt; The contract included a lifetime salary for Sanders and the agreement that he would be the company's quality controller and trademark.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-5&quot; /&gt; The chain had reached 3,000 outlets in 48 different countries by 1970.&lt;ref name=autogenerated40&gt;{{cite book|last=Aaseng|first=Nathan|title=Business Builders in Fast Food|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vwyiE8Gd8GQC&amp;pg=PA158|accessdate=March 13, 2013|date=January 1, 2001|publisher=The Oliver Press, Inc.|isbn=978-1-881508-58-8|page=125}}&lt;/ref&gt; In July 1971, Brown sold the company to the [[Connecticut]]-based [[Heublein]], a packaged food and drinks corporation, for US$285 million (around US$1.6 billion in 2013).&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-10&quot; /&gt; Sanders died in 1980, his promotional work making him a prominent figure in American cultural history.&lt;ref name=&quot;Smith2007&quot; /&gt; By the time of his death, there were an estimated 6,000 KFC outlets in 48 different countries worldwide, with $2 billion of sales annually.&lt;ref name=washpostobit&gt;{{cite news|last=Smith|first=J. Y.|title=Col. Sanders, the Fried-Chicken Gentleman, Dies|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 17, 1980}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 1982, Heublein was acquired by [[R. J. Reynolds]], the tobacco giant.&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt; In July 1986, Reynolds sold KFC to [[PepsiCo]] for $850 million (around US$1.8 billion in 2013).&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-15&quot; /&gt; PepsiCo made the chain a part of its restaurants division alongside [[Pizza Hut]] and [[Taco Bell]].&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated2&quot; /&gt; The Chinese market was entered in November 1987, with an outlet in [[Beijing]].&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt;

In 1991, the KFC name was officially adopted, although it was already widely known by that [[initialism]].&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated16&quot; /&gt; Kyle Craig, president of KFC US, admitted the change was an attempt to distance the chain from the unhealthy connotations of &quot;fried&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=And Now, Finger Lickin' Good For Ya?|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/1991-02-17/and-now-finger-lickin-good-for-ya|accessdate=February 5, 2013|newspaper=[[Businessweek]]|date=February 17, 1991}}&lt;/ref&gt; The early 1990s saw a number of successful major products launched throughout the chain, including spicy &quot;Hot Wings&quot; (launched in 1990), popcorn chicken (1992), and internationally, the &quot;Zinger&quot;, a spicy chicken fillet burger (1993).&lt;ref name=newitems&gt;{{cite news |title=A feast of bargains |url= |newspaper=[[Sunday Herald Sun]] |date=May 31, 1992}}&lt;/ref&gt; By 1994, KFC had 5,149 outlets in the US, and 9,407 overall, with over 100,000 employees.&lt;ref name=autogenerated31&gt;{{cite book|author1=John A. Jakle|author2=Keith A. Sculle|title=Fast Food: Roadside Restaurants in the Automobile Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0nYcgnWKWXgC|accessdate=March 11, 2013|year=1999|publisher=[[JHU Press]]|isbn=978-0-8018-6920-4|page=221}}&lt;/ref&gt; In August 1997, PepsiCo spun off its restaurants division as a public company valued at US$4.5 billion (around US$6.5 billion in 2013).&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-19&quot; /&gt; The new company was named [[Tricon Global Restaurants]], and at the time had 30,000 outlets and annual sales of US$10 billion (around US$14 billion in 2013), making it second in the world only to McDonald's.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-21&quot; /&gt; Tricon was renamed [[Yum! Brands]] in May 2002.&lt;ref name=tricontoyum&gt;{{cite news|title=Tricon Global Restaurants Shareholders Approve Company Name Change to Yum! Brands, Inc.|url=http://www.qsrmagazine.com/news/tricon-global-restaurants-shareholders-approve-company-name-change-yum-brands-inc|accessdate=November 20, 2013|newspaper=QSR Magazine|date=May 16, 2002}}&lt;/ref&gt;

By 2015, the company was struggling, having lost business to other retailers and being surpassed by [[Chick-fil-A]] as the leading chicken retailer three years previously. To combat this, the company launched a new initiative with a plan to revamp its packaging, decor and uniforms, as well as expanding its menu. Additionally, beginning in May 2015, a new series of advertisements was launched featuring [[Darrell Hammond]] as Colonel Sanders.&lt;ref name=&quot;2015revamp&quot;&gt;{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2015/05/25/the-fried-chicken-wars-inside-kfcs-weird-new-fight-to-dethrone-chick-fil-a/|title=The fried-chicken wars: Inside KFC's weird new fight to dethrone Chick-fil-A|first=Drew|last=Harwell|date=May 25, 2015|accessdate=May 27, 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]| archivedate=May 27, 2015| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YpVyK2U4 | deadurl=no}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Operations==
{{See also|List of countries with KFC franchises}}
[[File:KFC Home Base.jpg|thumbnail|A stand-alone KFC [[drive-through]] unit located in Australia]]
[[File:Qatar, Al Khor (24), KFC.JPG|thumbnail|A KFC restaurant in Al-Khor, rural [[Qatar]]]]
[[File:KFC World Operations v2.png|thumbnail|left|KFC world operations as of December 2014&lt;br /&gt;{{colorbox|green}} Countries with KFC restaurants&lt;br /&gt;{{colorbox|lime}} Countries planned to have KFC restaurants&lt;br /&gt;{{colorbox|tomato}} Countries that formerly had KFC restaurants]]
KFC is a subsidiary of Yum! Brands, one of the largest restaurant companies in the world. KFC had sales of $23 billion in 2013.&lt;ref name=yumpresentation /&gt; KFC has its headquarters at 1441 Gardiner Lane, [[Louisville, Kentucky]], in a three-story [[colonial style]] building known colloquially as the &quot;White House&quot; due to its resemblance to the [[White House|US president's home]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Kleber2000&quot; /&gt;&lt;ref name=storey&gt;{{cite news|last=Wolf |first=Barney |title=David Novak's Global Vision |url=http://www.qsrmagazine.com/executive-insights/david-novak-s-global-vision |accessdate=April 3, 2014 |newspaper=QSR Magazine |date=May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20140309202621/http://www.qsrmagazine.com/executive-insights/david-novak-s-global-vision |archivedate=March 9, 2014 }}&lt;/ref&gt; The headquarters contain executive offices and the company's [[research and development]] facilities.&lt;ref name=autogenerated51&gt;{{cite web|title=Yum! Brands 10K 31/12/2011|url=http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1041061/000104106112000005/yum10k123111.htm|publisher=Yum! Brands|accessdate=March 24, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; KFC is [[incorporation (business)|incorporated]] at [[Corporation Trust Center (CT Corporation)|1209 North Orange St]], [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]], [[Delaware]].&lt;ref name=&quot;thimmesch&quot;&gt;{{cite journal |author=Thimmesch, Adam B. |title=The Fading Bright Line of Physical Presence: Did ''KFC Corporation v. Iowa Department of Revenue'' Give States the Secret Recipe for Repudiating ''Quill''? |journal=Kentucky Law Journal |volume=100 |year=2011â€“2012 |pages=339â€“389}}&lt;/ref&gt;

By December 2013, there were 18,875 KFC outlets in 118 countries and territories around the world.&lt;ref name=restcount /&gt; There are 4,563 outlets in China, 4,491 in the United States, and 9,821 across the rest of the world.&lt;ref name=restcount /&gt; Outlets are owned by franchisees or directly by the company.&lt;ref name=&quot;Jing1&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Jing|first=Jun|title=Feeding China's Little Emperors: Food, Children, and Social Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NPI7wHge6CcC&amp;pg=PA123|accessdate=September 27, 2013|year=2000|publisher=[[Stanford University Press]]|isbn=978-0-8047-3134-8|page=123}}&lt;/ref&gt; Eleven percent of outlets are company owned, with the rest operated by franchise holders.&lt;ref name=autogenerated5&gt;{{cite journal|author1=David E. Bell|author2=Mary L. Shelman|title=KFC's Radical Approach To China|journal=Harvard Business Review|date=November 2011|url=http://hbr.org/2011/11/kfcs-radical-approach-to-china/ar/1|accessdate=January 31, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; Although [[capital intensive]], company ownership allows for faster expansion of the chain.&lt;ref name=steyn&gt;{{cite news|last=Steyn|first=Lisa|title=KFC's secret recipe for growth|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-06-21-00-kfcs-secret-recipe-for-growth|accessdate=September 26, 2013|newspaper=[[Mail &amp; Guardian]]|date=June 21, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Most restaurants are furnished with images of the company founder, Colonel Harland Sanders.&lt;ref name=autogenerated51 /&gt; As well as dine-in and take-out, many stand-alone KFC outlets offer a [[drive-through]] option.&lt;ref name=&quot;Cartwright2003&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Cartwright|first=Roger|title=Implementing a Training and Development Strategy: Training and Development 11.8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qyGeqgh8NowC&amp;pg=PA42|date=October 31, 2003|publisher=[[John Wiley &amp; Sons]]|isbn=978-1-84112-494-0|page=42}}&lt;/ref&gt; KFC offers a limited delivery service in a small number of markets.&lt;ref name=&quot;Cartwright2003&quot; /&gt; Units include express concessions and [[kiosks]] which feature a limited menu and operated in non-traditional locations such as filling stations, [[convenience store]]s, [[stadium|stadia]], [[theme park]]s and [[college]]s, where a full scale outlet would not be practical.&lt;ref name=&quot;Cartwright2003&quot; /&gt; Average annual sales per unit was $1.2 million in 2013.&lt;ref name=novakpres&gt;{{cite book|last=Novak|first=David|title=Recognizing the Power of Yum!|date=March 2014|publisher=Yum!|page=9}}&lt;/ref&gt; Worldwide, the daily average number of food orders at an outlet is 250, with most occurring within a two-hour peak-period.&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132&gt;{{cite book|last=Stephens Balakrishnan|first=Melodena|title=East Meets West: the World is Round and Time is Cyclic|year=2013|publisher=[[Emerald Group Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-78190-413-8|pages= 126â€“132 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8CLmuucAqogC&amp;pg=PA126}}&lt;/ref&gt;

As chairman and CEO of Yum!, [[David C. Novak]] ultimately has foremost responsibility for KFC operations.&lt;ref name=ceos /&gt; Sam Su is chairman and CEO of Yum!'s Chinese operations, and [[Muktesh Pant]] is the CEO of KFC.&lt;ref name=ceos/&gt; Richard T. Carucci is president of Yum!, and [[Roger Eaton]] is the COO of Yum! and the president of KFC.&lt;ref name=ceos/&gt;

===Africa===
[[File:KFC, Ilorin.JPG|thumbnail|KFC restaurant in [[Ilorin]], [[Kwara State|Kwara]], Nigeria]]
The company hopes to expand its African operations, where it is already the regional leader among US fast food chains.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=KFC to Expand Steadily Into Africa|url=http://www.kfc.co.za/zone/post/kfc-to-expand-steadily-into-africa/|publisher=KFC South Africa|accessdate=January 28, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Nakkas|first=Laurel|title=Africa: The Final Frontier?|url=http://www.qsrmagazine.com/growth/africa-final-frontier|accessdate=March 13, 2013|newspaper=QSR Magazine|date=February 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The company is slowly expanding across the African continent, opening 70 outlets, but progress has been hampered by sourcing issues, such as a lack of quality suppliers.&lt;ref name=steyn /&gt;

===Asia===
KFC continues to grow in Asia.

In [[Malaysia]], the first KFC restaurant was opened in 1973 on [[Jalan Tunku Abdul Rahman]].&lt;ref name=kfcmalaysia&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.com.my/kfc-malaysia/|title=KFC Malaysia|accessdate=June 12, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are 609 outlets as of June 2016.&lt;ref name=globalrestaurantsystem&gt;{{cite web|title=Complete List of KFC Malaysia Locations|url=https://www.aggdata.com/aggdata/complete-list-kfc-malaysia-locations|accessdate=June 23, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Fast Food in Malaysia|url=http://www.euromonitor.com/fast-food-in-malaysia/report|website=Euromonitor|accessdate=June 12, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1995, Projek Penyayang KFC was founded in an effort to  provide food to more than 150 orphanage every quarter.&lt;ref name=kfcmalaysia/&gt;

In [[Sri Lanka]], KFC was launched in 1995 at [[Majestic City]]. There were 25 KFC restaurants in Sri Lanka as of December 2014.&lt;ref&gt;KFC - Kentucky Fried Chicken, http://www.cargillsceylon.com/OurBusinesses/KFC.aspx&lt;/ref&gt;

In [[Singapore]], the first KFC franchise was opened in Somerset Road. In 1993, KFC Singapore was the first KFC in Asia to develop and launch the Zinger burger. In 2002, KFC Singapore was acquired by KFC (Malaysia) Holdings Bhd.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.com.sg/milestone2|title=About Us Milestone|website=KFC Singapore|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In [[Bangladesh]], the first KFC outlet was opened at [[Gulshan, Dhaka|Gulshan]] in 2006. As of June 2016, the country is home to 19 KFC outlets.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/check-it-out/kfc-opens-new-outlet-mirpur-2-1242682|title=KFC opens new outlet in Mirpur #2|date=June 20, 2016|work=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]|accessdate=July 20, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.transcombd.com/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=5 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231053643/http://www.transcombd.com/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=5 |archivedate=December 31, 2014 |title=Transcom Foods Ltd |work=transcombd.com |accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In [[Cambodia]], KFC first opened on [[Monivong Boulevard]] in [[Phnom Penh]] in 2008.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.com.kh/en/about-us/kfc-history/|title=KFC History|work=kfc.com.kh|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In [[Myanmar]], the first KFC outlet was officially opened on [[Bogyoke Aung San Road]] in [[Yangon]] in 2015.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Mullins|first=Jeremy|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/business/property-news/14310-kfc-s-first-location-will-be-on-bogyoke-aung-san-road.html|title=KFC's first location will be on Bogyoke Aung San Road|newspaper=[[The Myanmar Times]]|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |last=Taylor|first=Adam|url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/2685964-155/myanmar-gets-its-first-taste-of|title=Myanmar gets its first taste of KFC|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=July 1, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

====China====
{{Main article|KFC in China}}
KFC is the largest restaurant chain in China, with 5,003 outlets as of 2015.&lt;ref name=&quot;Yum!-Brands-AR2015&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=https://online.kfc.co.in/about-us|title=KFC India Official Site|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=yum.com|access-date=|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; They are operated by the Yum! China division. KFC became the first Western fast food company in China after its first outlet opened in [[Qianmen]], [[Beijing]], in November 1987.&lt;ref name=autogenerated12&gt;{{cite news|last=Kaiman|first=Jonathan|title=China's fast-food pioneer struggles to keep customers saying 'YUM!'|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/04/china-fast-food-pioneer|accessdate=January 4, 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=January 4, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Local food items include rice [[congee]] and tree fungus salad, with an average of 50 different menu items per store.&lt;ref name=autogenerated12 /&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Shen&quot; /&gt;

In December 2012, the chain faced allegations that some of its suppliers injected [[antiviral drug]]s and [[growth hormone]]s into poultry in ways that violated food safety regulations.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Waldmeir|first=Patti|title=Yum investigates poultry allegations|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|location=London|date=December 20, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; This resulted in the chain severing its relationship with 100 suppliers, and agreeing to &quot;actively co-operate&quot; with a government investigation into its use of antibiotics.&lt;ref name=autogenerated12 /&gt; KFC China sales in January 2013 were down 41 percent against the previous year.&lt;ref name=autogenerated41&gt;{{cite news|last=Coonan|first=Clifford|title=Scare takes bite out of KFC's sales|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2013/0212/1224329945842.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213010330/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2013/0212/1224329945842.html|archivedate=February 13, 2013|accessdate=February 12, 2013|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|location=Dublin|date=February 12, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; To counter sluggish sales, the menu was revamped in 2014.&lt;ref name=revampchina&gt;{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Venessa|title=To Start Fresh in China, KFC Goes for a Menu Makeover|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-03-27/to-start-fresh-in-china-kfc-goes-for-a-menu-makeover|accessdate=March 28, 2014|newspaper=[[Businessweek]]|date=March 27, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In July 2014, Chinese authorities closed down the [[Shanghai]] operations of the [[OSI Group]], amidst allegations that it had supplied KFC with expired meat.&lt;ref name=2014chinasafety&gt;{{cite news|last1=Hornby|first1=Lucy|title=McDonald's and KFC hit by China food safety scandal|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c84e2dfa-10ac-11e4-b116-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3B8IBoFUv|accessdate=August 22, 2014|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|location=London|date=July 21, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; Yum! immediately terminated its contract with the supplier, and stated that the revelation had led to a &quot;significant [and] negative&quot; decline in sales.&lt;ref name=yumresponse14&gt;{{cite news|last1=Ramakrishnan|first1=Sruthi|title=Yum says China food safety scare hurting KFC, Pizza Hut sales|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/30/us-china-food-idUSKBN0FZ2H320140730|accessdate=August 22, 2014|agency=Reuters|date=July 30, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

KFC will open its first outlet in Tibet in 2016.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/business/kfc-to-open-1st-outlet-in-tibet/168798.html|title=KFC to open 1st outlet in Tibet|work=[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]|date=December 10, 2015|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;

====India====
[[File:Kolkata Choweinghee 6.jpg|thumb|KFC outlet on Middleton Row in [[Kolkata]].]]
[[File:KFC Polayathode, Kollam city.jpg|right|thumb|KFC in [[Polayathode]], [[Kollam]] city. This is one of the largest KFC stores in [[Kerala]] state, [[India]]]]
There are 350 KFC outlets in India.&lt;ref name=&quot;Yum!-Brands-AR2015&quot;/&gt;  The company has adapted the standard KFC offerings to Indian tastes and the menu options in India include the ever-popular Hot &amp; Crispy Chicken and Fiery Grilled bucket options, Chicken Zinger Burger, Rice Bowlz, the more recently launched 5-in-1 Meal Box and a range of shakes called Krushers.&lt;ref name=&quot;India Infoline&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=KFC Menu on Zomato|url= https://www.zomato.com/ncr/kfc-sector-18-noida/menu#tabtop
}}&lt;/ref&gt; The business was refranchised in October 2015 after Yum concluded a year-and-a-half-long exercise to reorganize its business under larger, well-capitalized franchisees. In this regard, about a third of its outlets, operated by several of its franchisees, have been sold to a newly formed entityâ€”Sapphire Foods India Pvt. Ltd. The new entity is owned by a consortium of fourâ€Šprivate equity funds, led by Samara Capital. The other investors are CX Partners, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and a fourth fund, said a top executive at the local arm of the American food company.&lt;ref name=&quot;Live Mint&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=With Sapphire Foods franchisee, Yum reorganizes India business|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/jChCarxfXopS8iiI5X4E7H/With-Sapphire-Foods-franchisee-Yum-reorganizes-India-busine.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;
