The first Indian KFC was a two-storey outlet on the fashionable [[Brigade Road]] in [[Bangalore]] in June 1995.&lt;ref name=&quot;TichyMcGill1997&quot; /&gt; According to journalist [[Michael White (journalist)|Michael White]], the company could not have chosen a &quot;more difficult venue for its maiden entrÃ©e into the country&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;White2009&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=White|first=Michael|title=A Short Course in International Marketing Blunders: Mistakes Made by Companies that Should Have Known Better|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zz1L3nnNmMcC&amp;pg=PA68|year=2009|publisher=World Trade Press|isbn=978-1-60780-008-8|page=68}}&lt;/ref&gt; Bangalore housed the headquarters of the [[Karnataka Rajya Raitha Sangha]], one of the most influential, vocal and anti-foreign investment farmers' associations in the country.&lt;ref name=&quot;White2009&quot; /&gt; The first outlet suffered protests from [[Left-wing politics|left wing]], [[anti-globalisation]] and [[environmental movement|environmental]] campaigners, as well as local farmers, who objected to the chain bypassing local producers.&lt;ref name=&quot;BergerHuntington2003&quot; /&gt; Many{{quantify|date=September 2015}} Indians were concerned about the onslaught of [[consumerism]], the loss of national self-sufficiency, and the disruption of indigenous traditions.&lt;ref name=&quot;DernÃ©2008&quot; /&gt; The protests came to a head in August 1995, when the Bangalore outlet was repeatedly ransacked.&lt;ref name=&quot;TichyMcGill1997&quot; /&gt; The KFC outlet in Bangalore demanded, and received, a police van permanently parked outside for a year.&lt;ref name=&quot;BergerHuntington2003&quot; /&gt; The outlet was closed on September 13, 1995 by local authorities, who claimed the company used illegally high amounts of [[monosodium glutamate]] (MSG) in its food.&lt;ref name=&quot;Dayal-GulatiJain2010&quot; /&gt; The outlet re-opened a few hours later as the result of an appeal by KFC to the [[Karnataka High Court]]. The company stated the recipe was no different than that used in any other KFC store.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=KFC's India outlet reopens: India's first Kentucky Fried...|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-09-13/news/9509140320_1_karnataka-reopens-local-authorities|accessdate=November 19, 2013|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=September 13, 1995}}&lt;/ref&gt; Rural activist [[M. D. Nanjundaswamy]] claimed KFC would adversely affect the health of the impoverished, by diverting grain from poor people to make the more profitable animal feed.&lt;ref name=&quot;Gupta1998&quot; /&gt; Environmentalist [[Maneka Gandhi]] joined the anti-KFC movement.&lt;ref name=&quot;Gupta1998&quot; /&gt; A second outlet opened in [[Delhi]], but was closed by the authorities throughout November, purportedly for health reasons, but more likely to avoid a repetition of the Bangalore incident.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Reuters|title=Fried chicken outlet stays shut|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|date=November 14, 1995}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Delhi outlet soon closed permanently.&lt;ref name=amrit&gt;{{cite news|last=Dhillon|first=Amrit|title=India has no beef with fast-food chains|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|date=March 23, 2002}}&lt;/ref&gt;

KFC began to expand outside of Bangalore in 2004,&lt;ref name=tandoori&gt;{{cite news|title=KFC to give Tandoori chicken a run in Punjab|newspaper=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]|date=November 27, 2004}}&lt;/ref&gt; with a localized menu that was the most extensive meat-free menu across the chain's worldwide operations. It introduced a vegetarian menu that included rice meals, wraps and side dishes and, like McDonald's, served eggless mayonnaise and sauces. Unnat Varma, marketing director of KFC India, states &quot;The vegetarian offerings have made the brand more relevant to a larger section of consumers and that is necessary for KFC's growth.&quot; KFC also began using Indian spices and cooking techniques to localize its chicken dishes. By 2008â€“09, KFC operated 34 outlets in India.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Made for India: Succeeding in a Market Where One Size Won't Fit All|url=http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/made-for-india-succeeding-in-a-market-where-one-size-wont-fit-all/|work=Wharton|publisher=Wharton|accessdate=November 19, 2013|date=March 12, 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2014, KFC launched the &quot;So Veg, So Good&quot; menu as part of an India-specific promotional strategy focused on enhancing their vegetarian range. The company has been up to a lot of innovation over the past few months with the launch of the first-ever no crust, all chicken KFC Chizza in December 2016.&lt;ref name=&quot;IIFL&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=KFC launches first-ever no crust, all-chicken KFC Chizza|url=http://www.indiainfoline.com/article/news-business/kfc-launches-first-ever-no-crust-all-chicken-kfc-chizza-115122200459_1.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;  More recently, KFC got [[Mumbai]]'s [[dabbawala]]s to deliver its newly launched 5-in-1 Meal Boxes. The city's dabbawalas, famed for their efficient delivery of office lunches, took on the role of KFC delivery men as part of an innovative marketing campaign. They supplied specially created 5-in-1 meal boxes to some office-goers instead of their regular dabbas.&lt;ref name=&quot;India Today&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=In a clever campaign, KFC gets Mumbai's dabbawalas to deliver meal boxes|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mumbai-dabbawalas-kfc-campaign-meal-boxes/1/629611.html}}&lt;/ref&gt; The innovation efforts have continued with the launch of the Watt a Box, a practical new take on the 5-in-1 Meal Box, which can also charge phones.&lt;ref name=&quot;TIME&quot;&gt;{{cite journal|title=KFC's Practical New Box of Chicken Can Charge Phones|url=http://time.com/4376395/kfc-chicken-meal-box-phone-charger/}}&lt;/ref&gt;

====Indonesia====
[[File:KFC Bandung Supermall.jpg|thumb|right|A counter at a KFC in [[Bandung]], Indonesia]]
In [[Indonesia]] KFC is the largest Western restaurant chain, with 466 outlets as of December 2013.&lt;ref name=restcount /&gt;&lt;ref name=rappeport&gt;{{cite news|last=Rappeport|first=Alan|title=Finger lickin' all over the world|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1c6e8168-aa6c-11e1-9331-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1wmH5Xd5J|accessdate=November 13, 2013|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|date=June 3, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; The chain has grown to hold an estimated 32 percent market share, and menu items include spaghetti, wraps and chicken porridge.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Patton|first=Leslie|title=KFC Growth Seen Slowing as Indonesia Limits Franchisees|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-24/kfc-growth-seen-slowing-as-indonesia-limits-franchisees.html|accessdate=February 27, 2013|newspaper=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=February 25, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The master franchisee is PT Fastfood Indonesia.&lt;ref name=autogenerated45 /&gt;

The first outlet opened in Jakarta in 1979.&lt;ref name=autogenerated45&gt;{{cite web|title=Company Profile|url=http://www.kfcindonesia.com/kegiatan-usaha-perusahaan|publisher=KFC Indonesia|accessdate=September 26, 2013}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Salim Group]], Indonesia's largest conglomerate, became a major shareholder in 1990, which provided the company with funds for major expansion.&lt;ref name=autogenerated45 /&gt; Its master franchisee, PT Fastfood Indonesia, was publicly listed on the [[Indonesian Stock Exchange]] in 1993.&lt;ref name=autogenerated45 /&gt;

====Japan====
{{Main article|KFC in Japan}}
Japan is the third-largest market for KFC after China and the United States with 1,200 outlets.&lt;ref name=yumstores&gt;{{cite web|title=Top 25 Markets&amp;nbsp;â€” Traditional Stores (Year-End 2012)|url=http://yum.com/investors/restcounts.asp|publisher=Yum! Brands|accessdate=June 29, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

KFC Japan was formed in 1970 as a [[joint venture]] between the American parent and the Japanese [[Mitsubishi Corporation]].&lt;ref name=mitsubishi&gt;{{cite web|title=KFC Japan|url=http://www.mitsubishicorp.com/jp/en/mclibrary/projectstory/vol02/|publisher=Mitsubishi Corporation|accessdate=June 29, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In December 1974, KFC Japan began to promote fried chicken as a [[Christmas]] meal.&lt;ref name=mitsubishi2&gt;{{cite web|title=KFC Japan|url=http://www.mitsubishicorp.com/jp/en/mclibrary/projectstory/vol02/page2.html|publisher=[[Mitsubishi Corporation]]|accessdate=June 29, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; Eating KFC as a Christmas time meal has since become a widely practiced custom in Japan.&lt;ref name=xmas&gt;{{cite news|last=Whipp|first=Lindsay|title=All Japan wants for Christmas is Kentucky Fried Chicken|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bb2dafc6-0ba4-11e0-a313-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2XRv8gnig |accessdate=June 29, 2013|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|date=December 19, 2010}}{{Subscription required}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In December 2007, Mitsubishi assumed majority control of KFC Japan in a JPÂ¥ 14.83 billion transaction.&lt;ref name=jt&gt;{{cite news|title=Mitsubishi takes over Kentucky Fried Chicken Japan for Â¥14.83 billion|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2007/12/09/business/mitsubishi-takes-over-kentucky-fried-chicken-japan-for-14-83-billion/#.Uc8qVvnVDK0|accessdate=June 29, 2013|newspaper=[[Japan Times]]|date=December 9, 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Europe===

====United Kingdom====
[[File:KFC, Belfast, June 2010.JPG|thumb|left|A KFC in [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland]]
As of December 2013, there were 784 KFC outlets in the United Kingdom.&lt;ref name=restcount /&gt; British turnover was around Â£684.5 million in 2013, according to Technomic.&lt;ref name=kfcukbw&gt;{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Venessa|title=For KFC's New Look in Britain, Less Colonel and More Chipotle|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-11-24/for-kfcs-new-look-in-britain-less-colonel-and-more-chipotle|accessdate=November 25, 2014|work=Businessweek|date=November 24, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; About 70 percent of outlets are run by franchisees, with the remainder company owned.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014&gt;{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Andrew|title=Fast food and appetite for growth suits veteran KFC boss just fine|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/10791472/KFC-boss-Martin-Shuker-has-an-appetite-for-finger-lickin-food-and-growth.html|accessdate=April 28, 2014|newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=April 28, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; The company employs 24,000 people.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; Around 400 sites are drive-through outlets.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; Average outlet turnover is between Â£1 and Â£1.5 million.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt;

Annual sales amount to 60,000 [[metric tonne]]s of chicken, 60 percent of which is purchased from the four largest suppliers in the UK, including [[Faccenda Group]]&lt;ref name=faccenda&gt;{{cite news|last=Machell|first=Ben|title=Nando's: the A-list's favourite food|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/celebrity/article3849309.ece|accessdate=August 22, 2013|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=August 22, 2013}}{{Subscription required}}&lt;/ref&gt; and [[2 Sisters Food Group]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Shanahan|first=Andrew|title=Anatomy of a dish|url=http://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/oct/28/food.lifeandhealth|accessdate=January 6, 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=October 28, 2005}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Stiff|first=Peter|title=Chickens and Fox's reap rewards|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=July 6, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and delivered fresh to outlets at least three times a week.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-40&quot; /&gt; The remaining 40 percent is sourced from companies in Europe, Thailand (including [[Charoen Pokphand Foods]]) and Brazil.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated18&quot; /&gt; All of the Original Recipe chicken is sourced within the UK.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated18&quot; /&gt;

England had the first overseas branch of KFC which opened in [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], Lancashire in May 1965, and was the first American fast food restaurant chain in the country, pre-dating the arrival of McDonald's, Burger King and [[Pizza Hut]] by almost a decade.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-37&quot; /&gt; Ray Allen, an experienced Lancashire caterer, was the first franchisee.&lt;ref name=lep&gt;{{cite news|title=Britain's first Kentucky Fried Chicken flies the coop after 49 years|url=http://www.lep.co.uk/news/britain-s-first-kentucky-fried-chicken-flies-the-coop-after-49-years-1-6987614|accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=Lancashire Evening Post|date=December 4, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; The first London branch opened in [[North Finchley]] in November 1968.&lt;ref name=londonkfc&gt;{{cite web|title=Eating Out 1950â€“2000|url=http://www.20thcenturylondon.org.uk/eating-out-1950-2000|publisher=20th Century London|accessdate=August 18, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1971 there were 31 outlets; by 1975 the chain had grown to 250 outlets.&lt;ref name=nov75&gt;{{cite news|title=Business Around the World|newspaper=[[U.S. News &amp; World Report]]|date=November 3, 1975}}&lt;/ref&gt; In the late 1970s and throughout the 1980s, KFCs began to introduce seating. KFC opened its first drive through restaurant in the UK in 1984.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|title=Hotels &amp; Restaurants International|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fb5aAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=August 19, 2013|year=1984|publisher=''[[Restaurants &amp; Institutions|Restaurants &amp; Institutions Magazine]]''|page=107}}&lt;/ref&gt; By 1987 the company had almost 400 outlets.&lt;ref name=&quot;JacobsScholliers2003&quot;&gt;{{cite book|author1=Marc Jacobs|author2=Peter Scholliers|title=Eating Out in Europe: Picnics, Gourmet Dining and Snacks Since the Late Eighteenth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0AYbEC2xNSoC&amp;pg=PA307|accessdate=August 19, 2013|date=June 2003|publisher=Berg|isbn=978-1-85973-658-6|page=307}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In May 1997, the &quot;Tower Burger&quot;, a fried chicken fillet burger with the addition of a [[hash brown]], was first launched in the United Kingdom.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author1=Nick Jones |author2=Simeon Duckworth |author3=Christian Cocker |title=Success by the bucket load: Advertising's contribution to building the KFC brand|newspaper=Institute of Practitioners in Advertising: IPA Effectiveness Awards, 1998|year=1998}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2006, the company stopped pre-salting its fries and removed trans fats from its products.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; In 2012 palm oil was replaced by rapeseed oil in the fryers.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; Between 2004 and 2014, KFC UK increased its offering of &quot;portable&quot; foods: burgers, wraps and salads.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; During that period, sales rose from around Â£500 million to almost Â£1 billion.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; In 2012, KFC UK invested Â£9 million to install ovens in all of its outlets, so that it could offer griddled chicken.&lt;ref name=shukerinterview2014 /&gt; In 2013, KFC rolled out [[Lavazza]] coffee across all of its UK outlets.&lt;ref name=lavazza&gt;{{cite news|last=Reynolds|first=John|title=KFC gets serious about coffee with full UK rollout|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1178345/kfc-gets-serious-coffee-full-uk-rollout|accessdate=September 26, 2013|newspaper=Marketing|date=April 15, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; As of 2014, KFC UK is trialling serving only [[halal]] meat at 96 of its outlets.&lt;ref name=halaluk&gt;{{cite news|author1=Emily Davies |author2=Tania Steere |author3=Mark Duell |title=Pizza Express reveal ALL the chicken they use is halal - but they don't tell customers unless they ask staff|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2622052/Pizza-Express-reveal-chicken-use-halal-dont-tell-customers-unless-ask-staff.html|accessdate=May 7, 2014|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London|date=May 7, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Middle East===
The first KFC in the Middle East opened in 1973 in Kuwait. Today there are over 700 outlets, certified [[halal]], including the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite web|url=http://www.kfc-arabia.com/english/our-story/kfc-mena|title=KFC Arabia|website=KFC Arabia|access-date=April 12, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[KFC Israel]] existed from 1993 to 2013 and featured [[Kashrut|kosher]] restaurants.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3683023,00.html|title=KFC Israel going kosher|website=ynet|access-date=April 12, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2012 KFC opened in [[Ramallah]] in the Palestinian Authority&lt;sup&gt;[[KFC Israel|[8]]]&lt;/sup&gt; and later expanded to Hebron,&lt;sup&gt;[[KFC Israel|[9]]]&lt;/sup&gt; Bethlehem,&lt;sup&gt;[[KFC Israel|[10]]]&lt;/sup&gt; Jenin,&lt;sup&gt;[[KFC Israel|[11]]]&lt;/sup&gt; and three separate outlets in Ramallah: the Ersal Branch (Bacri), Plaza Mall Branch and Masyoun Branch.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/02/kfc-pizza-hut-in-the-palestinian-territories.html|title=American fried chicken comes to the Palestinian territories|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 4, 2012|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2013 the New York Times reported that KFC was being smuggled into Gaza through tunnels.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/16/world/middleeast/tunneling-kfc-to-gazans-craving-the-world-outside.html|title=Delivering KFC by Tunnel, Not Too Fast but Satisfying|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 15, 2013|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/smuggled-chicken-nuggets-hit-gaza/|title=Smuggled chicken tunnels into Gaza|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=May 16, 2013|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===North America===
[[File:KFCPromenade.JPG|thumb|right|A KFC in Canada.]]
====United States====
[[File:Kfc taco bell.jpg|thumb|right|A co-branded KFC-Taco Bell in [[Oscoda, Michigan]]]]
KFC sales in the United States in 2013 were estimated at $4.22 billion by Technomic.&lt;ref name=fila&gt;{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Venessa|title=Chick-fil-A Stole KFC's Chicken Crown With a Fraction of the Stores|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-03-28/chick-fil-a-stole-kfcs-chicken-crown-with-a-fraction-of-the-stores|accessdate=March 30, 2014|newspaper=[[Businessweek]]|date=March 28, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The basic model for KFC in the United States, not necessarily duplicated elsewhere, is a focus on low prices, a limited menu (29 items on average) and an emphasis on takeout.&lt;ref name=autogenerated5 /&gt; A [[Fried chicken#Racial stereotype|&quot;very strong percentage&quot; of sales]] come from African American customers.&lt;ref name=africanamerican&gt;{{cite journal|last=Soeder|first=John|title=Trendinista|journal=Restaurant Hospitality|date=September 1993|volume=77|issue=9|page=31}}&lt;/ref&gt; Many KFC locations are [[Colocation (business)|co-located]] with either [[Taco Bell]] or Pizza Hut, or other Yum! restaurants.&lt;ref name=&quot;Cartwright2003&quot; /&gt; When Yum! owned [[Long John Silver's]] and [[A&amp;W Restaurants]], these brands were often co-branded with KFC as well.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&amp;p_multi=DSNB&amp;d_place=DSNB&amp;p_theme=newslibrary2&amp;p_action=search&amp;p_maxdocs=200&amp;p_topdoc=1&amp;p_text_direct-0=0F37F1EBCB5C5B9A&amp;p_field_direct-0=document_id&amp;p_perpage=10&amp;p_sort=YMD_date:D&amp;s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Partnering for success,  Firms finding that co-branding makes economic sense|date=January 13, 2002|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; Often these locations behave like a single restaurant, offering one menu with food items from both restaurant brands.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-33&quot; /&gt; In 2003, there were 354 KFC-Taco Bell combines, offering the full KFC menu and Taco Bell items, and 13 units offering the full KFC menu and a limited number of Pizza Hut items.&lt;ref name=&quot;Cartwright2003&quot; /&gt; The concept originated in 1991, when a KFC-Taco Bell combination opened in [[Virginia]].&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt; Some locations were also opened as combinations of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, but this failed to catch on, and Yum! CEO David Novak blamed a lack of franchisee commitment for its lack of success.&lt;ref name=&quot;Novak2012&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Novak|first=David|title=Taking People with You: The Only Way to Make Big Things Happen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4vEiAHlWfToC|accessdate=March 11, 2013|date=January 26, 2012|publisher=[[Penguin Books|Penguin Books, Limited]]|isbn=978-0-241-95413-3}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Initially, Sanders and KFC used [[hydrogenated vegetable oil]] for frying, but in the 1980s the company began to switch to cheaper oils such as [[palm oil|palm]] or [[soybean oil|soybean]].&lt;ref&gt;''The Ford Show'', ABC https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cF4ph_gKcpI&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated19&quot; /&gt; In the 2000s it became apparent that these oils contain relatively high levels of [[trans fat]], which increases the risk of [[heart disease]]. By April 2007, the chain had switched to trans fat-free soybean oil in all of its US outlets.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=KFC, Taco Bell finish switch to trans-fat-free oil|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/18383687/ns/health-diet_and_nutrition/t/kfc-taco-bell-finish-switch-trans-fat-free-oil/#.UQp1Eyc03K1|accessdate=January 18, 2013|newspaper=[[NBC News]]|date=April 30, 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2008, Novak credited low US sales as being the result of a lack of new ideas and menu items.&lt;ref name=courierlow&gt;{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Alex|title=Yum chief Novak takes on KFC's weak results|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20080717/BUSINESS/80717019/Yum-chief-Novak-takes-KFC-s-weak-results?nclick_check=1|accessdate=September 27, 2013|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|date=July 17, 2008}}{{subscription required}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Spring 2009 launch of Kentucky Grilled Chicken only resulted in a temporary halt to the sales decline.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated23&quot; /&gt; In 2010 KFC announced a turnaround plan that included improving restaurant operations, introducing [[value theory|value]] items and providing healthier menu options.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated23&quot; /&gt; In the same year, ''[[Advertising Age]]'' noted that KFC was losing market share to its smaller chicken restaurant rival, [[Chick-fil-A]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Bryson|first=Emily|title=KFC's stunts make nightly news, but do nothing to stop sales slide|newspaper=[[Advertising Age]]|date=April 19, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2011 [[Bloomberg News]] referred to KFC US as &quot;an also-ran to McDonald's Corp&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-36&quot; /&gt; In 2012, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine described how many of the KFC outlets were &quot;aged and uninviting&quot;, and that the chain &quot;hasn't introduced an exciting new food item in ages&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Tice|first=Carol|title=Why Popeyes is Buying Up Bankrupt KFC Restaurants|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/caroltice/2012/10/25/popeyes-buys-up-bankrupt-kfc-restaurants/|accessdate=January 28, 2013|newspaper=[[Forbes]]|date=October 25, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

KFC was described in 2012 by ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' as a &quot;muscular player&quot; in developing regions, specifically Africa, China and India, while noting its falling market share in the US to rivals such as Chick-fil-A and [[Popeyes]].&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated21&quot; /&gt; Some analysts speculated that KFC would begin spinning off its ailing US operations.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated21&quot; /&gt; That year, the company began divesting control of company-owned US restaurants to franchised operations, with the intention of reducing overall company ownership from 35 percent to 5 percent.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated21&quot; /&gt;

===Oceania===
[[File:KFC Derwent Park Hobart Australia.jpg|thumb|right|A KFC outlet in [[Derwent Park, Tasmania|Derwent Park]], a northern suburb of [[Hobart]], [[Australia]].]]

There are over 600 KFC outlets in Australia, and around 100 in New Zealand.&lt;ref name=yumstores /&gt; KFC was the first American style fast food chain to open in both countries.&lt;ref name=newzealandjournal&gt;{{cite journal|last=Brailsford|first=Ian|title=If there's not one near you now, there soon will be|journal=New Zealand Journal of History|year=2005|volume=39|series=1|pages=60â€“65|url=http://www.nzjh.auckland.ac.nz/docs/2005/NZJH_39_1_05.pdf|accessdate=July 4, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2013, KFC reported an annual turnover of almost 2 billion AUD for its Australia and New Zealand operations.&lt;ref name=ceomag /&gt;

====Australia====
Yum! directly operates 160 KFC outlets in Australia.&lt;ref name=ceomag&gt;{{cite news|title=Serving Up Quality|url=http://www.theceomagazine.com.au/profiles/KFC/Tony-Lowings-KFC.pdf|accessdate=September 26, 2013|newspaper=CEO Magazine|date=July 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The largest of the 53 independent franchisees in Australia is Collins Foods, which operates 169 stores.&lt;ref name=ceomag /&gt;&lt;ref name=collinsbuy&gt;{{cite news|last=King|first=Mike|title=Collins Foods buys 44 KFC restaurants|url=http://finance.ninemsn.com.au/newsbusiness/motley/8762948/collins-foods-buys-44-kfc-restaurants|accessdate=November 28, 2013|newspaper=9 News|date=November 28, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; KFC's major poultry suppliers in Australia are [[Inghams Enterprises|Inghams]], [[Steggles]] and Turi Foods.&lt;ref name=ceomag /&gt;

The first Australian KFC was opened in 1968 in [[Guildford, New South Wales|Guildford]], a suburb of [[Sydney]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Dixon2002&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Dixon|first=Jane|title=The Changing Chicken: Chooks, Cooks and Culinary Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5foS_fQr87EC&amp;pg=PA134|year=2002|publisher=[[UNSW Press]]|isbn=978-0-86840-477-6|page=134}}&lt;/ref&gt; The franchise was owned by a Canadian entrepreneur called Bob Lapointe.&lt;ref name=&quot;Jensen2011&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Jensen|first=Mark|title=The Urban Cook: Collection: Cooking and eating for a sustainable future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TVw9aVTlXtQC&amp;pg=PT97|year=2011|publisher=Murdoch Books|isbn=978-1-74266-937-3|page=97}}&lt;/ref&gt; Between 1970 and 1971, 75 outlets were opened.&lt;ref name=&quot;Jensen2011&quot; /&gt; This had a major impact on Australian chicken production, which increased by 38 percent during the period.&lt;ref name=&quot;Jensen2011&quot; /&gt; By 1995 there were 452 outlets, and the company employed 12,000 staff.&lt;ref name=&quot;Dixon2002&quot; /&gt; That year, Australia produced 35 percent of KFC's international earnings.&lt;ref name=&quot;Dixon2002&quot; /&gt;

====New Zealand====
The first KFC opened in New Zealand in 1971 at [[Royal Oak, New Zealand|Royal Oak]], a suburb of [[Auckland]].&lt;ref name=kfcau&gt;{{cite web|title=About us&amp;nbsp;â€” Milestones |url=http://www.kfc.com.au/about-us/milestones.asp |publisher=KFC Australia |accessdate=July 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130419180701/http://www.kfc.com.au/about-us/milestones.asp |archivedate=April 19, 2013 }}&lt;/ref&gt; By 1980 there were 37 outlets.&lt;ref name=newzealandjournal /&gt; In 1989, PepsiCo acquired the 50 percent stake in KFC New Zealand that it did not already own from the local [[Goodman Fielder]] conglomerate.&lt;ref name=kfcau /&gt; In 1991 New Zealand turnover topped 100 million NZD for the first time.&lt;ref name=kfcau /&gt;

==Products==
[[File:KFC Shrimp Burger 2007.jpg|thumb|KFC shrimp burger in KFC Vietnam, 2007]]
[[File:16-03-02-Hot-Wings-KFC-Berlin-N3S 3711.jpg|thumb|Hot Wings menu set in KFC Berlin]]
[[File:KFC (Malaysia), Hot Wings fried chicken.jpg|thumbnail|KFC Hot Wings fried chicken in KFC Malaysia.]]
KFC's core product offering is [[Pressure frying|pressure fried]], on-the-bone chicken pieces seasoned with Colonel Harland Sanders' &quot;Original Recipe&quot; of 11 herbs and spices. The product is typically available in either two or three piece individual servings, or in a family size cardboard bucket, typically holding between 6 and 16 chicken pieces. Poultry is divided into 9 different cuts (2 [[Drumstick (poultry)#Cuts of poultry|drumsticks]], 2 [[Drumstick (poultry)#Cuts of poultry|thighs]], 2 [[chicken wing|wings]], 1 [[keel (bird anatomy)|keel]], and a [[Vertebral column|backbone]] based [[chicken breast|breast]] cut divided into 2 pieces).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Nutrition Guide|url=http://kfc.ca/en/assets/pdf/KFC11834_NutritionalChart_Eng.pdf|publisher=KFC Canada|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The product is hand-breaded at individual KFC outlets with [[wheat flour]] mixed with seasoning in a two- to four-minute process.&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132 /&gt;&lt;ref name=ceomag /&gt; [[File:KFC Coffee Mug, Dhaka.jpg|thumb|left|KFC Breakfast Coffee Cup in KFC Dhaka]]It is then pressure fried for between seven and ten minutes (the timing differs between countries) in oil at 185 degrees [[Celsius]].&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132 /&gt;&lt;ref name=cooktemp&gt;{{cite web|title=Secret of Kentucky Fried Chicken taste|url=http://www.kfc.co.jp/brand/from_kfc/index07.html|work=KFC Japan|publisher=Yum!|accessdate=November 13, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=howitsmade&gt;{{cite news|last1=Chan|first1=Casey|title=This is How KFC Actually Makes its Fried Chicken From Beginning to End|url=http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2014/10/this-is-how-kfc-actually-makes-its-fried-chicken-from-beginning-to-end/|accessdate=November 25, 2014|work=Gizmondo|date=October 28, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; Following this, the chicken is left to stand for 5 minutes in order for it to sufficiently cool before it is placed in the warming oven.&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132 /&gt; It is KFC policy to discard chicken if it has not been sold within 90 minutes, in order to ensure freshness.&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132 /&gt; The frying oil varies regionally, and versions used include [[sunflower oil|sunflower]], [[soybean oil|soybean]], [[rapeseed]] and [[palm oil]].&lt;ref name=steyn /&gt; A KFC executive stated that the taste of the chicken will vary between regions depending on the oil variety used, and whether the chicken has been corn-fed or wheat-fed.&lt;ref name=steyn /&gt;

As well as its core chicken on the bone offering, KFC's major products include chicken burgers (including the Zinger and the Tower burgers); [[wrap (sandwich)|wraps]] (&quot;Twisters&quot; and &quot;Boxmasters&quot;); and a variety of [[finger food]]s, including crispy chicken strips and [[Buffalo wing|hot wings]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Burgers|url=http://www.kfc.co.uk/our-food/burgers|publisher=KFC UK|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Food|url=http://www.kfc.com/food/chicken/|publisher=KFC US|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Popcorn Chicken]] is one of the most widely available KFC products, and consists of small pieces of fried chicken.&lt;ref name=autogenerated24&gt;{{cite news|last=Horovitz|first=Bruce|title=What's next: Fast-food giants hunt for new products to tempt consumers|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=July 3, 2002}}&lt;/ref&gt; In some locations, [[chicken nugget]]s are also sold.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Chicken|url=http://www.kfc.com.au/menu/|publisher=KFC Australia|accessdate=January 1, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

KFC adapts its menu internationally to suit regional tastes, and there are over three hundred KFC menu items worldwide.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated5&quot; /&gt; Some locations, such as the UK and the US, sell [[grilled]] chicken.&lt;ref name=brazer&gt;{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Andrew|title=KFC's Colonel joins the health kick|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/8335445/KFCs-Colonel-joins-the-health-kick.html|accessdate=November 13, 2013|newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=February 20, 2011|location=London}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=grilled&gt;{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Andrew|title=Kentucky Grilled Chicken|url=http://www.theguardian.com/business/andrew-clark-on-america/2009/apr/15/fooddrinks|accessdate=November 13, 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=April 15, 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; In predominantly [[Islamic]] countries, the chicken served is [[halal]].&lt;ref name=Balakrishnan132 /&gt; In Asia there is a preference for spicy foods, such as the Zinger chicken burger.&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-29&quot; /&gt; Some locations in the US sell fried chicken [[Liver (food)|livers]] and [[Gizzard#In cuisine|gizzards]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Nutrition Guide|url=http://www.kfc.com/nutrition/pdf/kfc_nutrition.pdf|publisher=KFC US|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; A small number of US outlets offer an [[all-you-can-eat]] [[buffet]] option with a limited menu.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=Bhasin, Kim |title=The All-You-Can-Eat KFC Buffet Is The Unicorn Of Fast Food|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-all-you-can-eat-kfc-buffet-is-the-unicorn-of-fast-food-2012-10|publisher=''[[Business Insider]]''|date= October 25, 2012|accessdate=October 25, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In multiracial Malaysian markets, KFC also has different limited-time products to cater to different festive seasons such as Ayam Kicap Meletup for [[Eid al-Fitr]] seasons and Golden Treasures for [[Chinese New Year]] in 2015.

A number of territories, such as Japan, Jamaica, Trinidad, Barbados, Ecuador and Singapore sell fried [[seafood]] products under the &quot;Colonel's Catch&quot; banner.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite journal|author1=R Oldakowski|author2=J McEwen|title=The Diffusion of American Fast Food to Ecuador|journal=Material Culture|year=2010|volume=42|issue=2|pages=28â€“49}}&lt;/ref&gt; In Jamaica, what was originally a seasonal offering for the [[Lent]] period was expanded to a year-round offering from 2010.&lt;ref name=lent&gt;{{cite news|title=KFC adds fish to menu permanently|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Foodie-News-KFC-Feb-18_7426429|accessdate=April 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Jamaica Observer]]|date=February 18, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[Value menu]] items are sold under the &quot;Streetwise&quot; name in locations such as Canada.&lt;ref name=streetwise&gt;{{cite news|last=Mattos|first=Melinda|title=Hungry for change|url=http://strategyonline.ca/2010/08/01/who-20100801/|accessdate=November 13, 2013|newspaper=Campaign|date=August 1, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Side dish]]es often include [[French fries]], [[coleslaw]], [[barbecue]] [[baked beans]], [[corn on the cob]], [[mashed potato]], [[bread roll]]s and American [[Biscuit (bread)|biscuits]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Sides|url=http://www.kfc.com/food/sides/|publisher=KFC US|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; Salads include the [[bean salad]], the [[Caesar salad]] and the [[garden salad]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.kfc.co.nz/menu/extras/bean-salad/|title=Bean Salad|work=kfc.co.nz|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; In a number of territories, KFC sell [[onion ring]]s.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Signature Sides|url=http://www.kfc-arabia.com/signeture_sides.html|publisher=KFC Arabia|accessdate=February 2, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In Asia, rice based side dishes such as congee are often sold.&lt;ref name=autogenerated12 /&gt; In Malaysia, chicken meatball soup is sold. In the US and Greece, [[potato wedges]] are sold instead of French fries.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Seasoned Potato Wedges|url=http://www.kfc.com/food/sides/wedges.asp|publisher=KFC US|accessdate=February 2, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[McCormick &amp; Company]] is KFC's largest supplier of sauces, seasonings and marinades, and is a long-term partner in new product development.&lt;ref name=ceomag /&gt;

Due to the company's previous relationship with PepsiCo, most territories supply PepsiCo products, but exceptional territories include Barbados, Greece, New Zealand, the Philippines, Romania, South Africa, and Turkey, which stock drinks supplied by [[The Coca-Cola Company]], and [[Aruba]], which stocks [[RC Cola]] from the [[Cott Corporation]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=KFC Menu: Drinks|url=http://www.kfc.co.za/c/menu/by/group/drinks/|publisher=KFC South Africa|accessdate=February 12, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=romaniadrinks&gt;{{cite web|title=Drinks|url=http://www.kfc.ro/meniu/bauturi|work=Yum!|publisher=KFC Romania|accessdate=April 11, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Drinks 'n' Chills|url=http://www.kfc.gr/#/menu|publisher=KFC Hellas|language=Greek|accessdate=February 2, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |first= Aimee |last= Shaw |date= November 6, 2015 |title= KFC ditches Pepsi for Coke |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&amp;objectid=11540985 |location=Auckland |publisher= The New Zealand Herald |accessdate= February 17, 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; In Peru, the locally popular [[Inca Kola]] is sold.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Piezas, snacks, complementos y bebidas |url=http://www.kfc.com.pe/es/contenido.php?60/menu/piezas,_snacks,_complementos_bebidas.html |publisher=KFC Peru |language=Spanish |accessdate=February 12, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130121212451/http://kfc.com.pe/es/contenido.php?60/menu/piezas,_snacks,_complementos_bebidas.html |archivedate=January 21, 2013 }}&lt;/ref&gt; In a number of Eastern European locations and Portugal, [[beer]] is offered, in addition to soft drinks.&lt;ref name=russiabeer&gt;{{cite web|title=Drinks|url=http://www.kfc.ru/menu/181|work=KFC Russia|publisher=Yum! Brands|accessdate=March 28, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Drinks|url=http://www.kfc-ukraine.com/category/7|publisher=KFC Ukraine|language=Ukrainian|accessdate=February 12, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=port&gt;{{cite web|title=Drinks|url=http://www.kfc.pt/acompanhamentos-bebidas|publisher=KFC Portugal|language=Portuguese|accessdate=September 25, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Launched in 2009, the Krusher/Krushem range of frozen beverages containing &quot;real bits&quot; such as [[Kit Kat]], [[Oreo]] and strawberry [[shortcake]], is available in over 2,000 outlets.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Q1 2010 Yum! Brands, Inc. Earnings Conference Call&amp;nbsp;â€” Final|newspaper=FD (Fair Disclosure) Wire|date=April 15, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Egg [[custard tart]] is a popular dessert worldwide, but other items include [[ice cream sundae]]s and [[tres leches cake]] in Peru.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Postres (Desserts)|url=http://www.kfc.com.pe/es/contenido.php?59/menu/postres.html|publisher=KFC Peru|language=Spanish|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2012, the &quot;KFC am&quot; breakfast menu began to be rolled out internationally, including such items as [[pancake]]s, [[waffle]]s and [[porridge]], as well as fried chicken.&lt;ref name=jargon&gt;{{cite news|last=Jargon|first=Julie|title=Yum's CEO Serves Up New Taco, Growth Plans|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970204059804577229570350332972.html|accessdate=September 27, 2013|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=February 21, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===11 herbs and spices===
{{Main article|KFC Original Recipe}}
[[File:KFC Original Recipe chicken in bucket.jpg|thumb|right|KFC Original Recipe fried chicken]]
Sanders' Original Recipe of &quot;11 herbs and spices&quot; is one of the most famous [[trade secret]]s in the catering industry.&lt;ref name=&quot;Chartrand&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Chartrand|first=Sandra|title=Patents; Many companies will forgo patents in an effort to safeguard their trade secrets|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/05/business/patents-many-companies-will-forgo-patents-effort-safeguard-their-trade-secrets.html?n=Top%2fNews%2fTechnology%2fColumns%2fPatents|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 5, 2001|accessdate=September 27, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The recipe is not [[patent]]ed, because patents eventually expire, whereas trade secrets can remain the [[intellectual property]] of their holders in perpetuity.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=It pays to understand law on trade secrets|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/stories/2001/02/26/editorial2.html?page=all|accessdate=February 22, 2013|newspaper=[[Business First]]|date=February 26, 2001}}&lt;/ref&gt;

A copy of the recipe, signed by Sanders, is held inside a safe inside a vault in KFC's Louisville headquarters, along with eleven vials containing the herbs and spices.&lt;ref name=autogenerated21 /&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author=[[Associated Press]]|title=Colonel's Secret Recipe Gets Bodyguards|url=http://www.cnbc.com/id/26618866/Colonel039s_Secret_Recipe_Gets_Bodyguards|accessdate=January 31, 2013|newspaper=[[CNBC]]|date=September 9, 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; To maintain the secrecy of the recipe, half of it is produced by Griffith Laboratories before it is given to [[McCormick &amp; Company|McCormick]], who add the second half.&lt;ref name=crossan&gt;{{cite news|last=Crossan|first=Rob|title=The A to Z of fried chicken|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=April 26, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

A couple who bought the house formerly occupied by Colonel Sanders found scribbled notes of purportedly the secret recipe. Initially KFC wanted to file a lawsuit against the couple, but in the end, it dropped the lawsuit, claiming the scribbled notes are &quot;nowhere close&quot; to the original recipe.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author=Sabra Chartrand|title=Patents; Many companies will forgo patents in an effort to safeguard their trade secrets.|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/05/business/patents-many-companies-will-forgo-patents-effort-safeguard-their-trade-secrets.html|accessdate=March 12, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 5, 2001}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Equipment===
KFC initially used stove-top covered [[cooking pot]]s to fry its chicken.&lt;ref name=shelton&gt;{{cite news|last=Coomes|first=Steve|title=Winston Shelton: The Colonel's Corporal|newspaper=[[Louisville Magazine]]|date=July 17, 2012|url=http://www.louisville.com/content/winston-shelton-colonels-corporal-food-dining|accessdate=October 1, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In the 1960s, the officially recommended model was the L S Hartzog developed &quot;KFC 20-Head Cooker&quot;, a large device that cost $16,000.&lt;ref name=winston&gt;{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.winstonind.com/kfc/history/|publisher=Winston Industries|accessdate=October 1, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Hartzog model had no oil filtration system, meaning that filtering had to be done manually, and the pressure fryers occasionally exploded, often causing harm to employees.&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt; In 1969, inventor and engineer [[Winston L. Shelton]] developed the &quot;Collectramatic&quot; pressurized fryer to overcome the problems KFC faced in quickly frying chicken to meet growing customer demand. The Collectramatic used precision time  and temperature controls and self-filtered the cooking oil â€“ all while meeting Colonel Sander's legendary high quality standards.&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt; Fred Jeffries, then vice president of purchasing at KFC, claimed that the invention helped fuel the company's rapid expansion and success:
&lt;blockquote&gt;There's no way it (KFC) could have grown like it did without the Collectramatic. Stores were doing about $200,000 a year in sales on average with the pots . . . but they could never have done the $900,000 a year it became without Win's fryer. He (Shelton) helped set the stage for that with true engineering thinking.&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

Although a number of franchisees bought the Collectramatic, which had the support of Colonel Sanders from 1970 onwards, John Y. Brown had given tacit approval to franchisees to exclusively use the older L S Hartzog fryer, saying &quot;Though those old pots were damn dangerous, at least we knew they worked! I was mostly afraid these new fryers would break down in the middle of business.&quot;&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt; Brown warned franchisees that they were in violation of their contract if they used the Collectramatic.&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt; Brown held his ground on the issue until he learned that his father, John Y. Brown, Sr., who owned multiple KFC franchises, was successfully using the Collectramatic in every franchise he owned.&lt;ref name=shelton /&gt;  The issue was eventually resolved after Heublein purchased KFC, acquired Hartzog and nullified the contract.&lt;ref name=winston /&gt; The Collectramatic has been an approved pressure fryer for KFC from 1972 onwards.&lt;ref name=winston /&gt;

==Advertising==
{{Main article|KFC advertising}}
Colonel Sanders was a key component of KFC advertising until his death in 1980. Despite his death, Sanders remains a key symbol of the company as an &quot;international symbol of hospitality&quot;.&lt;ref name=harvardbiz&gt;{{cite book|last=President and Fellows of Harvard College|title=PepsioCo's Restaurants|year=1994|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|location=Boston|page=9}}&lt;/ref&gt; Early official slogans for the company included &quot;North America's Hospitality Dish&quot; (from 1956) and &quot;We fix Sunday dinner seven nights a week&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=North America's Hospitality Dish|url=http://www.trademarkia.com/north-americas-hospitality-dish-72209166.html|work=Trademarkia|publisher=KFC Corporation|accessdate=March 13, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Dukes|first=Terry|title=KFC: The Animated Colonel Campaign|newspaper=[[Institute of Practitioners in Advertising]]|year=2000|publisher=WARC [World Advertising Center]|url=http://www.warc.com/Content/Documents/A35068_KFC_The_Animated_Colonel_Campaign.content?CID=A35068&amp;ID=a93e70b1-4bea-4cbf-a2d8-436868cc296d&amp;q=AID%3a35068&amp;qr=}}&lt;/ref&gt; The &quot;finger lickin' good&quot; slogan was used from 1956, and went on to become one of the best-known slogans of the 20th century.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated6&quot; /&gt; The trademark expired in the US in 2006.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Reynolds|first=John|title=Profile: Jennelle Tilling, vice-president of marketing, UK and Ireland at KFC|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/article/1063711/profile-jennelle-tilling-vice-president-marketing-uk-ireland-kfc|accessdate=January 28, 2013|newspaper=[[PR Week]]|date=April 6, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The first KFC logo was introduced in 1952 and featured a &quot;Kentucky Fried Chicken&quot; typeface and a logo of the Colonel.&lt;ref name=logohist&gt;{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Ian|title=The Mystery of the Colonel|url=http://www.greynotgrey.com/blog/2012/06/09/the-mystery-of-the-colonel/|publisher=Grey Not Grey|accessdate=April 3, 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Advertising played a key role at KFC after it was sold by Sanders, and the company began to advertise on US television with a budget of US$4 million in 1966.&lt;ref name=rood&gt;{{cite news|last=Rood|first=George|title=Accidental Competitor in Chicken Game Is Winner|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 5, 1969}}&lt;/ref&gt; In order to fund nationwide advertising campaigns, the Kentucky Fried Chicken Advertising Co-Op was established, giving franchisees ten votes and the company three when deciding on budgets and campaigns. In 1969, KFC hired its first national advertising agency, [[Leo Burnett]].&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt; A notable Burnett campaign in 1972 was the &quot;Get a bucket of chicken, have a barrel of fun&quot; [[jingle]], performed by [[Barry Manilow]].&lt;ref name=Darden1 /&gt; By 1976 KFC was one of the largest advertisers in the US.&lt;ref name=&quot;Georgescu2005&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Georgescu|first=Peter|title=The Source of Success: Five Enduring Principles at the Heart of Real Leadership|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F2rJlkLq-twC&amp;pg=PA75|accessdate=September 27, 2013|date=July 2005|publisher=[[John Wiley &amp; Sons]]|isbn=978-0-7879-8133-4|page=75}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Controversies and criticism==
{{See also|Kentucky Fried Cruelty}}
Since the turn of the 21st century, fast food has been criticized for its [[animal welfare]] record, its links to [[obesity]] and its environmental impact.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Barnett|first=Michael|title=Colonel Sanders' new modern army of outlets|url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/colonel-sanders-new-modern-army-of-outlets/3021690.article|accessdate=February 11, 2013|newspaper=[[Marketing Week]]|date=December 16, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Eric Schlosser]]'s book ''[[Fast Food Nation]]'' (2002) and [[Morgan Spurlock]]'s film ''[[Super Size Me]]'' (2004) reflected these concerns.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated26&quot; /&gt; Since 2003, [[PETA|People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA)]] has protested KFC's choice of poultry suppliers worldwide.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book |author1=Yaziji, Michael |author2=Doh, Jonathan |title=NGOs and Corporations: Conflict and Collaboration |series=Business, Value Creation, and Society |chapter=Case illustration: PETA and KFC |pages=112â€“114 |year=2009 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-86684-2}}&lt;/ref&gt; The exception is KFC Canada, which signed an agreement pledging to only use &quot;animal friendly&quot; suppliers.&lt;ref name=&quot;WilliamsChampion2011&quot;&gt;{{cite book|author1=Chuck Williams|author2=Terry Champion|author3=Ike Hall|title=MGMT|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8GkHKO0T4P8C&amp;pg=PA78|year=2011|publisher=[[Cengage Learning]]|isbn=978-0-17-650235-5|page=78}}&lt;/ref&gt; PETA have held thousands of demonstrations, sometimes in the home towns of KFC executives, and CEO David Novak was notably soaked in fake blood by a protester.&lt;ref name=&quot;WilliamsChampion2011&quot; /&gt; President of KFC's US division Gregg Dedrick said PETA mischaracterized KFC as a poultry producer rather than a purchaser of chickens.&lt;ref name=&quot;Swann2010&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Swann|first=Patricia|title=Cases in Public Relations Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQCogK0r4g4C&amp;pg=PA121|accessdate=September 26, 2013|date=April 2010|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=978-0-203-85136-4|pages=121â€“122}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2008, Yum! stated: &quot;[As] a major purchaser of food products, [Yum!] has the opportunity and responsibility to influence the way animals supplied to us are treated. We take that responsibility very seriously, and we are monitoring our suppliers on an ongoing basis.&quot;&lt;ref name=an08&gt;{{cite book|title=Annual Report|year=2008|publisher=Yum! Brands|location=Louisville|page=52|url=http://yum.com/investors/annualreport/08annualreport/docs/annualReport08.pdf|accessdate=September 27, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2006, [[Greenpeace]] accused KFC Europe of sourcing the [[soya bean]] for its chicken feed from [[Criticisms of Cargill#Controversy around SantarÃ©m port and Amazon deforestation|Cargill]], which had been accused of clearing large swathes of the [[Amazon rainforest]] in order to grow the crop.&lt;ref name=cargill&gt;{{cite news|author1=Felicity Lawrence|author2=John Vidal|title=Food giants to boycott illegal Amazon soya|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/jul/24/brazil.foodanddrink|accessdate=November 12, 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=July 24, 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2010, the Australian arm of KFC was accused of [[Racism|racial insensitivity]] over a television commercial showing an outnumbered white [[cricket]] fan handing out pieces of fried chicken to appease a dancing, drumming and singing group of black [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] supporters. The clip found its way around the world on the internet, prompting stinging criticism in the United States where fried chicken remains closely associated with long-standing racist stereotypes about black people in the once segregated south.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jan/06/kfc-advertisement-accused-of-racism KFC accused of racism over Australian cricket advertisement.] theguardian.com. Retrieved on December 4, 2015&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Boycott KFC.jpg|thumb|left|Protesters demonstrating outside a KFC restaurant in [[Royal Oak, Michigan]]]]
In May 2012, Greenpeace accused KFC of sourcing [[pulp (paper)|paper pulp]] for its food packaging from [[Deforestation in Indonesia|Indonesian]] rainforest wood.&lt;ref name=rainforest&gt;{{cite news|author1=Jim Efstathiou Jr.|author2=Leslie Patton|title=KFC Using Rain-Forest Wood in Boxes, Greenpeace Says|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-05-23/kfc-chicken-buckets-made-with-rain-forest-wood-greenpeace-finds.html|accessdate=November 12, 2013|newspaper=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=June 13, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; Independent forensic tests showed that some packaging contained more than 50 percent mixed tropical hardwood fiber, sourced from [[Asia Pulp &amp; Paper]] (APP).&lt;ref name=autogenerated13&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-05-23/kfc-chicken-buckets-made-with-rain-forest-wood-greenpeace-finds |title=KFC Using Rain-Forest Wood in Boxes, Greenpeace Says |publisher=''[[Businessweek]]'' |date=June 13, 2012 |accessdate=October 27, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;AutoFE-25&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.supplymanagement.com/news/2012/kfc-denies-greenpeace-sourcing-allegations/ |author=Badasha, Kamalpreet|title=KFC denies Greenpeace sourcing allegations|publisher=''[[Supply Management (magazine)|Supply Management]]'' |date=May 24, 2012 |accessdate=October 27, 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; APP said such fiber can be found in recycled paper, or: &quot;It can also come from tree residues that are cleared, after a forest area has become degraded, logged-over or burned, as part of a sustainable development plan. APP has strict policies and practices in place to ensure that only residues from legal plantation development on degraded or logged-over forest areas and sustainable wood fiber enters the production supply chain.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated13&quot; /&gt; KFC said: &quot;From a global perspective, 60 percent of the paper products that Yum! (our parent company) sources are from sustainable sources. Our suppliers are working towards making it 100 percent.&quot;&lt;ref name=rainforest /&gt;

In December 2012, the chain was criticised in China when it was discovered that a number of KFC suppliers had been using [[growth hormone]]s and an excessive amount of [[antibiotics]] on its poultry in ways that violated Chinese law.&lt;ref name=autogenerated36&gt;{{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Tiffany|title=After KFC chicken scare, Yum plans to 'stay the course in China'|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-kfc-chicken-china-yum-20130205,0,5847697.story|accessdate=February 5, 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 5, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In February 2013, Yum! CEO David Novak admitted that the scandal had been &quot;longer lasting and more impactful than we ever imagined.&quot;&lt;ref name=autogenerated36 /&gt; The issue is of major concern to Yum!, which earns almost half of its profits from China, largely through the KFC brand. In March 2013, Yum! reported that sales had rebounded in February, but that lower sales in December and January would result in a decline in same-store sales of 20 percent in the first quarter.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Cai|first=Debbie|title=Yum's China Sales Fall 20% as It Tries to Win Back KFC Customers|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887324281004578354771518385886.html|accessdate=March 12, 2013|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=March 11, 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;
