===Foreign relations===
{{Main article|Foreign relations of Germany}}
[[File:33rdG8Leaders.jpg|thumb|Germany hosted the [[33rd G8 summit|G8 summit]] in [[Heiligendamm]], 6â€“8 June 2007]]
Germany has a network of 227 diplomatic missions abroad&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/EN/AAmt/Auslandsvertretungen/Uebersicht_node.html|title=The German Missions Abroad|publisher=German Federal Foreign Office|accessdate=7 May 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; and maintains relations with more than 190 countries.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/EN/AAmt/Auslandsvertretungen/Botschaften_node.html|title=The Embassies|publisher=German Federal Foreign Office|accessdate=18 July 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; {{As of|2011}} it is the largest contributor to the budget of the [[European Union]] (providing 20%)&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | url=http://ec.europa.eu/budget/figures/2011/2011_en.cfm | title=The EU budget 2011 in figures|publisher=[[European Commission]]|accessdate=6 May 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and the third largest contributor to the UN (providing 8%).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | url=http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=ST/ADM/SER.B/824 | title=United Nations regular budget for the year 2011|publisher=UN Committee on Contributions|accessdate=6 May 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Germany is a member of [[NATO]], the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]], the [[G8]], the [[G20]], the [[World Bank]] and the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]]. It has played an influential role in the European Union since its inception and has maintained a [[Franco-German cooperation|strong alliance with France]] and all neighboring countries since 1990. Germany promotes the creation of a more unified European political, economic and security apparatus.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ambafrance-uk.org/Declaration-by-the-Franco-German,4519.html|title=Declaration by the Franco-German Defence and Security Council|publisher=French Embassy UK|date=13 May 2004|accessdate=19 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327015942/http://www.ambafrance-uk.org/Declaration-by-the-Franco-German,4519.html|archivedate=27 March 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/04/world/europe/04iht-poll.4.11666423.html | title = The leader of Europe? Answers an ocean apart | author = Freed, John C. | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 4 April 2008 | accessdate =28 March 2011 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

The development policy of Germany is an independent area of foreign policy. It is formulated by the Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development and carried out by the implementing organisations. The German government sees development policy as a joint responsibility of the international community.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.bmz.de/en/index.html|title=Aims of German development policy|publisher=Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development|date=10 April 2008|accessdate=26 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is the world's third biggest aid donor in 2009 after the United States and France.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/17/9/44981892.pdf |title=Net Official Development Assistance 2009 |publisher=OECD |accessdate=26 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url = http://www.bundesregierung.de/ContentArchiv/EN/Archiv17/Reden/2010/2010-09-21-merkel-mdg-gipfel.html |title =Speech by Chancellor Angela Merkel to the United Nations General Assembly |work =Die Bundesregierung |date =21 September 2010 |accessdate =18 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 1999, Chancellor [[Gerhard SchrÃ¶der]]'s government defined a new basis for German foreign policy by taking part in the NATO decisions surrounding the [[Kosovo War]] and by sending German troops into combat for the first time since 1945.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1741310,00.html |title=Germany's New Face Abroad |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=14 October 2005 |accessdate=26 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The governments of Germany and the United States are close political allies.&lt;ref name=&quot;state&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3997.htm|title=Germany|publisher=U.S. Department of State|date=10 November 2010|accessdate=26 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Cultural ties and economic interests have crafted a  bond between the two countries resulting in [[Atlanticism]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://germany.usembassy.gov/germany/img/assets/9336/econ_factsheet_may2006.pdf |title=U.S.-German Economic Relations Factsheet |publisher=U.S. Embassy in Berlin |date=May 2006 |accessdate=26 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Military===
{{Main article|Bundeswehr}}
[[File:Eurofighter 9803.ogg|thumb|thumbtime=32|The [[Eurofighter Typhoon]] is part of the [[German Air Force|Luftwaffe]] fleet]]

Germany's military, the ''Bundeswehr'', is organised into ''[[German Army|Heer]]'' (Army and special forces [[Kommando SpezialkrÃ¤fte|KSK]]), ''[[German Navy|Marine]]'' (Navy), ''[[German Air Force|Luftwaffe]]'' (Air Force), ''[[Bundeswehr Joint Medical Service]]'' and ''[[StreitkrÃ¤ftebasis]]'' (Joint Support Service) branches. In absolute terms, German military expenditure is the 9th highest in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.sipri.org/research/armaments/milex/resultoutput/milex_15/the-15-countries-with-the-highest-military-expenditure-in-2011-table/view|title=The 15 countries with the highest military expenditure in 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2012 |date=September 2011 | publisher=Stockholm International Peace Research Institute}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2015, military spending was at â‚¬32.9 billion, about 1.2% of the country's GDP, well below the NATO target of 2%.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |title=Germany to increase defence spending |work=IHS Jane's 360|url=http://www.janes.com/article/52745/germany-to-increase-defence-spending|accessdate=20 January 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;

{{As of|2015|12}} the Bundeswehr employed roughly 178,000 service members, including 9,500 volunteers.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bundeswehr.de/portal/a/bwde/!ut/p/c4/DcmxDYAwDATAWVgg7unYAugc8kSWI4OMIesTXXm002D8SeWQy7jRStshc-4p94L0hENCnXEGUvXXSuMKG8FwBd26TD9uIZiT/ |title=Die StÃ¤rke der StreitkrÃ¤fte |accessdate=2 January 2016|date=10 December 2015 |publisher=[[Bundeswehr]]|language=German}}&lt;/ref&gt; Reservists are available to the Armed Forces and participate in defence exercises and deployments abroad.&lt;ref name=&quot;bwzukunft&quot;&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bundeswehr.de/portal/a/bwde/!ut/p/c4/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP3I5EyrpHK9pPKUVL3ikqLUzJLsosTUtJJUvbzU0vTU4pLEnJLSvHRUuYKcxDygoH5BtqMiAMTJdF8!/ |title=Ausblick: Die Bundeswehr der Zukunft |accessdate=5 June 2011 |publisher=[[Bundeswehr]]|language=German}}&lt;/ref&gt; Since 2001 women may serve in all functions of service without restriction.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bundeswehr.de/portal/a/bwde/!ut/p/c4/FcwxEoUgDAXAE0l6O0_x1YZ5QMSMEp2In-urs_3STC_FXzKqHIqdRpqi9KG50BK7qxpL3Qy8VHbZbk07MqtbDDerF_WJzYdGv286DbmAJj26iLgynaUMD6qutPs!/| title= Frauen in der Bundeswehr |accessdate=14 April 2011 |publisher=[[Bundeswehr]] |language=German}}&lt;/ref&gt; About 19,000 female soldiers are on active duty. According to [[SIPRI]], Germany was the fourth largest exporter of major arms in the world in 2014.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Trends in International Arms Transfer, 2014|url=http://books.sipri.org/product_info?c_product_id=495|website=www.sipri.org|publisher=Stockholm International Peace Research Institute|accessdate=18 March 2015|ref=SIPRI Fact Sheet, March 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Fregatte Mecklenburg-Vorpommern F218.jpg|thumb|left|A [[German Navy]] [[Brandenburg class frigate]]]]

In peacetime, the Bundeswehr is commanded by the Minister of Defence. In [[State of Defence (Germany)|state of defence]], the Chancellor would become commander-in-chief of the ''Bundeswehr''.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bundesrecht/gg/gesamt.pdf |title=Grundgesetz fÃ¼r die Bundesrepublik Deutschland, Artikel 65a,87,115b |publisher=Bundesministerium der Justiz |accessdate=19 March 2011 |language=German}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The role of the ''Bundeswehr'' is described in the [[Constitution of Germany]] as defensive only. But after a ruling of the Federal Constitutional Court in 1994 the term &quot;defense&quot; has been defined to not only include protection of the borders of Germany, but also crisis reaction and conflict prevention, or more broadly as guarding the [[security]] of Germany anywhere in the world. {{As of|2015|1}}, the German military has about 2,370 troops stationed in foreign countries as part of international peacekeeping forces, including about 850 Bundeswehr troops in the NATO-led [[International Security Assistance Force|ISAF]] force in Afghanistan and [[Uzbekistan]], 670 German soldiers in [[Kosovo]], and 120 troops with [[UNIFIL]] in Lebanon.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bundeswehr.de/portal/a/bwde/einsaetze/einsatzzahlen?yw_contentURL=/C1256EF4002AED30/W264VFT2439INFODE/content.jsp |title=Einsatzzahlen&amp;nbsp;â€“ Die StÃ¤rke der deutschen Einsatzkontingente |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=[[Bundeswehr]]|language=German}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Until 2011, [[Conscription in Germany|military service]] was compulsory for men at age 18, and conscripts served six-month tours of duty; conscientious objectors could instead opt for an equal length of ''[[Zivildienst]]'' (civilian service), or a six-year commitment to (voluntary) emergency services like a [[Volunteer fire department|fire department]] or the [[German Red Cross|Red Cross]]. In 2011 conscription was officially suspended and replaced with a voluntary service.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |title= Germany to abolish compulsory military service |author= Connolly, Kate |url= http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/22/germany-abolish-compulsory-military-service |newspaper =The Guardian  |date= 22 November 2010 |accessdate =7 April 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |title = Marching orders for conscription in Germany, but what will take its place? |author =Pidd, Helen |url= http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/conscription-germany-army |newspaper =The Guardian |date =16 March 2011 |accessdate =7 April 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; 
{{Clear}}

==Economy==
{{Main article|Economy of Germany}}
[[File:2015 Mercedes-Benz S63 AMG CoupÃ©, front left (US).jpg|thumb|Germany maintains a large [[Automotive industry in Germany|automotive industry]], and is the world's third largest [[List of countries by exports|exporter]] of goods.&lt;ref name=&quot;auto1&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2078rank.html|title=Country Comparison: Exports|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=10 November 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;]]

Germany has a [[social market economy]] with a highly skilled [[labour force]], a large [[capital stock]], a low level of corruption,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://archive.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2009/cpi_2009_table |title=CPI 2009 table |publisher=Transparency International |accessdate=15 May 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; and a high level of [[innovation]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.bcg.com/documents/file15445.pdf |title=The Innovation Imperative in Manufacturing: How the United States Can Restore Its Edge |date=March 2009 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |publisher=Boston Consulting Group}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is [[List of countries by exports|the world's third largest exporter]] of goods,&lt;ref name=&quot;auto1&quot;/&gt; and has the largest national economy in Europe which is also [[List of countries by GDP (nominal)|the world's fourth largest by nominal GDP]]&lt;ref name=wbpdf&gt;{{cite web|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/DATASTATISTICS/Resources/GDP.pdf |work=The World Bank: World Development Indicators database |title=Gross domestic product (2009) |date=27 September 2010 |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=1 January 2011}}&lt;br /&gt;[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2195.html Field listing&amp;nbsp;â€“ GDP (official exchange rate)]&lt;/ref&gt; and the [[List of countries by GDP (PPP)|fifth one by PPP]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/DATASTATISTICS/Resources/GDP_PPP.pdf |work=The World Bank: World Development Indicators database |title=Gross domestic product (2009) |date=27 September 2010 |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=5 October 2010}}&lt;br /&gt;[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2001rank.html Field listing&amp;nbsp;â€“ GDP (PPP exchange rate)]&lt;/ref&gt;

The [[Tertiary sector of industry|service sector]] contributes approximately 71% of the total GDP (including [[information technology]]), industry 28%, and agriculture 1%.&lt;ref name=&quot;CIA&quot;/&gt; The unemployment rate published by [[Eurostat]] amounts to 4.7% in January 2015, which  is the lowest rate of all 28 EU member states.&lt;ref name=&quot;Eurostat&quot;&gt;[http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/6664116/3-02032015-AP-EN.pdf/28d48055-3894-492d-a952-005097600ee0 Eurostat: Euro area unemployment rate at 11.2%, Press release of 2 March 2015]&lt;/ref&gt; With 7.1% Germany also has the lowest [[youth unemployment]] rate of all EU member states.&lt;ref name=&quot;Eurostat&quot; /&gt; According to the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] Germany has one of the highest [[Workforce productivity|labour productivity]] levels in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Labour productivity levels in the total economy|url=http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LEVEL|publisher=OECD|accessdate=12 December 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Frankfurt Skyline (16259801511).jpg|thumb|left|[[Frankfurt]] is a leading financial center in Europe and seat of the [[European Central Bank|ECB]].]]

Germany is part of the [[Internal market|European single market]] which represents more than 508 million consumers. Several domestic commercial policies are determined by agreements among European Union (EU) members and by EU legislation. Germany introduced the common European currency, the [[Euro]] in 2002.&lt;ref name=euroc&gt;{{Cite news |title =Germans Say Goodbye to the Mark, a Symbol of Strength and Unity |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate =18 March 2011 |url = http://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/01/world/germans-say-goodbye-to-the-mark-a-symbol-of-strength-and-unity.html |first=Edmund L. |last =Andrews |date=1 January 2002}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |title=On Jan.&amp;nbsp;1, out of many arises one Euro |newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |first= Susan |last =Taylor Martin |date=28 December 1998 |page=National, 1.A }}&lt;/ref&gt; It is a member of the Eurozone which represents around 338 million citizens. Its monetary policy is set by the [[European Central Bank]], which is headquartered in [[Frankfurt]], the financial centre of continental Europe.

Being home to the [[History of the automobile#19th century|modern car]], the [[automotive industry in Germany]] is regarded as one of the most competitive and innovative in the world,&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.gtai.de/GTAI/Navigation/EN/Invest/Industries/Mobility/automotive.html Germany â€“ The World's Automotive Hub of Innovation], Germany Trade &amp; Invest, Ernst &amp; Young European Automotive Survey 2013, retrieved 25 April 2015&lt;/ref&gt; and is [[List of countries by motor vehicle production|the fourth largest by production]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://oica.net/category/production-statistics/|title=Production Statistics - OICA|work=oica.net}}&lt;/ref&gt; The top 10 exports of Germany are vehicles, machinery, chemical goods, electronic products, electrical equipments, pharmaceuticals, transport equipments, basic metals, food products, and rubber and plastics.&lt;ref name=&quot;Destatis&quot;&gt;{{cite web| url = http://www.destatis.de/EN/FactsFigures/NationalEconomyEnvironment/ForeignTrade/_Graphic/TradingGoods.png?__blob=poster| title = CIA Factbook | accessdate =23 April 2015 | authorlink =Statistiches Bundesamt}}&lt;/ref&gt;
{{Clear}}

===Companies===

Of the world's 500 largest stock-market-listed companies measured by revenue in 2014, the [[Fortune Global 500]], 28 are headquartered in Germany. 30 Germany-based companies are included in the [[DAX]], the German stock market index. Well-known international brands include [[Mercedes-Benz]], [[BMW]], [[SAP AG|SAP]], [[Volkswagen]], [[Audi]], [[Siemens]], [[Allianz]], [[Adidas]], [[Porsche]], and [[DHL Express|DHL]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web| url=http://bestglobalbrands.com/2014/ranking/ |title=Best Global Brands - 2014 Rankings |publisher=Interbrand |accessdate=26 March 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315012352/http://bestglobalbrands.com/2014/ranking/|archivedate=15 March 2015|deadurl=no}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Germany is recognised for its large portion of specialised [[small and medium enterprises]], known as the ''[[Mittelstand]]'' model. Around 1,000 of these companies are global market leaders in their segment and are labelled [[Hidden Champions|hidden champions]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |author=Gavin, Mike |date=23 September 2010 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-09-23/germany-has-1-000-market-leading-companies-manager-magazin-says.html |title=Germany Has 1,000 Market-Leading Companies, Manager-Magazin Says |newspaper=Businessweek  |accessdate=27 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430195209/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-09-23/germany-has-1-000-market-leading-companies-manager-magazin-says.html |archivedate=30 April 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Berlin developed a thriving, cosmopolitan [[Startup ecosystem|hub]] for [[Startup company|startup companies]] and became a leading location for venture capital funded firms in the European Union.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|last1=Frost|first1=Simon|title=Berlin outranks London in start-up investment|url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/innovation-industry/berlin-outranks-london-start-investment-317140|website=euractiv.com|accessdate=28 October 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The list includes the largest German companies by revenue in 2014:&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url=http://fortune.com/global500/ |title=Global 500&amp;nbsp;â€“ Fortune |work=Fortune|accessdate=3 July 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:BlueEurozone.svg|thumb|Germany is part of a monetary union, the [[eurozone]] (dark blue), and of the [[Internal Market (European Union)|EU single market]].]]
