[[Expressionist architecture]] developed in the 1910s in Germany and influenced [[Art Deco]] and other modern styles, with e.g. [[Johann Friedrich HÃ¶ger|Fritz HÃ¶ger]], [[Erich Mendelsohn]], [[Dominikus BÃ¶hm]] and [[Fritz Schumacher (architect)|Fritz Schumacher]] being influential architects. Germany was particularly important in the early [[modern architecture|modernist movement]]: it is the home of [[Deutscher Werkbund|Werkbund]] initiated by [[Hermann Muthesius]] ([[New Objectivity (architecture)|New Objectivity]]), and of the [[Bauhaus]] movement founded by [[Walter Gropius]]. Consequently, Germany is often considered the cradle of modern architecture and design. [[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe]] became one of the world's most renowned architects in the second half of the 20th century. He conceived of the glass faÃ§ade [[skyscraper]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|year=2006|title=A Dictionary of Architecture and Landscape Architecture|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=880|isbn=0-19-860678-8}}&lt;/ref&gt; Renowned contemporary [[List of German architects|architects]] and offices include [[Hans Kollhoff]], [[Sergei Enwerowitsch Tschoban|Sergei Tchoban]], [[Christoph Kohl (architect)|KK Architekten]], [[Helmut Jahn]], [[Behnisch Architekten|Behnisch]], [[Gerkan, Marg and Partners|GMP]], [[Ole Scheeren]], [[JÃ¼rgen Mayer (architect)|J. Mayer H.]], [[Oswald Mathias Ungers|OM Ungers]], [[Gottfried BÃ¶hm]] and [[Frei Otto]] (the last two being [[Pritzker Prize]] winners).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|last1=Jodidio|first1=Philip|title=100 Contemporary Architects|date=21 January 2008|publisher=Taschen|isbn=3836500914|edition=1}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Literature and philosophy===
{{Main article|German literature|German philosophy}}
[[File:Grimm.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The [[Brothers Grimm]] collected and published popular German [[Grimms' Fairy Tales|folk tales]].]]

German literature can be traced back to the Middle Ages and the works of writers such as [[Walther von der Vogelweide]] and [[Wolfram von Eschenbach]]. Well-known German authors include [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]], [[Friedrich Schiller]], [[Gotthold Ephraim Lessing]] and [[Theodor Fontane]]. The collections of folk tales published by the [[Brothers Grimm]] popularised [[German folklore]] on an international level.&lt;ref name=&quot;D99ff&quot;&gt;DÃ©gh, Linda (1979). &quot;Grimm's Household Tales and its Place in the Household&quot;. Western Folklore 38 (2): 85â€“103, pp. 99â€“101. {{subscription}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Grimms also gathered and codified regional variants of the German language, grounding their work in historical principles; their ''[[Deutsches WÃ¶rterbuch]]'', or German Dictionary, sometimes called the Grimm dictionary, was begun in 1838 and the first volumes published in 1854.&lt;ref name = DWBhistory&gt;History of the ''Deutsches WÃ¶rterbuch'' from the [http://150-grimm.bbaw.de/start.htm DWB 150th Anniversary Exhibition and Symposium], Berlin: Humboldt-UniversitÃ¤t, 2004. {{De icon}}, retrieved 27 June 2012.&lt;/ref&gt;

Influential authors of the 20th century include [[Gerhart Hauptmann]], [[Thomas Mann]], [[Hermann Hesse]], [[Heinrich BÃ¶ll]] and [[GÃ¼nter Grass]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/articles/espmark/index.html |title=The Nobel Prize in Literature |publisher=Nobelprize.org |date=3 December 1999 |author=[[Kjell Espmark|Espmark, Kjell]] |accessdate=28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The German book market is the third largest in the world, after the United States and China.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalpublishers.org/images/reports/2014/IPA-annual-report-2014.pdf|title=Annual Report|date=October 2014|publisher=International Publishers Association|accessdate=6 July 2016|page=13}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[Frankfurt Book Fair]] is the most important in the world for international deals and trading, with a tradition spanning over 500 years,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book |title =A History of the Frankfurt Book Fair |isbn=978-1-55002-744-0 |first =Peter |last =Weidhaas |first2 =Carolyn |last2 =Gossage |first3 =Wendy A. |last3 =Wright |publisher =Dundurn Press Ltd. | pages = 11 ff|year = 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; also the [[Leipzig Book Fair]] retains a major position in Europe.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|last1=Chase|first1=Jefferson|title=Leipzig Book Fair: Cultural sideshow with a serious side|url=http://www.dw.de/leipzig-book-fair-cultural-sideshow-with-a-serious-side/a-18313879|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=13 March 2015|accessdate=25 April 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

German philosophy is historically significant: [[Gottfried Leibniz]]'s contributions to [[rationalism]]; the [[Age of Enlightenment|enlightenment]] philosophy by [[Immanuel Kant]]; the establishment of classical [[German idealism]] by [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte]], [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]] and [[Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling]]; [[Arthur Schopenhauer]]'s composition of metaphysical pessimism; the formulation of [[communist theory]] by [[Karl Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels]]; [[Friedrich Nietzsche]]'s development of [[perspectivism]]; [[Gottlob Frege]]'s contributions to the dawn of [[analytic philosophy]]; [[Martin Heidegger]]'s works on Being; the development of the [[Frankfurt school]] by [[Max Horkheimer]], [[Theodor Adorno]], [[Herbert Marcuse]] and [[JÃ¼rgen Habermas]] have been particularly influential; and [[Oswald Spengler]]'s historical philosophy, including his book ''[[The Decline of the West]]'', in which he predicts the fall of the western European civilization and describes the [[Germanic culture (disambiguation)|Germanic culture]] as [[Faust]]ian.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|author=Searle, John|year=1987|title=The Blackwell Companion to Philosophy|chapter=Introduction|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Media===
{{Main article|Television in Germany|Video gaming in Germany}}
[[File:Deutsche Welle.jpg|thumb|[[Deutsche Welle]] headquarters in [[Bonn]] (center).]]

The largest internationally operating [[Mass media|media]] companies in Germany are the [[Bertelsmann]] enterprise, [[Axel Springer AG|Axel Springer SE]] and [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media]]. The [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|German Press Agency DPA]] is also significant. [[Television in Germany|Germany's television market]] is the largest in Europe, with some 38&amp;nbsp;million TV households.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Distribution of TV in Germany (German)|url=http://www.astra.de/16795168/tv-verbreitung_in_deutschland|publisher=Astra Sat|date=19 February 2013|accessdate=10 December 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; Around 90% of German households have cable or satellite TV, with a variety of [[Public broadcasting#Germany|free-to-view public]] and [[Commercial broadcasting|commercial]] channels.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1047864.stm |title=Country profile: Germany |work=BBC News |accessdate=28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are more than 500 public and private [[List of radio stations in Germany|radio stations in Germany]], with the public [[Deutsche Welle]] being the main German radio and television broadcaster in foreign languages.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/1950-1954/a-326253-1 |title=Organization 1950-1954|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=15 May 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; Germany's national radio network is the [[Deutschlandradio]] while [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] stations are covering local services.

Many of Europe's best-selling [[List of newspapers in Germany|newspapers]] and [[List of magazines in Germany|magazines]] are produced in Germany. The papers (and internet portals) with the highest circulation are ''[[Bild]]'' (a [[Tabloid journalism|tabloid]]), ''[[Die Zeit]]'', ''[[SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung]]'', ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]'' and ''[[Die Welt]]'', the largest magazines include ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', ''[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]'' and ''[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]]''.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://dispatch.opac.d-nb.de/LNG=DU/DB=1.1/|title=ZDB OPAC - start/text|work=d-nb.de|accessdate=1 April 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The [[Video gaming in Germany|German video gaming market]] is one of the largest in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|last=Purchese |first=Robert |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/germany-becomes-europes-top-market |title=Germany's video game market |publisher=Eurogamer.net |date=17 August 2009 |accessdate=4 March 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[Gamescom]] in Cologne is the world's leading gaming convention.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.gamescom-cologne.com/en/gamescom/presse/presseinformationen/gc_pressinformationen.php?aktion=pfach&amp;p1id=kmpresse_gamescom_e&amp;format=html&amp;base=&amp;tp=k3content&amp;search=&amp;pmid=kmeigen.kmpresse_1408435283&amp;start=0&amp;anzahl=10&amp;channel=kmeigen&amp;language=e&amp;archiv=|title=Press releases|publisher=gamescom Press Center|date=2014|accessdate=26 March 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210125817/http://www.gamescom-cologne.com/en/gamescom/presse/presseinformationen/gc_pressinformationen.php?aktion=pfach&amp;p1id=kmpresse_gamescom_e&amp;format=html&amp;base=&amp;tp=k3content&amp;search=&amp;pmid=kmeigen.kmpresse_1408435283&amp;start=0&amp;anzahl=10&amp;channel=kmeigen&amp;language=e&amp;archiv=|archivedate=10 February 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; Popular game series from Germany include ''[[Turrican]]'', the [[Anno (series)|''Anno'' series]], [[The Settlers|''The Settlers'' series]], the [[Gothic series|''Gothic'' series]], ''[[SpellForce]]'', the [[FIFA Manager (video game series)|''FIFA Manager'' series]], ''[[Far Cry]]'' and ''[[Crysis]]''. Relevant game developers and publishers are [[Ubisoft Blue Byte|Blue Byte]], [[Crytek]], [[Deep Silver]], [[Kalypso Media]], [[Piranha Bytes]], [[Yager Development]], and some of the largest [[social network game]] companies like [[Bigpoint Games|Bigpoint]], [[Gameforge]], [[Goodgame Studios|Goodgame]] and [[Wooga]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Made in Germany: The most important games from Germany (German)|url=http://www.pcgameshardware.de/Spiele-Thema-239104/Specials/Deutsche-Wertarbeit-681808/|publisher=[[PC Games (magazine)|PC Games]] Hardware|date=27 November 2011|accessdate=9 December 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Cinema===
{{Main article|Cinema of Germany}}

[[Cinema of Germany|German cinema]] has made major technical and artistic contributions to film. The first works of the [[Max Skladanowsky|Skladanowsky Brothers]] were shown to an audience in 1895. The renowned [[Babelsberg Studio]] in Berlin's suburb [[Potsdam]] was established in 1912, thus being the first large-scale film studio in the world. Today it is Europe's largest studio.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.studiobabelsberg.com/service/filmstudios-ateliers/neue-film-1/ Studio Babelsberg] â€“ ''Mit der ErschlieÃŸung des direkt in der Nachbarschaft befindlichen FilmgelÃ¤ndes mit den Studios Neue Film 1 und Neue Film 2 konnte Studio Babelsberg seine StudiokapazitÃ¤ten verdoppeln und verfÃ¼gt so Ã¼ber Europas grÃ¶ÃŸten zusammenhÃ¤ngenden Studiokomplex.'', retrieved 3 December 2013 (German)&lt;/ref&gt; Early German cinema was particularly influential with [[German expressionism|German expressionists]] such as [[Robert Wiene]] and [[Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau]]. Director [[Fritz Lang]]'s ''[[Metropolis (1927 film)|Metropolis]]'' (1927) is referred to as the first major science-fiction film.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.scififilmhistory.com/index.php?pageID=metro|title=SciFi Film History â€“ Metropolis (1927)|publisher=|accessdate=28 September 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1930 [[Josef von Sternberg]] directed ''[[The Blue Angel]]'', the first major German [[sound film]], with [[Marlene Dietrich]].&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite book |last= Bordwell |first= David |authorlink= David Bordwell |author2=Thompson, Kristin |title= Film History: An Introduction |origyear= 1994 |edition= 2nd |year= 2003 |publisher=McGraw-Hill |isbn= 978-0-07-115141-2 |page= 204 |chapter= The Introduction of Sound}}&lt;/ref&gt; Films of [[Leni Riefenstahl]] set new artistic standards, in particular [[Triumph of the Will]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|last1=Rother|first1=Rainer|title=Leni Riefenstahl: The Seduction of Genius|date=1 July 2003|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=1441159010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Filmstudio Babelsberg Eingang.jpg|thumb|[[Babelsberg Studio]] near Berlin, the world's first large-scale film studio]]

After 1945, many of the films of the immediate post-war period can be characterised as  ''[[TrÃ¼mmerfilm]]''. Such films included [[Wolfgang Staudte]]'s ''[[Die MÃ¶rder sind unter uns]] (The Murderers are among us)'' (1946). Notable East German films included ''[[Der Untertan (film)|Der Untertan]]'' (1951); [[Konrad Wolf]]'s ''[[Divided Heaven (film)|Der geteilte Himmel]] (Divided Heaven)'' (1964) and [[Frank Beyer]]'s ''[[Jacob the Liar (1975 film)|Jacob the Liar]]'' (1975). The defining film genre in West Germany of the 1950s was arguably the ''[[Heimatfilm]]'' (&quot;homeland film&quot;); these  films depicted the beauty of the land and the moral integrity of the people living in it.&lt;ref&gt;Stephen Brockmann, ''A Critical History of German Film,'' Camden House, 2010, p. 286. ISBN 1571134689&lt;/ref&gt;

During the 1970s and 1980s, [[New German Cinema]] directors such as [[Volker SchlÃ¶ndorff]], [[Werner Herzog]], [[Wim Wenders]], and [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]] brought West German auteur cinema to critical acclaim. German movies such as ''[[Das Boot]]'' (1981), ''[[The NeverEnding Story (film)|The Never Ending Story]]'' (1984), ''[[Good Bye, Lenin!]]'' (2003), ''[[Head-On (film)|Head On]]'' (2004), ''[[The White Ribbon]]'' (2009), ''[[Animals United]]'' (2010), and ''[[Cloud Atlas (film)|Cloud Atlas]]'' (2012) also had international success. The [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] (&quot;Oscar&quot;) went to the German production ''[[The Tin Drum (film)|Die Blechtrommel (The Tin Drum)]]'' in 1979, to ''[[Nowhere in Africa|Nirgendwo in Afrika (Nowhere in Africa)]]'' in 2002, and to ''[[The Lives of Others|Das Leben der Anderen (The Lives of Others)]]'' in 2007.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405094/awards|title=Awards:Das Leben der Anderen|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The annual [[European Film Award]]s ceremony is held every other year in Berlin, home of the [[European Film Academy]]. The [[Berlin International Film Festival]], known as &quot;Berlinale&quot;, awarding the &quot;[[Golden Bear]]&quot; and held annually since 1951, is one of the world's leading [[film festival]]s.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.fiapf.org/pdf/2006accreditedFestivalsDirectory.pdf |title=2006 FIAPF accredited Festivals Directory|publisher=International Federation of Film Producers Associations|accessdate=28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The &quot;Lolas&quot; are annually awarded in Berlin, at the [[Deutscher Filmpreis|German Film Awards]], that have been presented since 1951.&lt;ref&gt;Die Beauftragte der BUndesregierung fuer Kultur und Medien, [http://www.deutscher-filmpreis.de/ ''Deutscher-flimpreis.''] Accessed 21 May 2015.&lt;/ref&gt;

===Cuisine===
{{Main article|German cuisine}}
[[File:Black Forest gateau.jpg|thumb|[[Black Forest cake|Black Forest GÃ¢teau]], a [[List of German desserts|German dessert]]]]

German cuisine varies from region to region and often neighboring regions share some culinary similarities (e.g. the southern regions of [[Bavarian cuisine|Bavaria]] and [[Swabian cuisine|Swabia]] share some traditions with Switzerland and Austria). International varieties such as [[pizza]], [[sushi]], [[Chinese food]], [[Greek cuisine|Greek food]], [[Indian cuisine]] and [[doner kebab]] are also popular and available, thanks to diverse ethnic communities.

[[Bread in Europe#Germany|Bread]] is a significant part of German cuisine and German bakeries produce about 600 main types of bread and 1,200 different types of pastries and rolls (''BrÃ¶tchen''). German [[List of German cheeses|cheeses]] account for about a third of all cheese produced in Europe.&lt;ref name=IG&gt;[https://books.google.com/books?id=sjW9adVFS2kC&amp;pg=PA113 The Complete Idiot's Guide to Cheeses of the World - Steve Ehlers, Jeanette Hurt&lt;!-- Bot generated title --&gt;]. pp. 113-115.&lt;/ref&gt; In 2012 over 99% of all meat produced in Germany was either pork, chicken or beef. Germans produce their ubiquitous sausages in almost 1,500 varieties, including [[Bratwurst]]s, [[Weisswurst]]s, and [[Currywurst]]s.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | url = http://germanfoods.org/german-food-facts/german-hams-sausages-meats-guide/ | title = Guide to German Hams and Sausages | publisher = German Foods North America | accessdate =26 March 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2012, [[organic food]]s accounted for 3.9% of total food sales.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | url = https://www.foodwatch.org/de/informieren/bio-lebensmittel/mehr-zum-thema/zahlen-daten-fakten/ | title =Numbers, data, facts about the organic food sector|language=German| publisher= Foodwatch | accessdate =4 June 2015|quote=Bio-Produkte machen lediglich 3,9 Prozent des gesamten Lebensmittelumsatzes in Deutschland aus (2012).}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Although [[German wine|wine]] is becoming more popular in many parts of Germany, especially in [[List of German wine regions|German wine regions]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=German Wine Statistics|url=http://www.germanwineusa.com/press-trade/statistics.html|publisher=Wines of Germany, Deutsches Weininstitut|accessdate=14 December 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; the national alcoholic drink is [[Beer in Germany|beer]]. German beer consumption per person stands at {{convert|110|litres|0}} in 2013 and remains among the [[List of countries by beer consumption per capita|highest in the world]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news | url = http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/top-10-heaviest-beer-drinking-countries-czech-republic-germany-sink-most-pints-1475764 | title = Top 10 Heaviest Beer-drinking Countries: Czech Republic and Germany Sink Most Pints | accessdate =6 May 2015 | author = Samantha Payne | date = 20 November 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Reinheitsgebot|German beer purity regulations]] date back to the 15th century.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,549175,00.html/ spiegel.de/international/germany]&lt;/ref&gt;

The 2015 [[Michelin Guide]] awarded eleven restaurants in Germany [[List of Michelin starred restaurants#Germany|three stars]], the highest designation, while 38 more received two stars and 233 one star.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.viamichelin.com/web/Restaurants/Restaurants-Germany|title=Michelin Guide restaurants for Germany|publisher=|accessdate=26 January 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; German restaurants have become the world's second-most decorated after France.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news | url = http://in.reuters.com/article/2007/11/14/us-germany-food-idINL1447732320071114 | title = German cuisine beats Italy, Spain in gourmet stars | publisher = Reuters  | accessdate =19 March 2011 | date = 28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news | url = http://www.dw.de/dw/article/0,,2914502_page_0,00.html | title = Schnitzel Outcooks Spaghetti in Michelin Guide | work = Deutsche Welle | accessdate =6 April 2012 | date = 15 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Sports===
{{Main article|Sport in Germany}}
[[File:Germany champions 2014 FIFA World Cup.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Germany national football team|German national football team]] after winning the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] for the fourth time in 2014. [[Football in Germany|Football]] is the most popular sport in Germany.]]

Twenty-seven million Germans are members of a sports club and an additional twelve million pursue sports individually.&lt;ref name=&quot;sports&quot;&gt;{{cite web | url = http://www.germany.info/relaunch/culture/life/sports.html | title = Germany Info: Culture &amp; Life: Sports | publisher=Germany Embassy in Washington, D.C | accessdate = 28 March 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Football in Germany|Association football]] is the most popular sport. With more than 6.3&amp;nbsp;million official members, the [[German Football Association]] (''Deutscher FuÃŸball-Bund'') is the largest sports organisation of its kind worldwide, and the German top league, the [[Bundesliga]], attracts the second highest [[List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues|average attendance]] of all professional sports leagues in the world.&lt;ref name=&quot;sports&quot;/&gt; The [[Germany national football team|German men's national football team]] won the [[FIFA World Cup]] in 1954, 1974, 1990, and 2014, and the [[UEFA European Championship]] in 1972, 1980 and 1996. Germany hosted the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup in 1974]] and [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]] and the UEFA European Championship in [[UEFA Euro 1988|1988]].

Other popular spectator sports include [[Sport in Germany#Wintersports|winter sports]], [[Sport in Germany#Boxing|boxing]], [[Basketball Bundesliga|basketball]], [[Handball-Bundesliga|handball]], [[Germany men's national volleyball team|volleyball]], [[Ice hockey in Germany|ice hockey]], [[German Open Tennis Championships|tennis]], [[Equestrianism|horse riding]] and [[Sport in Germany#Golf|golf]]. [[Water sports]] like [[sailing]], [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]], and [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] are popular in Germany as well.&lt;ref name=&quot;sports&quot;/&gt;

Germany is one of the leading [[Sport in Germany#Motorsport|motor sports]] countries in the world. Constructors like [[BMW]] and [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]] are prominent manufacturers in motor sport. [[Porsche]] has won the [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] race 17 times, and [[Audi]] 13 times ({{As of|2015|lc=y}}). The driver [[Michael Schumacher]] has set many motor sport records during his career, having won more [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|Formula One World Drivers' Championships]] with seven titles, than any other. He is one of the highest paid sportsmen in history.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news | url = http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2006/oct/23/formulaone.sport | title = What we will miss about Michael Schumacher | newspaper=The Guardian | date = 23 October 2006 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | first=David | last=Ornstein }}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Sebastian Vettel]] is also among the top three most successful Formula One drivers of all time.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/vettel-makes-formula-one-history-with-eighth-successive-victory-29761655.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Vettel makes Formula One history with eighth successive victory | date=17 November 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Historically, [[Germany at the Olympics|German athletes]] have been successful contenders in the [[Olympic Games]], ranking third in an [[all-time Olympic Games medal count]] (when combining East and West German medals). Germany was the last country to host both the summer and winter games in the same year, in 1936 the Berlin [[1936 Summer Olympics|Summer Games]] and the [[1936 Winter Olympics|Winter Games]] in [[Garmisch-Partenkirchen]],&lt;ref&gt;Large, David Clay, ''Nazi Games: The Olympics of 1936.'' W. W. Norton &amp; Company, 2007, ISBN 9780393058840 p. 136.&lt;/ref&gt; and in [[Munich]] it hosted the Summer Games of [[1972 Summer Olympics|1972]].&lt;ref&gt;Large, p. 337.&lt;/ref&gt;

===Fashion and design===
{{Main article|German fashion}}
[[File:Claudia Schiffer 20091006 Chanel 01.jpg|thumb|[[Claudia Schiffer]], German [[supermodel]]]]
German designers were leaders of modern [[product design]], with the [[Bauhaus]] designers like [[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe|Mies van der Rohe]], and [[Dieter Rams]] of [[Braun (company)|Braun]] being essential.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bauhaus: The Single Most Influential School of Design|url=http://gizmodo.com/5918142/8-beautiful-things-from-bauhaus-the-single-most-influential-school-of-design|publisher=gizmodo|date=13 June 2012|accessdate=9 December 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Germany is a leading country in the [[fashion industry]]. The German textile industry consisted of about 1,300 companies with more than 130,000 employees in 2010, which generated a revenue of 28 billion Euro. Almost 44 percent of the products are exported.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.bmwi.de/BMWi/Navigation/Wirtschaft/branchenfokus,did=196528.html?view=renderPrint&amp;page=0|title=BMWI Branchenfokus Textil und Bekleidung|publisher=|accessdate=28 September 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[Berlin Fashion Week]] and the fashion trade fair [[Bread and Butter tradeshow|Bread &amp; Butter]] are held twice a year.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Berlin as a fashion capital: the improbable rise|url=http://www.fashionunited.co.uk/fashion-news/fashion/germanys-fashion-capital-the-improbable-rise-of-berlin-2012011713844|publisher=Fashion United UK|date=12 January 2012|accessdate=15 May 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Munich, Hamburg and DÃ¼sseldorf are also important design, production and trade hubs of the domestic fashion industry, among smaller towns.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.brigitte.de/mode/trends/deutsche-mode-reportage-1134129/|title=''Die deutsche Mode kommt aus der Provinz''|work=BRIGITTE|accessdate=28 September 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt; Renowned fashion designers from Germany include [[Karl Lagerfeld]], [[Jil Sander]], [[Wolfgang Joop]], [[Philipp Plein]] and [[Michael Michalsky]]. Important brands include [[Hugo Boss]], [[Escada]], [[Adidas]], [[Puma SE|Puma]] and [[Triumph International|Triumph]]. The German [[supermodel]]s [[Claudia Schiffer]], [[Heidi Klum]], [[Tatjana Patitz]] and [[Nadja Auermann]] have come to international fame.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=German Cultures Today: Fashion Stars - One Germany in Europe|url=http://www.germanhistorydocs.ghi-dc.org/sub_image.cfm?image_id=3211&amp;language=english|publisher=German History Docs GHDI|accessdate=26 April 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;
