===Overseas territories and collectivities===
In addition to the 18 regions and 101 departments, the French Republic has five [[overseas collectivity|overseas collectivities]] ([[French Polynesia]], [[Saint BarthÃ©lemy]], [[Collectivity of Saint Martin|Saint Martin]], [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]], and [[Wallis and Futuna]]), one ''[[sui generis]]'' collectivity ([[New Caledonia]]), one [[overseas territory (France)|overseas territory]] ([[French Southern and Antarctic Lands]]), and one island possession in the Pacific Ocean ([[Clipperton Island]]).
[[File:France-Constituent-Lands.png|thumb|alt=diagram of the overseas territories of France showing map shapes|The lands making up the French Republic, shown at the same [[scale (map)|geographic scale]].]]

Overseas collectivities and territories form part of the French Republic, but do not form part of the European Union or its fiscal area (with the exception of St. Bartelemy, which seceded from Guadeloupe in 2007). The Pacific Collectivities (COMs) of French Polynesia, Wallis and Fortuna, and New Caledonia continue to use the [[CFP franc]]&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.thetahititraveler.com/touristinfo/moneycurr.asp |title=Currency and Exchange Rate |publisher=Thetahititraveler.com |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; whose value is strictly linked to that of the euro. In contrast, the five overseas regions used the French franc and now use the euro.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2085rank.html?countryName=France&amp;countryCode=fr&amp;regionCode=eu&amp;rank=7#fr |title=CIA&amp;nbsp;â€“ The World Factbook |publisher=CIA |date= |accessdate=22 June 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Politics==
{{Main article|Politics of France}}

===Government===
[[File:FranÃ§ois Hollande (JournÃ©es de Nantes 2012).jpg|thumb|upright|alt=head shot of FranÃ§ois Hollande with blue tie|[[FranÃ§ois Hollande]], elected [[President of France|President of the French Republic]] in April 2012.]]{{Main article|Political system of France|Cabinet of France|Constitution of France}}

The French Republic is a [[unitary state|unitary]] [[semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic with strong democratic traditions.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.democracyweb.org/limits/france.php |title=Comparative studies in Freedom&amp;nbsp;â€“ France |publisher=Democracy Web |date= |accessdate=30 September 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The constitution of the Fifth Republic was approved by [[referendum]] on 28 September 1958.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.oecd.org/home/0,3305,en_2649_201185_1_1_1_1_1,00.html France: Fifth Republic]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://flagspot.net/flags/index.html Flags of the World] {{wayback|url=http://www.oecd.org/home/0,3305,en_2649_201185_1_1_1_1_1,00.html |date=20100817062109 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; It greatly strengthened the authority of the executive in relation to parliament. The executive branch itself has two leaders: the [[President of France|President of the Republic]], currently [[FranÃ§ois Hollande]], who is [[head of state]] and is elected directly by universal adult suffrage for a 5-year term (formerly 7 years),&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.ladocumentationfrancaise.fr/dossiers/quinquennat/chronologie.shtml Le quinquennat : le rÃ©fÃ©rendum du 24 Septembre 2000]&lt;/ref&gt; and the Government, led by the president-appointed [[Prime Minister of France|Prime Minister]], currently [[Manuel Valls]].

The French [[French Parliament|parliament]] is a [[Bicameralism|bicameral]] legislature comprising a [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] (''AssemblÃ©e Nationale'') and a [[Senate (France)|Senate]].&lt;ref&gt;[https://web.archive.org/web/20081205055025/http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/english/synthetic_files/file_4.asp The National Assembly and the Senate&amp;nbsp;â€“ General Characteristics of the Parliament]. Official Site of the French National Assembly&lt;/ref&gt; The National Assembly deputies represent local constituencies and are directly elected for 5-year terms.&lt;ref&gt;[https://web.archive.org/web/20110704054719/http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/english/election.asp#election Election of deputies]. Official Site of the National Assembly&lt;/ref&gt; The Assembly has the power to dismiss the government, and thus the majority in the Assembly determines the choice of government. Senators are chosen by an electoral college for 6-year terms (originally 9-year terms), and one half of the seats are submitted to election every 3 years starting in September 2008.&lt;ref&gt;[https://web.archive.org/web/20110615001205/http://www.senat.fr/lng/en/election_senateurs.html The senatorial elections]. Official Site of the Senate&lt;/ref&gt;

The Senate's legislative powers are limited; in the event of disagreement between the two chambers, the National Assembly has the final say.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.politique.net/2007081801-le-role-du-senat.htm Le role du SÃ©nat]&lt;/ref&gt; The government has a strong influence in shaping the agenda of Parliament.

French politics are characterised by two politically opposed groupings: one left-wing, centred on the [[Socialist Party (France)|French Socialist Party]], and the other right-wing, centred previously around the [[Rally for the Republic|Rassemblement pour la RÃ©publique (RPR)]], then its successor the UMP [[Union for a Popular Movement]] (UMP), which in 2015 was renamed Les RÃ©publicains.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book |title=La France vers le bipartisme? La prÃ©sidentialisation du PS et de l'UMP|last=Grunberg |first=GÃ©rard |year=2007 |isbn=2-7246-1010-5|url=http://www.pressesdesciencespo.fr/fr/livre/?GCOI=27246100617740|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; Since the 2012 elections, the executive branch is currently composed mostly of the Socialist Party.

===Law===
{{Main article|Law of France}}
France uses a [[civil law (legal system)|civil legal]] system;&lt;ref name=France /&gt; that is, law arises primarily from written statutes; judges are not to make law, but merely to interpret it (though the amount of judicial interpretation in certain areas makes it equivalent to [[case law]]). Basic principles of the [[rule of law]] were laid in the [[Napoleonic Code]] (which was, in turn, largely based on the royal law codified under [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]]). In agreement with the principles of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, law should only prohibit actions detrimental to society. As [[Guy Canivet]], first president of the [[Court of Cassation (France)|Court of Cassation]], wrote about the management of prisons: ''Freedom is the rule, and its restriction is the exception; any restriction of Freedom must be provided for by Law and must follow the principles of necessity and proportionality.'' That is, Law should lay out prohibitions only if they are needed, and if the inconveniences caused by this restriction do not exceed the inconveniences that the prohibition is supposed to remedy.
[[File:Declaration of Human Rights.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=color drawing of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen from 1789|The basic principles that the French Republic must respect are found in the 1789 [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]].]]

French law is divided into two principal areas: [[private law]] and [[public law]]. Private law includes, in particular, [[civil law (common law)|civil law]] and [[criminal law]]. Public law includes, in particular, [[administrative law]] and [[constitutional law]]. However, in practical terms, French law comprises three principal areas of law: civil law, criminal law, and administrative law. Criminal laws can only address the future and not the past (criminal ''[[Ex post facto law|ex post facto]]'' laws are prohibited).&lt;ref&gt;In European countries, legal doctrine has long faced the question of succession of criminal laws in time:  {{cite journal|last1=Buonomo|first1=Giampiero|title = La rivendicazione di Gallo |journal= Mondoperaio edizione online|date=2015| url= https://www.questia.com/projects#!/project/89426924}} {{Subscription required |via=[[Questia]]}}&lt;/ref&gt; While administrative law is often a subcategory of civil law in many countries, it is completely separated in France and each body of law is headed by a specific supreme court: ordinary courts (which handle criminal and civil litigation) are headed by the [[Court of Cassation (France)|Court of Cassation]] and administrative courts are headed by the [[Conseil d'Etat (France)|Council of State]].

To be applicable, every law must be officially published in the ''[[Journal officiel de la RÃ©publique franÃ§aise]]''.

France does not recognize [[religious law]] as a motivation for the enactment of prohibitions. France has long had neither [[blasphemy]] laws nor [[sodomy law]]s (the latter being abolished in 1791). However, &quot;offenses against [[Decency|public decency]]&quot; (''contraires aux bonnes mÅ“urs'') or [[breach of the peace|disturbing public order]] (''trouble Ã  l'ordre public'') have been used to repress public expressions of homosexuality or street prostitution. Since 1999, [[Pacte civil de solidaritÃ©|civil unions]] for homosexual couples are permitted, and since May 2013, [[same-sex marriage]] and [[LGBT adoption]] are legal in France.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=|first=|title=FranÃ§ois Hollande signs same-sex marriage into law|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130518-france-gay-marriage-law-adoption|accessdate=27 June 2013|publisher=France 24|date=18 May 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; Laws prohibiting discriminatory speech in the press are [[Law on the Freedom of the Press of 29 July 1881|as old as 1881]]. Some consider however that [[hate speech laws in France]] are too broad or severe and damage [[freedom of speech]].&lt;ref&gt;&quot;France: Strict Defamation and Privacy Laws Limit Free Expression&amp;nbsp;â€“ Index on Censorship | Index on Censorship.&quot; France: Strict Defamation and Privacy Laws Limit Free Expression&amp;nbsp;â€“ Index on Censorship | Index on Censorship. N.p., n.d. Web. 26 February 2014. [http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2013/08/france-faces-restrictions-on-free-expression/].&lt;/ref&gt;
France has laws against [[racism]] and [[antisemitism]].&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20101205103557/http://www.ambafrance-dz.org/ambassade/IMG/Lutte_racisme_et_antisemitisme.pdf La lutte contre le racisme et l'antisÃ©mintisme en France]. AmbaFrance&lt;/ref&gt; Since 1990, the [[Gayssot Act]] prohibits [[Holocaust denial]].

France's attitude towards [[freedom of religion in France|freedom of religion]] is complex. Freedom of religion is guaranteed by the constitutional rights set forth in the 1789 ''Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen''. However, since the [[1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State]], the State tries to prevent its policy-making from being influenced by religion and became suspicious in recent decades towards new religious tendencies of the French society: the Parliament has [[Groups referred to as cults in government reports#France|listed many religious movements as dangerous cults]] since 1995, and has [[French law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools|banned wearing conspicuous religious symbols in schools]] since 2004. In 2010, it banned the [[French ban on face covering|wearing of face-covering Islamic veils in public]]. As some have complained that they have suffered from discrimination thus, and after criticism by human rights groups such as [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=Kenneth Roth Executive Director |url=http://hrw.org/english/docs/2004/02/26/france7666.htm |title=Human Rights Watch |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=26 February 2004 |accessdate=31 January 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=France votes to ban full-face veils|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/france-votes-ban-full-face-veils-2010-07-13|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|date=13 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; these laws remain controversial, although they are supported by most of the population.&lt;ref name='Pew'&gt;{{cite news|first=Frederic |last=Dumoulin |title=French parliament adopts ban on full-face veil |date=14 September 2010 |publisher=Google News |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gNCFdNZ4r-9aDEBG0G_OUSMKoASw |accessdate=14 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130518083647/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gNCFdNZ4r-9aDEBG0G_OUSMKoASw |archivedate=18 May 2013 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Foreign relations===
{{Main article|Foreign relations of France}}

[[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F076314-0006, Manching, ManÃ¶ver Frankreich-Deutschland.jpg|thumb|right|alt=FranÃ§ois Mitterrand Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 24 September 1987 at press conference with microphones|French President [[FranÃ§ois Mitterrand]] and [[West Germany|West German]] Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]], in 1987.]]
France is a founding member of the [[United Nations]] and serves as one of the [[Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council|permanent members of the UN Security Council]] with veto rights.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.un.org/sc/members.asp Membership of the Security Councils of the UN] on the [http://www.un.org/en/index.shtml Official Site of the UN] {{wayback|url=http://www.un.org/sc/members.asp |date=20100706231352 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2015, France was described as being &quot;the best networked state in the world&quot;, because it is a country that &quot;is member of more multi-lateral organisations than any other country&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.comres.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Report_Final-published.pdf The Soft Power 30], [[Monocle (media company)|Monocle]]&lt;/ref&gt;

France is a member of the [[G8]], [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO),&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/whatis_e/tif_e/org6_e.htm |title=Understanding the WTO&amp;nbsp;â€“ Members |publisher=WTO |accessdate=30 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; the [[Secretariat of the Pacific Community]] (SPC)&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.spc.int/en/about-spc/history.html|title=History|publisher= Official Site of the SPC}}&lt;/ref&gt; and the [[Indian Ocean Commission]] (COI).&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.coi-ioc.org/index.php?id=36 Pays membres]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.coi-ioc.org/index.php?id=72 Site officiel de la COI] {{wayback|url=http://www.coi-ioc.org/index.php?id=36 |date=20120402173028 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; It is an associate member of the [[Association of Caribbean States]] (ACS)&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.acs-aec.org/index.php?q=about-the-acs |title=About the Association of Caribbean States |publisher=Acs-aec.org |date=24 July 1994 |accessdate=22 June 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; and a leading member of the [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie|International Francophone Organisation]] (OIF) of fifty-one fully or partly French-speaking countries.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.francophonie.org/-Etats-et-gouvernements-.html Ã‰tats et gouvernements : le monde de la Francophonie]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.francophonie.org/ Site officiel de l'OIF]&lt;/ref&gt;

As a significant hub for international relations, France hosts the [[List of diplomatic missions of France|second largest assembly]] of [[diplomatic mission]]s in the world and the headquarters of [[international organization]]s including the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]], [[UNESCO]], [[Interpol]], the [[International Bureau of Weights and Measures]], and ''[[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie|la Francophonie]]''.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/ministry_158/embassies-and-consulates_2052/bilateral-embassies_1580.html |title=France-Diplomatie&amp;nbsp;â€“ Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development |author=The French Ministry of Foreign affairs |work=France Diplomatie : The French Ministry of Foreign affairs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908014607/http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr:80/en/ministry_158/embassies-and-consulates_2052/bilateral-embassies_1580.html |archivedate=8 September 2010 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

Postwar French foreign policy has been largely shaped by membership of the European Union, of which it was a [[Inner Six|founding member]]. Since the [[Ã‰lysÃ©e Treaty|1960s]], France has developed close ties with reunified Germany to become the [[Franceâ€“Germany relations|most influential driving force of the EU]].&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.oftt.eu/perspectives/article/l-alliance-franco-allemande-au-coeur-de-la-puissance-europeenne L'alliance Franco-allemande au coeur de la puissance europÃ©enne]&lt;/ref&gt; In the 1960s, France sought to exclude the British from the European unification process,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/27/newsid_4187000/4187714.stm |title=De Gaulle says 'non' to Britain&amp;nbsp;â€“ again |publisher=BBC News |date= 27 November 1967|accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; seeking to build its own standing in continental Europe. However, since 1904, France has maintained an &quot;[[Entente cordiale]]&quot; with the [[United Kingdom]], and there has been a strengthening of links between the countries, especially [[Defence and Security Co-operation Treaty|militarily]].

[[File:Inauguration EYE2014 Parlement europÃ©en Strasbourg 9 mai 2014.jpg|thumb|left|alt=European Parliament opening in Strasbourg with crowd and many countries' flags on flagpoles|The [[European Parliament]] in [[Strasbourg]], near the border with [[Germany]]. France is a founding member of all EU institutions.]]

France is a member of the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organisation]] (NATO), but under President de Gaulle, it excluded itself from the joint military command to protest the [[Special Relationship|special relationship]] between the United States and Britain and to preserve the independence of French foreign and security policies.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2009/03/11/01003-20090311ARTFIG00073-quand-mitterrand-deja-negociait-le-retour-dans-l-otan-.php Quand Mitterrand, dÃ©jÃ , nÃ©gociait le retour de la France dans l'OTAN]&amp;nbsp;â€“ ''Le Figaro''&lt;/ref&gt; France vigorously opposed the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/asiapcf/east/01/23/sprj.irq.china/index.html |title=China adds voice to Iraq war doubts |publisher=CNN |date= 23 January 2003|accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2683409.stm |title=EU allies unite against Iraq war |publisher=BBC News |date=22 January 2003 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; straining bilateral relations with the US&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://usforeignpolicy.about.com/od/newsiss3/tp/iraqwarrelations.htm |title=Foreign Policy Implications of the Iraq War |publisher=Usforeignpolicy.about.com |date=11 March 2004 |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author=Sean Loughlin CNN Washington Bureau |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2003/ALLPOLITICS/03/11/sprj.irq.fries/ |title=House cafeterias change names for 'french' fries and 'french' toast |publisher=CNN |date=12 March 2003 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and the UK.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/pays-zones-geo_833/royaume-uni_202/index.html France-Diplomatie : Royaume-Uni]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (France)|MinistÃ¨re des Affaires Ã‰trangÃ¨res]]&lt;/ref&gt; However, as a result of Nicolas Sarkozy's ''pro-American'' politics (much criticised in France by the leftists and by a part of the right),&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7937666.stm |title=France ends four-decade Nato rift |publisher=BBC News |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = Le retour de la France dans l'OTAN suscite un malaise dans les rangs de la Droite
 | first = Patrick
 | last = Roger
 | url = http://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2009/03/11/le-retour-de-la-france-dans-l-otan-suscite-un-malaise-dans-les-rangs-de-la-droite_1166352_823448.html
 | newspaper=Le Monde
 | location = Paris
 | date = 11 March 2009
 |language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; France rejoined the NATO joint military command on 4 April 2009.

In the early 1990s, the country drew considerable criticism from other nations for its underground nuclear tests in [[French Polynesia]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9512/france_nuclear/ |title=Fifth French nuclear test sparks international outrage |publisher=CNN |date=28 December 1995 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

France retains strong political and economic influence in its [[Second French colonial empire|former African colonies]] ([[FranÃ§afrique]])&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.memo.fr/article.asp?ID=CON_COL_009 L'empire colonial franÃ§ais]&lt;/ref&gt; and has supplied economic aid and troops for peace-keeping missions in [[Ivory Coast]] and [[Chad]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.delegfrance-onu-geneve.org/spip.php?article417 |title=France involvement in peace-keeping operations |publisher=Delegfrance-onu-geneve.org |accessdate=9 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20110425024055/http://www.delegfrance-onu-geneve.org/spip.php?article417 |archivedate=25 April 2011 }}&lt;/ref&gt; Recently, after the unilateral declaration of independence of northern [[Mali]] by the [[Tuareg rebellion (2012)|Tuareg]] [[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad|MNLA]] and the subsequent regional [[Northern Mali conflict]] with several Islamist groups including [[Ansar Dine]] and [[Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa|MOJWA]], France and other African states intervened to help the Malian Army to retake control.

In 2013, France was the fourth largest (in absolute terms) donor of [[development aid]] in the world, behind the US, the UK and Germany. This represents 0.36% of its GDP, in this regard rating France as twelfth largest donor on the list.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/newsroom/aid-to-developing-countries-rebounds-in-2013-to-reach-an-all-time-high.htm|title=Aid to developing countries rebounds in 2013 to reach an all-time high
|publisher=OECD|accessdate=3 March 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; The organisation managing the French help is the [[French Development Agency]], which finances primarily humanitarian projects in [[sub-Saharan Africa]].&lt;ref name = aid /&gt; The main goals of this help are &quot;developing infrastructure, access to health care and education, the implementation of appropriate economic policies and the consolidation of the rule of law and democracy&quot;.&lt;ref name = aid&gt;[http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/france-priorities_1/index.html France priorities]&amp;nbsp;â€“ France Diplomatie&lt;/ref&gt;

===Military===
{{Main article|French Armed Forces}}

[[File:French military images.jpg|thumb|300px|alt=see description|Examples of France's military. Clockwise from top left: Nuclear aircraft carrier ''[[French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)|Charles de Gaulle]]''; A [[Dassault Rafale|Rafale]] [[fighter aircraft]]; French [[Chasseurs Alpins]] patrolling the valleys of Kapisa province in Afghanistan; a [[AMX-56 Leclerc|Leclerc tank]] in Paris for the [[Bastille Day|14 July]] [[Bastille Day Military Parade]].]]

The French Armed Forces (''Forces armÃ©es franÃ§aises'') are the military and paramilitary forces of France, under the [[President of France|president]] as supreme commander. They consist of the [[French Army]] (''ArmÃ©e de Terre''), [[French Navy]] (''Marine Nationale'', formerly called ''ArmÃ©e de Mer''), the [[French Air Force]] (''ArmÃ©e de l'Air''), the French Strategic Nuclear Force (''Force NuclÃ©aire StratÃ©gique'', nicknamed ''Force de Frappe'' or &quot;Strike Force&quot;)  and the Military Police called [[National Gendarmerie]] (''Gendarmerie nationale''), which also fulfils civil police duties in the rural areas of France. Together they are among the [[List of countries by number of troops|largest armed forces]] in the world and the largest in the [[EU]].

While the Gendarmerie  is an integral part of the French armed forces (gendarmes are career soldiers), and therefore under the purview of the [[Minister of Defense (France)|Ministry of Defence]], it is operationally attached to the [[Minister of the Interior (France)|Ministry of the Interior]] as far as its civil police duties are concerned.

When acting as general purpose police force, the Gendarmerie encompasses the counter terrorist units of the [[Parachute Intervention Squadron of the National Gendarmerie]] (''Escadron Parachutiste d'Intervention de la Gendarmerie Nationale''), the [[National Gendarmerie Intervention Group]] (''Groupe d'Intervention de la Gendarmerie Nationale''), the Search Sections of the National Gendarmerie (''Sections de Recherche de la Gendarmerie Nationale''), responsible for criminal enquiries, and the Mobile Brigades of the National Gendarmerie (''Brigades mobiles de la Gendarmerie Nationale'', or in short ''Gendarmerie mobile'') which have the task to maintain public order.

The following special units are also part of the Gendarmerie:
The Republican Guard (''Garde rÃ©publicaine'') which protects public buildings hosting major French institutions,
the Maritime Gendarmerie (''Gendarmerie maritime'') serving as Coast Guard,
the Provost Service (''PrÃ©vÃ´tÃ©''), acting as the Military Police branch of the Gendarmerie.

As far as the French intelligence units are concerned, the [[Directorate-General for External Security]] (''Direction gÃ©nÃ©rale de la sÃ©curitÃ© extÃ©rieure'') is considered to be a component of the Armed Forces under the authority of the Ministry of Defence. The other, the Central Directorate for Interior Intelligence (''Direction centrale du renseignement intÃ©rieur'') is a division of the National Police Force (''Direction gÃ©nÃ©rale de la Police Nationale''), and therefore reports directly to the Ministry of the Interior. There has been no national [[conscription]] since 1997.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.ladocumentationfrancaise.fr/dossiers/service-civil/fin-service-militaire-obligatoire.shtml La fin du service militaire obligatoire]&amp;nbsp;â€“ La documentation franÃ§aise&lt;/ref&gt;

France has a special military corps, the [[French Foreign Legion]], founded in 1830, which consists of foreign nationals from over 140 countries who are willing to serve in the French Armed Forces and become French citizens after the end of their service period. The only other countries having similar units are Spain (the Spanish Foreign Legion, called ''Tercio'', was founded in 1920) and Luxembourg (foreigners can serve in the National Army provided they speak Luxembourgish).

France is a [[Big Five (United Nations)|permanent member of the Security Council of the UN]], and a [[List of states with nuclear weapons#Five nuclear-weapon states under the NPT|recognised nuclear state]] since 1960. France has signed and ratified the [[Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty]] (CTBT)&lt;ref name=&quot;status&quot;&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.ctbto.org/the-treaty/status-of-signature-and-ratification/ |title=Status of signature and ratification |publisher=CTBTO Preparatory Commission |date=26 May 2010 |accessdate=27 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and acceded to the [[Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]]. France's annual military expenditure in 2011 was US$62.5 billion, or 2.3%, of its GDP making it the [[List of countries by military expenditures|fifth biggest military spender in the world]] after the United States, China, Russia, and the United Kingdom.&lt;ref name=&quot;SIPRI Yearbook 2012&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.statista.com/statistics/262742/countries-with-the-highest-military-spending/ |title=The 15 countries with the highest military spending worldwide in 2012 (in billion U.S. dollars) |publisher=Sipri.org |date= |accessdate=25 September 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

French nuclear deterrence, (formerly known as &quot;''[[Force de Frappe]]''&quot;), relies on complete independence. The current French nuclear force consists of four [[Triomphant class submarine|''Triomphant'']] class submarines equipped with [[submarine-launched ballistic missile]]s. In addition to the submarine fleet, it is estimated that France has about 60 [[Air-Sol Moyenne PortÃ©e|''ASMP'']] medium-range [[Air-to-surface missile|air-to-ground missiles]] with [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear warheads]],&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} Centre de Documentation et de Recherche sur la Paix et les Conflits, [http://obsarm.org/obsnuc/puissances-mondiales/france-forces.html ''Etat des forces nuclÃ©aires franÃ§aises au 15 aoÃ»t 2004'']&lt;/ref&gt; of which around 50 are deployed by the Air Force using the [[Dassault Mirage 2000N/2000D|Mirage 2000N]] long-range nuclear strike aircraft, while around 10 are deployed by the French Navy's [[Dassault-Breguet Super Ã‰tendard|Super Ã‰tendard ModernisÃ© (SEM)]] attack aircraft, which operate from the nuclear-powered [[aircraft carrier]] [[French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)|''Charles de Gaulle'']]. The new [[Dassault Rafale|Rafale F3]] aircraft will gradually replace all Mirage 2000N and SEM in the nuclear strike role with the improved ''ASMP-A'' missile with a nuclear warhead.

France has major military industries with one of the largest [[Aerospace manufacturer|aerospace industries]] in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/ynhti/curriculum/units/1990/7/90.07.06.x.html |title=90.07.06: The Aerospace Industry: Its History and How it Affects the U.S. Economy |publisher=Yale |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Aerospace industry of France|url=https://thetranslationcompany.com/resources/language-country/french/aerospace-industry-france.htm|website=The Translation Company|accessdate=6 January 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; Its industries have produced such equipment as the Rafale fighter, the ''Charles de Gaulle'' aircraft carrier, the [[Exocet]] missile and the [[AMX-56 Leclerc|Leclerc]] tank among others. Despite withdrawing from the [[Eurofighter Typhoon|Eurofighter]] project, France is actively investing in European joint projects such as the [[Eurocopter Tiger]], [[FREMM multipurpose frigate|multipurpose frigates]], the [[Unmanned combat air vehicle|UCAV]] demonstrator [[Dassault nEUROn|nEUROn]] and the [[Airbus A400M]]. France is a major arms seller,&lt;ref&gt;&quot;En 2001, la France a vendu pour 1,288 milliard de dollars d'Ã©quipements militaires, ce qui la met au troisiÃ¨me rang mondial des exportateurs derriÃ¨re les Ã‰tats-Unis et la Russie.&quot;&amp;nbsp;â€“ &quot;In 2001, France sold $1,288&amp;nbsp;billion of military equipment, ranking 3rd in the world for arms exportations behind the USA and Russia&quot; [http://lexpansion.lexpress.fr/entreprise/la-france-demeure-un-fournisseur-d-armes-de-premier-plan_95084.html La France demeure un fournisseur d'armes de premier plan (France stays one of the biggest arms supplier)]&amp;nbsp;â€“ L'express. 13 June 2002{{Dead link|date=June 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&quot;La France est au 4Ã¨me rang mondial des exportateurs d'armes, derriÃ¨re les Etats-Unis, le Royaume-Uni et la Russie, et devant IsraÃ«l, selon un rapport du ministÃ¨re de la DÃ©fense publiÃ© l'an dernier.&quot; &quot;France is 4th biggest arms exportator, behind the USA, the UK and Russia, and ahead of Israel, according to a report of the Ministry of Defense published a year ago&quot; [http://www.20minutes.fr/article/551139/Economie-Les-ventes-d-armes-explosent-en-2009.php Arms sellings explode in 2009]&amp;nbsp;â€“ 20 minutes&lt;/ref&gt; with most of its arsenal's designs available for the export market with the notable exception of nuclear-powered devices.

The [[Bastille Day Military Parade|military parade]] held in Paris each 14 July for [[Bastille Day|France's national day]], called ''Bastille Day'' in English-speaking countries (but not in France), is the oldest and largest regular military parade in Europe.&lt;ref&gt;Mail Online, ''Harrowing loss of Afghanistan troops overshadows France's Bastille Day military parade'', 14 July 2011. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2014729/France-proudly-celebrates-Bastille-Day-despite-deaths-soldiers-Afghanistan-overshadowing-annual-parade.html]. Retrieved 5 January 2012&lt;/ref&gt;

===Government finance===
{{See also|Taxation in France}}

In April and May 2012, France held a [[French presidential election, 2012|presidential election]] in which the winner, [[FranÃ§ois Hollande]], had opposed [[austerity]] measures, promising to eliminate France's budget deficit by 2017. The new government stated that it aimed to cancel recently enacted tax cuts and exemptions for the wealthy, raising the top tax bracket rate to 75% on incomes over a million euros, restoring the retirement age to 60 with a full pension for those who have worked 42 years, restoring 60,000 jobs recently cut from public education, regulating rent increases; and building additional public housing for the poor.

In June, Hollande's [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party]] won a supermajority in [[French legislative election, 2012|legislative elections]] capable of amending the [[Constitution of France|French Constitution]] and enabling the immediate enactment of the promised reforms. French government bond interest rates fell 30% to record lows,&lt;ref name=&quot;bloomberg.com&quot;&gt;Bloomberg (2012) [http://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GFRN10:IND French government bond interest rates] (graph)&lt;/ref&gt; less than 50 [[basis point]]s above German government bond rates.&lt;ref name=&quot;Bloomberg 2012&quot;&gt;Bloomberg (2012) [http://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GDBR10:IND German government bond interest rates] (graph)&lt;/ref&gt;

Under European Union rules, member states are supposed to limit their debt to 60% of output or be reducing the ratio structurally towards this ceiling, and run public deficits of no more than 3% of GDP. The French government has run a [[budget deficit]] each year since the early 1970s. In 2012, French government debt levels reached 1.8 trillion euros, the equivalent of 90% of French GDP.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2186rank.html |title=The World Factbook |publisher=CIA |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In late 2012, [[credit rating agencies]] warned that growing French government debt levels risked [[List of countries by credit rating|France's AAA credit rating]], raising the possibility of a future downgrade and subsequent higher borrowing costs for the French government.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=John |first=Mark |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/26/us-france-debt-idUSBRE89P0SO20121026 |title=Analysis: Low French borrowing costs risk negative reappraisal |publisher=Reuters |date= 26 October 2012|accessdate=27 November 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Economy==
{{Main article|Economy of France}}

A member of the [[G7|Group of 7]] (formerly G8) leading industrialised countries, {{As of|2014|lc=y}}, it is ranked as the world's [[List of countries by GDP (PPP)|ninth largest]] and the EU's second largest economy by [[purchasing power parity]].&lt;ref name=&quot;data.worldbank.org&quot; /&gt; With 31 of the 500 biggest companies in the world in 2015, France ranks fourth in the [[Fortune Global 500]], ahead of Germany and the UK.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://fortune.com/global500/|title=Fortune Global 500 |publisher=Fortune  |accessdate=3 March 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt; France joined 11 other EU members to launch the euro in 1999, with [[euro coins]] and [[euro banknotes|banknotes]] completely replacing the [[French franc]] (â‚£) in 2002.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/in_depth/business/2001/euro_cash/history/ |title=History of the Euro |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=30 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:BlueEurozone.svg|thumb|alt=European map of Eurozone monetary union|France is part of a monetary union, the [[Eurozone]] (dark blue), and of the [[Internal Market (European Union)|EU single market]].]]

France has a [[mixed economy]] that combines extensive private enterprise&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/tableau.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=NATTEF09203|title=Entreprises selon le nombre de salariÃ©s et l'activitÃ©|publisher=[[INSEE]]|date=July 2008|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/tableau.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=NATTEF9303|title=Entreprises publiques selon l'activitÃ© Ã©conomique|publisher=INSEE|date=March 2009|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; with substantial state enterprise and government intervention. The government retains considerable influence over key segments of infrastructure sectors, with majority ownership of railway, electricity, aircraft, nuclear power and telecommunications.&lt;ref name=France /&gt;{{failed verification|date=February 2016}} It has been relaxing its control over these sectors since the early [[1990s in economics|1990s]].&lt;ref name=France /&gt;{{failed verification|date=February 2016}} The government is slowly [[Corporatization|corporatising]] the state sector and selling off holdings in [[Orange S.A.|France TÃ©lÃ©com]], [[Air France]], as well as in the insurance, banking, and defence industries.&lt;ref name=France /&gt;{{failed verification|date=February 2016}} France has an important aerospace industry led by the European consortium [[Airbus]], and has its own national [[spaceport]], the ''[[Centre Spatial Guyanais]]''.

According to the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO), in 2009 France was the world's sixth largest exporter and the fourth largest importer of manufactured goods.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/res_e/statis_e/its2008_e/its2008_e.pdf |title=International Trade Statistics 2008|page=12|year=2009|publisher=[[World Trade Organization]] (WTO)|accessdate=5 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2008, France was the third largest recipient of [[foreign direct investment]] among OECD countries at $118 billion, ranking behind Luxembourg (where foreign direct investment was essentially monetary transfers to banks located there) and the US ($316&amp;nbsp;billion), but above the UK ($96.9&amp;nbsp;billion), Germany ($25&amp;nbsp;billion), or Japan ($24&amp;nbsp;billion).&lt;ref name=FDI&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.unctad.org/sections/dite_dir/docs/wir09_fs_fr_en.pdf|publisher=[[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD)|format=PDF |work=World Investment Report 2009|title=Country fact sheet: France|accessdate=7 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=FDI2&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.unctad.org/sections/dite_dir/docs/wir09_fs_jp_en.pdf|publisher=UNCTAD|format=PDF|work=World Investment Report 2009|title=Country fact sheet: Japan|accessdate=7 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In the same year, French companies invested $220&amp;nbsp;billion outside France, ranking France as the second largest outward direct investor in the OECD, behind the US ($311&amp;nbsp;billion), and ahead of the UK ($111&amp;nbsp;billion), Japan ($128&amp;nbsp;billion) and Germany ($157&amp;nbsp;billion).&lt;ref name=FDI /&gt;&lt;ref name=FDI2 /&gt;

Financial services, banking and the insurance sector are an important part of the economy. The Paris stock exchange ({{lang-fr|link=no|La Bourse de Paris}}) is an old institution, created by [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]] in 1724.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.gralon.net/articles/economie-et-finance/bourse/article-la-bourse-de-paris---une-institution-depuis-1724-981.htm La Bourse de Paris : une institution depuis 1724]&lt;/ref&gt; In 2000, the stock exchanges of Paris, Amsterdam and Bruxelles merged into [[Euronext]].&lt;ref name = banque&gt;{{cite web|author=Embassy of France |url=http://www.ambafrance-us.org/spip.php?article511 |title=Embassy of France in Washington: Economy of France |publisher=Ambafrance-us.org |accessdate=16 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2007, Euronext merged with the [[New York stock exchange]] to form [[NYSE Euronext]], the world's largest stock exchange.&lt;ref name = banque /&gt; [[Euronext Paris]], the French branch of the NYSE Euronext group is Europe's 2nd largest stock exchange market, behind the [[London Stock Exchange]].

France is part of the European single market which represents more than 500 million consumers. Several domestic commercial policies are determined by agreements among European Union (EU) members and by EU legislation. France introduced the common European currency, the [[Euro]] in 2002.&lt;ref name=euroc&gt;{{cite news |title =Germans Say Goodbye to the Mark, a Symbol of Strength and Unity |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate =18 March 2011 |url = http://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/01/world/germans-say-goodbye-to-the-mark-a-symbol-of-strength-and-unity.html |first=Edmund L. |last =Andrews |date=1 January 2002}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |title=On Jan.&amp;nbsp;1, out of many arises one Euro |newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |first= Susan |last =Taylor Martin |date=28 December 1998 |page=National, 1.A }}&lt;/ref&gt; It is a member of the Eurozone which represents around 330 million citizens.

French companies have maintained key positions in the insurance and banking industries: [[AXA]] is the world's largest insurance company. The leading French banks are [[BNP Paribas]] and the [[CrÃ©dit Agricole]], ranking as the world's first and sixth largest banks in 2010&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.doughroller.net/banking/largest-banks-in-the-world/ |title=The 10 Largest Banks in the World |publisher=Doughroller.net |date=15 June 2010 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (by assets), while the [[SociÃ©tÃ© GÃ©nÃ©rale]] group was ranked the world's eighth largest in 2009.

===Agriculture===
[[File:Glass of champagne.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Champagne wine in a flute|[[Champagne wine|Champagne]], widely regarded as a [[luxury good]], originates from the [[Champagne region]] in northeast France.]]

France has historically been a large producer of agricultural products.&lt;ref name = agriculture&gt;[http://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/economies/Europe/France-AGRICULTURE.html France&amp;nbsp;â€“ Agriculture]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Encyclopedia of the Nations&lt;/ref&gt; Extensive tracts of fertile land, the application of modern technology, and [[Common agricultural policy|EU subsidies]] have combined to make France the leading agricultural producer and exporter in Europe&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url= http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/france_159/economy_6815/overview-of-the-french-economy_6831/key-figures-of-the-french-economy_1402.html#sommaire_1 |publisher=[[Minister of Foreign Affairs (France)|French Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs]]|title=Key figures of the French economy|quote=France is the world's fifth largest exporter of goods (mainly durables). The country ranks fourth in services and third in agriculture (especially in cereals and the agri-food sector). It is the leading producer and exporter of farm products in Europe.}}&lt;/ref&gt; (representing 20% of the EU's agricultural production&lt;ref name=&quot;ministÃ¨re&quot;&gt;[http://agriculture.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/panorama_agriculture_ed2008EN.pdf A panorama of the agriculture and agri-food industries]&amp;nbsp;â€“ MinistÃ¨re de l'Alimentation, de l'Agriculture et de la PÃªche&lt;/ref&gt;) and the world's third biggest exporter of agricultural products.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://agriculture.gouv.fr/un-ministere-au-service-de-votre Un ministÃ¨re au service de votre alimentation]&amp;nbsp;â€“ MinistÃ¨re de l'Alimentation, de l'Agriculture et de la PÃªche&lt;/ref&gt;

Wheat, poultry, dairy, beef, and pork, as well as internationally recognized processed foods are the primary French agricultural exports. [[RosÃ©]] wines are primarily consumed within the country, but [[Champagne (wine)|Champagne]] and [[Bordeaux wine|Bordeaux]] wines are major exports, being known worldwide. EU agriculture subsidies to France have decreased in recent years but still amounted to $8&amp;nbsp;billion in 2007.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url= http://ec.europa.eu/agriculture/fin/directaid/2007/annex1_en.pdf|title=Annex 1: Indicative Figures on the Distribution of Aid, by Size-Class of Aid, Received in the Context of Direct Aid Paid to the Producers According to Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 (Financial Year 2007) |format=PDF |publisher=[[European Commission]]|date=22 April 2009|accessdate=7 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; That same year, France sold 33.4&amp;nbsp;billion euros of transformed agricultural products.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://panorama-iaa.alimentation.gouv.fr/ Les enjeux des industries agroalimentaires franÃ§aises]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Panorama des Industries Agroalimentaires&lt;/ref&gt;

Agriculture is an important sector of France's economy: 3.8% of the active population is employed in agriculture, whereas the total agri-food industry made up 4.2% of French GDP in 2005.&lt;ref name=&quot;ministÃ¨re&quot; /&gt;

===Tourism===
{{Main article|Tourism in France}}
[[File:Mona Lisa, by Leonardo da Vinci, from C2RMF retouched.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Mona Lisa, La Joconde in the Louvre Museum |The [[Mona Lisa]] is the World's best known work of art,&lt;ref&gt;John Lichfield, ''[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/the-moving-of-the-mona-lisa-6149165.html The Moving of the Mona Lisa]'', The Independent, 2 April 2005 (Retrieved 9 March 2012)&lt;/ref&gt; on permanent display at the [[Louvre]], the World's most visited museum.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.aecom.com/deployedfiles/Internet/Capabilities/Economics/_documents/2012%20Theme%20Index%20Combined_1-1_online.pdf Global Attraction Attendance Report, 2012]&lt;/ref&gt;]]

With 83&amp;nbsp;million foreign tourists in 2012,&lt;ref name=&quot;tourism.stat&quot; /&gt; France is [[World Tourism rankings|ranked]] as the first tourist destination in the world, ahead of the US (67&amp;nbsp;million) and China (58&amp;nbsp;million). This 83&amp;nbsp;million figure excludes people staying less than 24 hours, such as North Europeans crossing France on their way to Spain or Italy. It is third in income from tourism due to shorter duration of visits.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news | first=Sarah | last=Dilorenzo | title=France learns to welcome, to speak 'touriste'| url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/france-learns-speak-touriste-0| newspaper=[[The Burlington Free Press]] | location=[[Burlington, Vermont]] | pages= 5A | date=20 July 2013| accessdate=20 July 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;!---sources for hard and soft copy differ but are identical articles---&gt; France has 37 sites inscribed in [[List of World Heritage Sites in France|UNESCO's World Heritage List]] and features cities of high cultural interest, beaches and seaside resorts, [[ski]] resorts, and rural regions that many enjoy for their beauty and tranquillity ([[Ecotourism|green tourism]]). Small and picturesque French villages are promoted through the association ''[[Les Plus Beaux Villages de France]]'' (litt. &quot;The Most Beautiful Villages of France&quot;). The &quot;[[Remarkable Gardens of France|Remarkable Gardens]]&quot; label is a list of the over 200 gardens classified by the [[Minister of Culture (France)|French Ministry of Culture]]. This label is intended to protect and promote remarkable gardens and [[park]]s. France attracts many religious pilgrims on their [[Way of St. James|way to St. James]], or to [[Lourdes]], a town in the [[Hautes-PyrÃ©nÃ©es]] that hosts several million visitors a year.

[[File:Le Mont Saint-Michel.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Mont Saint-Michel a hill monastery in a wetland, with the tide out|The [[Mont Saint-Michel]] is one of the most visited and recognisable landmarks in France. It is one of the 39 [[List of World Heritage Sites in France|UNESCO World Heritage Sites in France]].]]

France, especially Paris, has some of the world's largest and renowned museums, including the [[MusÃ©e du Louvre|Louvre]], which is the [[List of most visited art museums in the world|most visited art museum in the world]], the [[MusÃ©e d'Orsay]], mostly devoted to [[impressionism]], and [[Centre Georges Pompidou|Beaubourg]], dedicated to [[Contemporary art]]. [[Disneyland Paris]] is Europe's most popular theme park, with 15 million combined visitors to the resort's [[Disneyland Park (Paris)|Disneyland Park]] and [[Walt Disney Studios Park]] in 2009.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://www.themeit.com/etea/2009report.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602032710/http://www.themeit.com/etea/2009report.pdf|archivedate=2 June 2010|publisher=Themed Entertainment Association|title=2009 Theme Index. The Global Attractions Attendance Report, 2009|accessdate=7 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

With more than 10 millions tourists a year, the [[French Riviera]] (or ''CÃ´te d'Azur''), in south-east France, is the second leading tourist destination in the country, after the [[ÃŽle-de-France (region)|Paris region]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.frenchriviera-tourism.com/regional-tourism-organization/the-french-riviera-tourist-board-06_191.html |title=The French Riviera Tourist Board |publisher=Frenchriviera-tourism.com |accessdate=23 January 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; It benefits from 300 days of sunshine per year, {{convert|115|km}} of coastline and beaches, 18 golf courses, 14 ski resorts and 3,000 restaurants.&lt;ref&gt;CÃ´te d'Azur Economic Development Agency. [http://www.crdp-nice.net/dp/IMG/pdf/Kit_Info_Cote_d_Azur_FR_Version_sept_07.pdf p. 31 CRDP-Nice.net] {{wayback|url=http://www.crdp-nice.net/dp/IMG/pdf/Kit_Info_Cote_d_Azur_FR_Version_sept_07.pdf |date=20100704173303 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; Each year the ''CÃ´te d'Azur'' hosts 50% of the world's [[Luxury yacht|superyacht]] fleet.&lt;ref&gt;CÃ´te d'Azur Economic Development Agency, [http://www.crdp-nice.net/dp/IMG/pdf/Kit_Info_Cote_d_Azur_FR_Version_sept_07.pdf p. 66] {{wayback|url=http://www.crdp-nice.net/dp/IMG/pdf/Kit_Info_Cote_d_Azur_FR_Version_sept_07.pdf |date=20100704173303 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt;

Another major destination are the ''ChÃ¢teaux'' of the [[Loire Valley]], this [[World Heritage Site]] is noteworthy for its architectural heritage, in its historic towns but in particular its castles (''chÃ¢teaux''), such as the [[ChÃ¢teau]]x d'[[ChÃ¢teau d'Amboise|Amboise]], de Chambord, d'[[ChÃ¢teau d'UssÃ©|UssÃ©]], de [[ChÃ¢teau de Villandry|Villandry]] and [[ChÃ¢teau de Chenonceau|Chenonceau]]. The most popular tourist sites include: (according to a 2003 ranking&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www2.culture.gouv.fr/deps/mini_chiff_03/fr/musee.htm|title=FrÃ©quentation des musÃ©es et des bÃ¢timents historiques|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; visitors per year): [[Eiffel Tower]] (6.2&amp;nbsp;million), Louvre Museum (5.7&amp;nbsp;million), Palace of Versailles (2.8&amp;nbsp;million), MusÃ©e d'Orsay (2.1&amp;nbsp;million), [[Arc de Triomphe]] (1.2&amp;nbsp;million), [[Centre Georges Pompidou|Centre Pompidou]] (1.2&amp;nbsp;million), [[Mont Saint-Michel]] (1&amp;nbsp;million), ChÃ¢teau de Chambord (711,000), [[Sainte-Chapelle]] (683,000), [[ChÃ¢teau du Haut-KÅ“nigsbourg]] (549,000), [[Puy de DÃ´me]] (500,000), [[MusÃ©e Picasso]] (441,000), [[Carcassonne]] (362,000).

===Energy===
{{Further|Energy in France}}
[[File:Nuclear Power Plant Cattenom.jpg|thumb|alt=Nuclear power plant in Cattenom, France four large cooling towers expelling white water vapor against a blue sky|France derives [[Nuclear power in France|75% of its electricity from nuclear power]], the highest percentage in the world.&lt;ref name=&quot;energy profile&quot;&gt;{{cite news
| last = EnerPub
| title = France: Energy profile
| work=Spero News
| accessdate =25 August 2007
| date = 8 June 2007
| url = http://www.speroforum.com/site/article.asp?idarticle=9839&amp;t=France%3A+Energy+profile
}}&lt;/ref&gt; Photo of [[Cattenom Nuclear Power Plant]].]]

[[Ã‰lectricitÃ© de France]] (EDF), the main [[electricity]] generation and distribution company in France, is also one of the world's largest producers of electricity. In 2003, it produced 22% of the [[European Union]]'s electricity, primarily from [[nuclear power]]. France is the smallest emitter of [[Greenhouse gas|carbon dioxide]] among the [[G8]], due to its heavy investment in [[nuclear power]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/environment/air_co2_emissions.htm |title=Greenhouse Gas Emissions|publisher=United Nations|date=August 2009|work=Environmental Indicators}}&lt;/ref&gt; As a result of large investments in nuclear technology, most electricity produced by France is generated by 59 nuclear power plants (75% in 2012).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Facts-and-Figures/Nuclear-generation-by-country/#.UkrawYakrOM |title=Nuclear shares of electricity generation |publisher=World-nuclear.org |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; In this context, renewable energies are having difficulty taking off. France also uses hydroelectric dams to produce electricity, such as the [[Eguzon dam]], [[Ã‰tang de Soulcem]], and [[Lac de Vouglans]].

===Transport===
{{Main article|Transport in France}}
The [[Rail transport in France|railway network of France]], which {{as of|lc=y|2008}} stretches {{convert|29473|km|mi|0}}&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Chiffres_transport-pdf.pdf|title=Chiffres clÃ©s du transport 2010|accessdate=7 October 2010|language=fr}}&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/ Site officiel] du [[Ministry of Ecology, Energy, Sustainable Development and Sea|MinistÃ¨re de l'Ã‰cologie, de l'Ã‰nergie, du DÃ©veloppement Durable et de la Mer]]&lt;/ref&gt; is the second most extensive in Western Europe after that of [[Rail transport in Germany|Germany]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2121rank.html?countryName=France&amp;countryCode=fr&amp;regionCode=eu&amp;rank=9#fr |title=The World Factbook&amp;nbsp;â€“ Country comparison :: railways|publisher=CIA |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is operated by the [[SNCF]], and high-speed trains include the [[Thalys]], the [[Eurostar]] and [[TGV]], which travels at {{convert|320|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} in commercial use.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://h2g2.com/dna/h2g2/A711785 |title=h2g2&amp;nbsp;â€“ TGV&amp;nbsp;â€“ The French High-speed Train Service |publisher=BBC |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Eurostar, along with the [[Eurotunnel Shuttle]], connects with the United Kingdom through the [[Channel Tunnel]]. Rail connections exist to all other neighbouring countries in Europe, except [[Andorra]]. Intra-urban connections are also well developed with both [[Rapid transit|underground services]] (Paris, Lyon, Lille, Marseille, Toulouse, Rennes) and tramway services (Nantes, Strasbourg, Bordeaux, Grenoble, Montpellier...) complementing bus services.

[[File:TGV-Duplex Paris.jpg|thumb|left|alt=TGV Duplex silver and blue in the Gare de Lyon, Paris|A [[TGV Duplex]], which can reach a maximum speed of {{convert|320|km/h|2|abbr=on}}.]]

There are approximately {{convert|1027183|km|mi|0}} of serviceable roadway in France, ranking it the most extensive network of the European continent.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2085rank.html?countryName=France&amp;countryCode=fr&amp;regionCode=eu&amp;rank=7#fr |title=The World Factbook&amp;nbsp;â€“ Country comparison :: roadways |publisher=CIA |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Paris region is enveloped with the most dense network of roads and highways that connect it with virtually all parts of the country. French roads also handle substantial international traffic, connecting with cities in neighbouring Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Spain, Andorra and Monaco. There is no annual registration fee or [[road tax]]; however, usage of the mostly privately owned motorways is through tolls except in the vicinity of large communes. The new car market is dominated by domestic brands such as [[Renault]] (27% of cars sold in France in 2003), [[Peugeot]] (20.1%) and [[CitroÃ«n]] (13.5%).&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} L'automobile magazine, hors-sÃ©rie 2003/2004 page 294&lt;/ref&gt; Over 70% of new cars sold in 2004 had [[diesel engine]]s, far more than contained petrol or [[Liquified petroleum gas|LPG]] engines.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ademe.fr/particuliers/fiches/voiture/rub3.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006095330/http://www.ademe.fr/particuliers/fiches/voiture/rub3.htm |archivedate=6 October 2008 |title=Guide pratique de l' ADEME, la voiture |publisher=Ademe.fr |accessdate=22 October 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; France possesses the [[Millau Viaduct]], the world's tallest bridge,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Bockman |first=Chris |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3237329.stm |title=France builds world's tallest bridge |publisher=BBC News |date=4 November 2003 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and has built many important bridges such as the [[Pont de Normandie]].

There are 464 [[List of airports in France|airports]] in France.&lt;ref name=France&gt;{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/fr.html |title=The World Factbook: France |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |accessdate=12 February 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]], located in the vicinity of Paris, is the largest and busiest airport in the country, handling the vast majority of popular and commercial traffic and connecting Paris with virtually all major cities across the world. [[Air France]] is the national carrier airline, although numerous private airline companies provide domestic and international travel services. There are ten major ports in France, the largest of which is in [[Marseille]],&lt;ref&gt;[https://web.archive.org/web/20080517035156/http://www.bdpinternational.com/news/StrikesblockFrenchports.asp Strikes block French ports]. The Journal of Commerce Online (via BDP International). 23 April 2008&lt;/ref&gt; which also is the largest bordering the Mediterranean Sea.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.laprovence.com/article/region/marseille-un-grand-port-maritime-qui-ne-demande-qua-se-montrer Marseille : un grand port maritime qui ne demande qu'Ã  se montrer]&amp;nbsp;â€“ La Provence&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://blog.hotelclub.com/marseille/ |title=Marseille&amp;nbsp;â€“ A French Pearl in the Mediterranean Sea |publisher=Blog.hotelclub.com |date=22 February 2010 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; {{convert|12261|km|mi|0}} of waterways traverse France including the [[Canal du Midi]], which connects the Mediterranean Sea to the Atlantic Ocean through the [[Garonne]] river.&lt;ref name =France /&gt;

===Sciences===
{{Main article|List of French inventions and discoveries}}
[[File:Ariane4.jpg|thumb|upright|right|alt=Ariane four rocket taking off past the tower|France is one of the biggest contributors to the [[European Space Agency]] ([[Ariane 4]] launch pictured).]]

Since the [[Middle Ages]], France has been a major contributor to scientific achievement. Around the beginning of the 11th century [[Pope Sylvester II]], born Gerbert d'Aurillac, reintroduced the [[abacus]] and [[armillary sphere]], and introduced [[Arabic numerals]] and [[clock]]s to northern and western Europe.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/livesnecromance04godwgoog|title=Lives of the Necromancers|author=William Godwin|year=1876|page=232}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[University of Paris]], founded in the mid-12th century, is still one of the most important universities in the Western world.&lt;ref&gt;AndrÃ© Thuilier, Histoire de l'universitÃ© de Paris et de la Sorbonne, Paris, Nouvelle librairie de France, 1994&lt;/ref&gt; In the 17th century, [[RenÃ© Descartes]] defined a [[Rationalism|method for the acquisition of scientific knowledge]], while [[Blaise Pascal]] became famous for his work on [[probability]] and [[fluid mechanics]]. They were both key figures of the [[Scientific revolution]], which erupted in Europe during this period. The [[French Academy of Sciences|Academy of Sciences]] was founded by [[Louis XIV]] to encourage and protect the spirit of [[French people|French]] [[Scientific method|scientific research]]. It was at the forefront of scientific developments in Europe in the 17th and 18th centuries. It is one of the earliest [[academy of sciences|academies of sciences]].

The [[Age of Enlightenment]] was marked by the work of biologist [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon|Buffon]] and chemist [[Antoine Lavoisier|Lavoisier]], who discovered the role of [[oxygen]] in [[combustion]], while [[Denis Diderot|Diderot]] and [[Jean le Rond d'Alembert|D'Alembert]] published the ''[[EncyclopÃ©die]]'', which aimed to give access to &quot;useful knowledge&quot; to the people, a knowledge that they can apply to their everyday life.&lt;ref&gt;Burke, Peter, A social history of knowledge: from Gutenberg to Diderot, Malden: Blackwell Publishers Inc., 2000, p.17&lt;/ref&gt;  With the [[Industrial Revolution]], the 19th century saw spectacular scientific developments in France with scientists such as [[Augustin Fresnel]], founder of modern [[optics]], [[Nicolas LÃ©onard Sadi Carnot|Sadi Carnot]] who laid the foundations of [[thermodynamics]], or [[Louis Pasteur]], a pioneer of [[microbiology]]. Other eminent French scientists of the 19th century have their [[List of the 72 names on the Eiffel Tower|names inscribed on the Eiffel Tower]].

Famous French scientists of the 20th century include the mathematician and physicist [[Henri PoincarÃ©]], physicists [[Henri Becquerel]], [[Pierre Curie|Pierre]] and [[Marie Curie]], remained famous for their work on [[radioactivity]], the physicist [[Paul Langevin]] or virologist [[Luc Montagnier]], co-discoverer of [[HIV AIDS]]. [[Hand transplantation]] was developed on 23 September 1998 in [[Lyon, France|Lyon]] by a team assembled from different countries around the world including [[Jean-Michel Dubernard]] who, shortly thereafter, performed the first successful double hand transplant.&lt;ref name =&quot;dubernard1&quot;&gt;{{cite journal |author=Lanzetta M |title=Second report (1998â€“2006) of the International Registry of Hand and Composite Tissue Transplantation |journal=Transpl Immunol. |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=1â€“6 |date=Jul 2007 |pmid=17584595 |doi=10.1016/j.trim.2007.03.002 |author2=Petruzzo P |author3=Dubernard JM |display-authors=3 |last4=Margreiter |first4=Raimund |last5=Schuind |first5=Frederic |last6=Breidenbach |first6=Warren |last7=Nolli |first7=Roberta |last8=Schneeberger |first8=Stephan |last9=Van Holder |first9=Carlo }}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Remote surgery|Telesurgery]] was developed by [[Jacques Marescaux]] and his team on 7 September 2001 across the Atlantic Ocean (New-York-Strasbourg, [[Lindbergh Operation]]).&lt;ref name=istmarescaux&gt;{{cite web|last=Ghodoussi|first=Dr.|title=Media Collection|url=http://www.intersurgtech.com/media.html|publisher=Interface Surgical Technologies, LLC|accessdate=14 November 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; A [[face transplant]] was first done on 27 November 2005&lt;ref name=&quot;titleBBC NEWS | Health | 'My face transplant saved me'&quot;&gt;{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/6058696.stm |title=  'My face transplant saved me' |accessdate=25 November 2007 |work= BBC News| date=17 October 2006 | first=Naomi | last=Austin}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4484728.stm|title=BBC NEWS&amp;nbsp;â€“ Health&amp;nbsp;â€“ Woman has first face transplant|work=bbc.co.uk}}&lt;/ref&gt; by Dr [[Bernard Devauchelle]].

France was the [[Force de dissuasion|fourth country to achieve nuclear capability]]&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JWF7eftCUQwC&amp;pg=PT120&amp;dq=france+quatri%C3%A8me+puissance+nucl%C3%A9aire&amp;hl=fr&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=eH9dVeujAoiPU8v_gPAG&amp;ved=0CDEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&amp;q=france%20quatri%C3%A8me%20puissance%20nucl%C3%A9aire&amp;f=false|title=Le monde nuclÃ©aire|work=google.fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; and has the [[List of states with nuclear weapons|third largest nuclear weapons arsenal]] in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/issues/nuclear-weapons/status-world-nuclear-forces/|title=Status of World Nuclear Forces|work=Federation Of American Scientists}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is also a leader in [[Nuclear power in France|civilian nuclear technology]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20080814/COLUMNISTS/808140356|title=Study France's Nuclear-Power Success|work=TheLedger.com}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://web.stanford.edu/group/sjir/pdf/Nuclear_11.2.pdf Stanford Journal of International Relations, &quot;The French Connection: Comparing French and American Civilian Nuclear Energy Programs&quot;]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/countries-generating-the-most-nuclear-energy-2014-3?op=1&amp;IR=T|title=Countries Generating The Most Nuclear Energy&amp;nbsp;â€“ Business Insider|date=6 March 2014|work=Business Insider}}&lt;/ref&gt; France was the third nation, after the former [[USSR]] and the [[United States]], to launch its [[Diamant|own space satellite]] and remains the biggest contributor to the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oEq1y9GIcr0C&amp;pg=PA322&amp;lpg=PA322&amp;dq=france+first+contributor+esa&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=W_JszWIDIo&amp;sig=68U_eqkmH_MhXw1juE3LMGeu7OE&amp;hl=fr&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=G_hdVf-ZCoGsUcaYgOgB&amp;ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&amp;q=france%20first%20contributor%20esa&amp;f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Astrobiology|work=google.fr}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/economics/the-space-economy-at-a-glance-2011/france_9789264113565-22-en;jsessionid=pgi7a3cfp7p2.x-oecd-live-03|title=France|work=oecd-ilibrary.org}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy-1/scientific-diplomacy/events-7867/article/france-at-the-heart-of-the-rosetta|title=France at the heart of the Rosetta space mission: a unique technological challenge|author=French Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development|publisher=France Diplomatie}}&lt;/ref&gt; The European [[Airbus Group]], formed from the French group [[AÃ©rospatiale]] along with [[DaimlerChrysler Aerospace]] AG (DASA) and [[Construcciones AeronÃ¡uticas SA]] (CASA), designs and develops civil and military aircraft as well as communications systems, missiles, space rockets, helicopters, satellites, and related systems. From 1970 [[SNCF]], the French national [[railroad]] company, has developed the [[TGV]], a high speed train which holds a series of [[Land speed record for railed vehicles#Conventional wheeled|world speed records]]. The TGV has been the fastest wheeled train in commercial use since reaching a speed of ''574.8&amp;nbsp;km/h (357.2&amp;nbsp;mph)'' on 3 April 2007.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6521295.stm|title=BBC NEWS&amp;nbsp;â€“ Europe&amp;nbsp;â€“ French set new rail speed record|work=bbc.co.uk}}&lt;/ref&gt; Western Europe is now serviced by a network of TGV lines.

{{As of|2014}}, [[List of Nobel laureates by country|67 French]] people have been awarded a [[Nobel Prize]]&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/lists/all/ |title=All Nobel Prizes |publisher=Nobel Media |accessdate=10 October 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; and 12 have received the [[Fields Medal]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/fields/prizewinners/ |title=List of Fields Medallists |publisher=International Mathematical Union |accessdate=10 October 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Demographics==
{{Main article|Demographics of France|French people}}
[[File:France population density 40pc.png|thumb|alt=map of population in France|Population density in the French Republic at the 1999 census.]]

With an estimated total population of around 66.6 million people as of January 2016,&lt;ref name=populationINSEE /&gt; with 64.5 million in metropolitan France,&lt;ref name=metropolitanINSEE&gt;{{cite web|title=Population totale par sexe et Ã¢ge au 1er janvier 2016, France mÃ©tropolitaine|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/detail.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=bilan-demo&amp;page=donnees-detaillees/bilan-demo/pop_age2.htm|website=Insee.fr|publisher=Institut national de la statistique et des Ã©tudes Ã©conomiques|accessdate=22 January 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt; France is the [[List of countries by population#List|20th most populous country in the world]] and the third-most populous in Europe.

France is an outlier among developed countries in general, and European countries in particular, in having a fairly high rate of natural population growth: by birth rates alone, France was responsible for almost all natural population growth in the European Union in 2006, with the natural growth rate (excess of births over deaths) rising to 300,000.&lt;ref name=evol&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/detail.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=bilan-demo&amp;page=donnees-detaillees/bilan-demo/pop_age3.htm#evol-gen-sit-demo-fe|title=Ã‰volution gÃ©nÃ©rale de la situation dÃ©mographique, France|first=Government of France|last=INSEE|accessdate=20 January 2011|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; This was the highest rate since the end of the [[baby boom]] in 1973, and coincides with the rise of the [[total fertility rate]] from a nadir of 1.7 in 1994 to 2.0 in 2010.&lt;ref name=population&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/document.asp?ref_id=ip1332|title=Bilan dÃ©mographique 2010|first=[[Cabinet of France|Government of France]]|last=[[INSEE]]|accessdate=20 January 2011|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/ppp/bases-de-donnees/irweb/sd2008/dd/excel/sd2008_t44_fe.xls|title=Tableau 44&amp;nbsp;â€“ Taux de fÃ©conditÃ© gÃ©nÃ©rale par Ã¢ge de la mÃ¨re|first=Government of France|last=INSEE|accessdate=20 January 2011|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt;

From 2006 to 2011 population growth was on average +0.6% per year.&lt;ref name=evol /&gt; Immigrants are also major contributors to this trend; in 2010, 27% of newborns in metropolitan France had at least one [[Immigration to France#Immigration per region|foreign-born]] parent and 24% had at least one parent born outside of Europe (parents born in overseas territories are considered as born in France).&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/detail.asp?ref_id=ir-sd20101 |title=Naissances selon le pays de naissance des parents 2010 |publisher=Insee.fr |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Ethnic groups===
Most [[French people]] are of [[Celtic peoples|Celtic]] ([[Gauls]]) origin, with an admixture of [[Latin peoples|Latin]] ([[Roman Empire|Romans]]) and [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] ([[Franks]]) groups.&lt;ref&gt;Jean-Louis Brunaux, Nos ancÃªtres les Gaulois, Ã©d. Seuil, 2008, p. 261&quot;&lt;/ref&gt; Different regions reflect this diverse heritage, with notable [[Bretons|Breton]] elements in western France, [[Aquitani]]an in the southwest, [[Scandinavia]]n in the northwest, [[Alemanni]]c in the northeast and [[Ligures|Ligurian]] influence in the southeast.

Large-scale [[immigration]] over the last century and a half has led to a more multicultural society. In 2004, the Institut Montaigne estimated that within Metropolitan France, 51 million people were White (85% of the population), 6 million were North African (10%), 2 million were Black (3.3%), and 1 million were Asian (1.7%).&lt;ref&gt;[[Yazid Sabeg]] et Laurence MÃ©haignerie, [http://www.conventioncitoyenne.com/documents/oubliesdelegalite.pdf Les oubliÃ©s de l'Ã©galitÃ© des chances], [[Institut Montaigne]], January 2004&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/13377324 |title=France's ethnic minorities: To count or not to count |publisher=The Economist |date=26 March 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

A law originating from the 1789 revolution and reaffirmed in the 1958 [[French Constitution]] makes it illegal for the French state to collect data on ethnicity and ancestry. In 2008, the TeO (&quot;Trajectories and origins&quot;) poll conducted jointly by [[INED]] and [[INSEE|the French National Institute of Statistics]]&lt;ref&gt;[http://teo_english.site.ined.fr/ &quot;TRAJECTORIES AND ORIGINS&quot; Survey on population diversity in France], Insee 2008&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Oppenheimer&quot;&gt;{{cite journal |last=Oppenheimer |first=David B. |year=2008| title=Why France needs to collect data on racial identity...in a French way |journal=Hastings International and Comparative Law Review |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=735â€“752 |url=http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1236362}}&lt;/ref&gt; estimated that 5 million people were of [[Italians in France|Italian]] ancestry (the largest immigrant community), followed by 3 million&lt;ref name=&quot;Cohen1995&quot;&gt;{{cite book|author=Robin Cohen|title=The Cambridge Survey of World Migration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YbzsBPuhyggC|date=2 November 1995|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-44405-7}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/frances-crisis-of-national-identity-1826942.html |location=London |work=The Independent | title=France's crisis of national identity | date=25 November 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; to 6 million&lt;ref&gt;&quot;Les personnes d'origine maghrÃ©bine y sont Ã©galement au nombre de 5 Ã  6 millions; 3,5 millions ont la nationalitÃ© franÃ§aise (don't 500 000 harkis)&quot;, Ã‰velyne Perrin, ''IdentitÃ© Nationale, Amer MinistÃ¨re'', L'Harmattan, 2010, p. 112 ISBN 2-296-10839-3&lt;/ref&gt; people of [[Mahgreb|North African]] ancestry, 2.5 million people of [[Afro-French|Sub-Saharan African]] origin, and 200,000 people of [[Turks in France|Turkish]] ancestry.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=Falila Gbadamassi |url=http://www.afrik.com/article16248.html |title=Les personnes originaires d'Afrique, des Dom-Tom et de la Turquie sont 5,5 millions dans l'Hexagone |publisher=Afrik.com |date= |accessdate=30 September 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are also sizeable minorities of other [[European ethnic groups]], namely [[Spaniards|Spanish]], [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]], [[Romani people in France|Romani]], [[Poles|Polish]], and [[Greeks|Greek]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Cohen1995&quot; /&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = Europe's Minority Politicians in Short Supply
 | first = Keith B.
 | last = Richburg
 | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A12396-2005Apr23.html
 | newspaper=The Washington Post

 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = In officially colorblind France, blacks have a dream&amp;nbsp;â€“ and now a lobby

 | newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor
 | location = Boston
 | date = 12 January 2007
 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

It is currently estimated that 40% of the French population is descended at least partially from the different waves of immigration the country has received since the early 20th century;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = Paris Riots in Perspective
 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=1280843
 | publisher=ABC News
 | location = New York
 | date = 4 November 2005
 }}&lt;/ref&gt; between 1921 and 1935 alone, about 1.1 million net immigrants came to France.&lt;ref&gt;&quot;''[https://books.google.com/books?id=uUsLAAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA22 Transactions of the American Philosophical Society. III. French Government and the Refugees]''&quot;. American Philosophical Society, James E. Hassell (1991). p. 22. ISBN 0-87169-817-X&lt;/ref&gt; The next largest wave came in the 1960s, when around 1.6&amp;nbsp;million ''[[pieds noirs]]'' returned to France following the independence of its North African possessions, [[Algeria]] and [[Morocco]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = For Pieds-Noirs, the Anger Endures
 | first = James M.
 | last = Markham
 | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DEFDE1539F935A35757C0A96E948260&amp;sec=&amp;spon=&amp;pagewanted=all
 | newspaper=The New York Times
 | date = 6 April 1988
 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;Raimondo Cagiano De Azevedo (1994). ''&quot;[https://books.google.com/books?id=N8VHizsqaH0C&amp;pg=PA25 Migration and development co-operation.]&quot;''. p. 25.&lt;/ref&gt; They were joined by numerous former colonial subjects from North and West Africa, as well as numerous immigrants from Spain and Portugal.

France remains a major destination for immigrants, accepting about 200,000 legal immigrants annually.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.ined.fr/fr/pop_chiffres/france/flux_immigration/depuis_1994/ Statistiques dÃ©taillÃ©es sur les flux d'immigration], Ined, 2011 {{wayback|url=http://www.ined.fr/fr/pop_chiffres/france/flux_immigration/depuis_1994/ |date=20120523053018 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; It is also Western Europe's leading recipient of [[refugee|asylum]] seekers, with an estimated 50,000 applications in 2005 (a 15% decrease from 2004).&lt;ref name=&quot;UNHCR&quot;&gt;{{cite web |publisher=[[UNHCR]] |year=2006 |url=http://www.unhcr.org/publ/PUBL/4492677f0.pdf |title=UNHCR Global Report 2005: Western Europe |accessdate=14 December 2006 |format=PDF}}&lt;/ref&gt; The European Union allows free movement between the member states, although France established controls to curb [[Eastern European]] migration, and immigration remains a contentious political issue.

In 2008, the [[INSEE]] estimated that the total number of foreign-born immigrants was around 5 million (8% of the population), while their French-born descendants numbered 6.5 million, or 11% of the population. Thus, nearly a fifth of the country's population were either first or second-generation immigrants, of which more than 5 million where of European origin and 4 million of [[Maghrebis|Maghrebi]] ancestry.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/document.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=ip1287 ÃŠtre nÃ© en France d'un parent immigrÃ©], [[Insee PremiÃ¨re]], nÂ°1287, mars 2010, Catherine Borrel et Bertrand Lhommeau, Insee&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Insee_1&quot;&gt;[http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/tableau.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=immigrespaysnais RÃ©partition des immigrÃ©s par pays de naissance 2008], Insee, October 2011&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;INSEE1&quot;&gt;{{cite web |author=INSEE |url=http://www.insee.fr/fr/ffc/ipweb/ip1098/ip1098.html#encadre1 |title=EnquÃªtes annuelles de recensement 2004 et 2005 |date=25 January 2005|accessdate=14 December 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061212212050/http%3A//www.insee.fr/fr/ffc/ipweb/ip1098/ip1098.html#encadre1 |archivedate = 12 December 2006|deadurl=yes|language=fr}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2008, France granted citizenship to 137,000 persons, mostly to people from Morocco, Algeria and Turkey.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news
 | title = Turks and Moroccans top list of new EU citizens
 | first = Andrea
 | last = Swalec
 | url = http://in.reuters.com/article/2010/07/06/idINIndia-49921620100706
 | agency=Reuters
 | date = 6 July 2010
 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2014 The National Institute of Statistics (INSEE, for its acronym in French) published a study which reported doubling of the number of Spanish immigrants, Portuguese and Italians in France between 2009 and 2012.
