According to the French Institute, this increase resulting from the financial crisis that hit several European countries in that period, has pushed up the number of Europeans installed in France.&lt;ref name=&quot;sudouest.fr&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.sudouest.fr/2014/11/28/qui-sont-les-nouveaux-immigres-qui-vivent-en-france-1751452-705.php|title=Qui sont les nouveaux immigrÃ©s qui vivent en France ?|work=SudOuest.fr}}&lt;/ref&gt;
Statistics on Spanish immigrants in France show a growth of 107 percent between 2009 and 2012, i.e. in this period went from 5300 to 11,000 people.&lt;ref name=&quot;sudouest.fr&quot; /&gt;
Of the total of 229,000 foreigners who were in France in 2012, nearly 8% were Portuguese, 5% British, 5% Spanish, 4% Italians, 4% Germans, 3% Romanians, and 3% Belgians.&lt;ref name=&quot;sudouest.fr&quot; /&gt;

===Major cities===
France is a highly urbanized country, with its [[List of cities in France over 20,000 population (1999 census)|largest cities]] (in terms of metropolitan area population in 2013&lt;ref&gt;http://www.pss-archi.eu/aires_urbaines.html&lt;/ref&gt;) being Paris (12,405,426 inh.), [[Lyon]] (2,237,676), [[Marseille]] (1,734,277), [[Toulouse]] (1,291,517), [[Bordeaux]] (1,178,335), [[Lille]] (1,175,828), [[Nice]] (1,004,826), [[Nantes]] (908,815), [[Strasbourg]] (773,447) and [[Rennes]] (700,675). (Note: There are significant differences between the metropolitan population figures just cited and those in the following table, which only include the core population). [[Rural flight]] was a perennial political issue throughout most of the 20th century.

{{Largest cities of France}}

===Language===
{{Main article|French language|Languages of France|Organisation internationale de la Francophonie}}

[[File:New-Map-Francophone World.PNG|thumb|350px|alt=world map of French speaking countries|A map of the [[List of territorial entities where French is an official language|Francophone]] world
{{legend|#0c5eb1|native language}}
{{legend|#0080ff|administrative language}}
{{legend|#9fceff|secondary or non-official language}}
{{legend|#00ff00|francophone minorities}}]]
According to Article 2 of the Constitution, the official language of France is French,&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110604145028/http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/html/constitution/constitution2.htm#titre2 La Constitution- La Constitution du 4 Octobre 1958]&amp;nbsp;â€“ LÃ©gifrance&lt;/ref&gt; a [[Romance language]] derived from [[Latin]]. Since 1635, the [[AcadÃ©mie franÃ§aise]] has been France's official authority on the French language, although its recommendations carry no legal power.

The French government does not regulate the choice of language in publications by individuals but the use of French is required by law in commercial and workplace communications. In addition to mandating the use of French in the territory of the Republic, the French government tries to promote French in the European Union and globally through institutions such as [[La Francophonie]]. The perceived threat from [[anglicisation]] has prompted efforts to safeguard the position of the French language in France. Besides French, there exist 77 vernacular minority languages of France, eight spoken in French metropolitan territory and 69 in the French [[Overseas departments and territories of France|overseas territories]].

From the 17th to the mid-20th century, French served as the pre-eminent international language of diplomacy and international affairs as well as a [[lingua franca]] among the educated classes of Europe.&lt;ref name=exception&gt;Joffre Agnes [http://www.franceinlondon.com/en-Article-335-Is-the-French-obsession-with-cultural-exception-declining-Culture--london-language.html ls the French obsession with &quot;cultural exception&quot; declining?]. France in London. 5 October 2008&lt;/ref&gt; The dominant position of French language in international affairs was overtaken by English, since the emergence of the US as a major power.&lt;ref name=&quot;Language and Diplomacy&quot; /&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomacy.edu/language/Translation/default.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719183516/http://www.diplomacy.edu/language/Translation/default.htm |archivedate=19 July 2011 |title=Language and Diplomacy&amp;nbsp;â€“ Translation and Interpretation |publisher=Diplomacy.edu |accessdate=10 September 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.legallanguage.com/legal-articles/language-of-diplomacy/ |title=Why Is French Considered the Language of Diplomacy? |publisher=Legallanguage.com |accessdate=23 January 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

For most of the time in which French served as an international lingua franca, it was not the native language of most Frenchmen: a report in 1794 conducted by [[Henri GrÃ©goire]] found that of the country's 25 million people, only three million spoke French natively; the rest spoke one of the country's many regional languages, such as [[Alsatian language|Alsatian]], [[Breton language|Breton]] or [[Occitan language|Occitan]].&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.languefrancaise.net/dossiers/dossiers.php?id_dossier=66 Rapport GrÃ©goire an II] {{wayback|url=http://www.languefrancaise.net/dossiers/dossiers.php?id_dossier=66 |date=20080405022802 |df=y }}&lt;/ref&gt; Through the expansion of public education, in which French was the sole language of instruction, as well as other factors such as increased urbanization and the rise of mass communication, French gradually came to be adopted by virtually the entire population, a process not completed until the 20th century.

As a result of France's extensive [[French colonial empire|colonial ambitions]] between the 17th and 20th centuries, French was introduced to the Americas, Africa, Polynesia, South-East Asia, and the Caribbean. French is the second most studied foreign language in the world after English,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.intstudy.com/articles/practicalfrench.htm |title=The International Education Site |publisher=Intstudy.com |accessdate=23 January 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is a lingua franca in some regions, notably in Africa. The legacy of French as a living language outside Europe is mixed: it is nearly extinct in some former French colonies (The Levant, South and Southeast Asia), while creoles and pidgins based on French have emerged in the French departments in the [[West Indies]] and the South Pacific ([[French Polynesia]]). On the other hand, many former French colonies have adopted French as an official language, and the total number of French speakers is increasing, especially in Africa.

It is estimated that between 300 million&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://about-france.com/french/french-language.htm |title=French: one of the world's main languages |publisher=About-france.com |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and 500 million&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.tlfq.ulaval.ca/axl/francophonie/francophonie.htm Qu'est-ce que la Francophonie ?]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]]&lt;/ref&gt; people worldwide can speak French, either as a [[mother tongue]] or a [[second language]].

===Religion===
{{Main article|Religion in France}}
[[File:Facade de la CathÃ©drale de Reims - Parvis.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Notre-Dame de Reims facade, gothic stone cathedral against blue sky|[[Notre-Dame de Reims]] is the Roman Catholic cathedral where the [[Coronation of the French monarch|kings of France were crowned]] until 1825.&lt;ref name=&quot;auto&quot;&gt;The last ''sacre'' was that of [[Charles X of France|Charles X]], 29 May 1825.&lt;/ref&gt;]] France is a [[secular]] country, and [[freedom of religion]] is a constitutional right. French religious policy is based on the concept of ''[[laÃ¯citÃ©]]'', a strict [[separation of church and state]] under which public life is kept completely secular.

[[Catholicism]] has been the predominant religion in France for more than a millennium, though it is not as actively practised today as it was. Among the 47,000 religious buildings in France, 94% are [[Roman Catholic]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Observatoire du patrimoine religieux|url=http://www.patrimoine-religieux.fr/rubriques/gauche/actualites/actualites-de-la-base-de-donnees|date=1 February 2012|quote=94 % des Ã©difices sont catholiques (dont 50 % Ã©glises paroissiales, 25 % chapelles, 25 % Ã©difices appartenant au clergÃ© rÃ©gulier)}}&lt;/ref&gt; While in 1965, 81% of the French declared themselves to be Catholics, in 2009 this proportion was 64%. Moreover, while 27% of the French went to Mass once a week or more in 1952, only 5% did so in 2006.&lt;ref name=catho&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.la-croix.com/Religion/S-informer/Actualite/La-France-reste-catholique-mais-moins-pratiquante-_NG_-2009-12-29-570979 La France reste catholique mais moins pratiquante]&amp;nbsp;â€“ La Croix. 29 December 2009&lt;/ref&gt; The same survey found that [[Protestantism|Protestants]] accounted for 3% of the population, an increase from previous surveys, and 5% adhered to other religions, with the remaining 28% stating they had no religion.&lt;ref name=catho /&gt; [[Evangelical Protestantism]] may be the fastest growing religion in France.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=Robert Marquand |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/2012/0712/In-a-France-suspicious-of-religion-evangelicalism-s-message-strikes-a-chord |title=In a France suspicious of religion, evangelicalism's message strikes a chord|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=25 April 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The [[French Revolution]] saw a radical shift in the status of the Catholic Church with the launch of a brutal [[Dechristianisation of France during the French Revolution|campaign of de-Christianization]]. After the back and forth of Catholic royal and secular republican governments over the 19th century, ''laÃ¯citÃ©'' was established with the [[1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State|1905 law on the Separation of the Churches and the State]].&lt;ref name=&quot;georgetown2&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/countries/france |title=France |publisher=[[Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs]] |accessdate=14 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20110206213909/http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu:80/resources/countries/france |archivedate=6 February 2011 }}&lt;/ref&gt;

According to a poll in January 2007,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |author=Catholic World News |year=2003 |url=http://www.catholicculture.org/news/features/index.cfm?recnum=48547 |title=France is no longer Catholic, survey shows |accessdate=19 December 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; only 5% of the French population attended church regularly (10% attend church services regularly among the respondents who did identify themselves as Catholics). The poll showed&lt;ref name=&quot;religion&quot;&gt;{{ro icon}} [http://old.cotidianul.ro/franta_nu_mai_e_o_tara_catolica-20395.html FranÅ£a nu mai e o Å£arÄƒ catolicÄƒ], ''[[Cotidianul]]'' 11 January 2007&lt;/ref&gt; 51% identified as being Catholics, 31% identified as being agnostics or [[atheism|atheists]] ''(another poll&lt;ref&gt;La Vie, issue 3209, 1 March 2007 {{fr icon}}&lt;/ref&gt; sets the proportion of atheists equal to 27%)'', 10% identified as being from other religions or being without opinion, 4% identified as Muslim, 3% identified as Protestant, 1% identified as [[Buddhism|Buddhist]], 1% identified as Jewish. Meanwhile, an independent estimate by the politologist Pierre BrÃ©chon in 2009 concluded that the proportion of Catholics had fallen to 42% while the number of atheists and agnostics had risen to 50%.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.la-croix.com.prd-jsp.bayardweb.com/documents/doc.jsp?docId=2389007&amp;rubId=786 |title=&quot; Sur la religion, les FranÃ§ais restent dubitatifs &quot;&amp;nbsp;â€“ A la Une |work=La Croix |location=France |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; According to [[Eurobarometer]] poll in 2012 [[Christianity]] is the largest religion in France accounting 60% of French citizens.&lt;ref name=EUROBAROMETER&gt;{{citation|title=Discrimination in the EU in 2012|work=[[Eurobarometer|Special Eurobarometer]] |year=2012 |series=383 |page=233 |url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_393_en.pdf |accessdate=14 August 2013 |publisher=[[European Commission]] |location=[[European Union]]}} The question asked was &quot;Do you consider yourself to be...?&quot; With a card showing: Catholic, Orthodox, Protestant, Other Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Sikh, Buddhist, Hindu, Atheist, and Non-believer/Agnostic.  Space was given for Other (SPONTANEOUS) and DK. Jewish, Sikh, Buddhist, Hindu did not reach the 1% threshold.&lt;/ref&gt; [[Catholics]] are the largest [[Christian]] group in France, accounting for 50% of French citizens,&lt;ref name=&quot;EUROBAROMETER&quot; /&gt; while [[Protestant]]s make up 8%, and Other Christian make up 2%. [[Agnostic|Non believer/Agnostic]] account 20%, [[Atheist]] account's 13%, and [[Muslim]] 6%.&lt;ref name=&quot;EUROBAROMETER&quot; /&gt;

Estimates of the number of [[Islam in France|Muslims in France]] vary widely. In 2003, the French Ministry of the Interior estimated the total number of people of Muslim background to be between 5 and 6 million (8â€“10%).&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/apr/23/france.islam France to train imams in 'French Islam'], The Guardian&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51552.htm |title=France&amp;nbsp;â€“ International Religious Freedom Report 2005 |publisher=State.gov |accessdate=30 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; According to the Pewforum, &quot;In France, proponents of a 2004 law banning the wearing of religious symbols in schools say it protects Muslim girls from being forced to wear a headscarf, but the law also restricts those who want to wear headscarves&amp;nbsp;â€“ or any other &quot;conspicuous&quot; religious symbol, including large Christian crosses and Sikh turbans&amp;nbsp;â€“ as an expression of their faith&quot;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://pewforum.org/uploadedFiles/Topics/Issues/Government/restrictions-fullreport.pdf |title=Global Restrictions on Religion. Pew Forum on Religion &amp; Public Life. Washington. 2009 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=1 October 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The current [[Jews in France|Jewish community in France]] numbers around 600,000 according to the [[World Jewish Congress]] and is the largest in Europe.

Since 1905 the French government has followed the principle of ''[[laÃ¯citÃ©]]'', in which it is prohibited from recognising any specific right to a religious community (except for legacy statutes like that of military chaplains and the [[local law in Alsace-Moselle]]). Instead, it merely recognises ''religious organisations'', according to formal legal criteria that do not address religious doctrine. Conversely, religious organizations should refrain from intervening in policy-making.&lt;ref&gt;Joy of Sects, Sam Jordison, 2006, p. 166&lt;/ref&gt; Certain bodies of beliefs such as [[Scientology]], [[Children of God (New Religious Movement)|Children of God]], the [[Unification Church]], or the [[Order of the Solar Temple]] are considered [[cult]]s (&quot;''[[sect#Corresponding words in other European languages|sectes]]''&quot; in French),&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/rap-enq/r2468.asp |title=Commission d'enquÃªte sur les sectes |publisher=Assemblee-nationale.fr |accessdate=30 October 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and therefore do not have the same status as religions in France. ''Secte'' is considered a pejorative term in France.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.understandfrance.org/France/Society2.html |title=Society2 ; religion in France ; beliefs ; secularism (laicitÃ©) |publisher=Understandfrance.org |accessdate=20 September 2009}}{{Self-published source|date=June 2016}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Health===
{{Main article|Health in France}}
[[File:P1000513 Paris XIII SalpetriÃ¨re reductwk.JPG|thumb|220px|alt=PitiÃ©-SalpÃªtriÃ¨re Hospital in Paris, stone building with slate dome|The [[PitiÃ©-SalpÃªtriÃ¨re Hospital]], a teaching hospital in Paris, one of Europe's largest hospitals.&lt;ref&gt;[https://web.archive.org/web/20070117112822/http://www.paris-region.com/ard_uk/upload/document/D176.pdf How to conduct European clinical trials from the Paris Region ?] Clinical Trials. Paris. February 2003&lt;/ref&gt;]]
The [[Health in France|French health care system]] is one of [[universal health care]] largely financed by government [[national health insurance]]. In its 2000 assessment of world health care systems, the [[World Health Organization]] found that France provided the &quot;close to best overall health care&quot; in the world.&lt;ref name=&quot;who.int&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/whr/2000/media_centre/press_release/en/ |title=World Health Organization Assesses the World's Health Systems |publisher=Who.int |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=6 January 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; The French healthcare system was ranked first worldwide by the World Health Organization in 1997.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.photius.com/rankings/healthranks.html The ranking, see spreadsheet details for a whole analysis] photius.com&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/healthinfo/paper30.pdf |title=Measuring Overall Health System Performance for 191 Countries |format=PDF |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2011, France spent 11.6% of [[GDP]] on health care, or US$4,086 per capita,&lt;ref name=&quot;WHO country facts: France&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/countries/fra/en/ |title=WHO country facts: France |publisher=Who.int |accessdate=11 November 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; a figure much higher than the average spent by countries in Europe but [[Health care compared#International comparisons|less than in the US]]. Approximately 77% of health expenditures are covered by government funded agencies.&lt;ref&gt;The World Health Report 2000: WHO&lt;/ref&gt;

Care is generally free for people affected by [[chronic disease]]s (''affections de longues durÃ©es'') such as cancer, AIDS or [[Cystic Fibrosis]]. Average life expectancy at birth is 78 years for men and 85 years for women, one of the highest of the European Union.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/tableau.asp?reg_id=98&amp;ref_id=CMPTEF02216 EspÃ©rance de vie, taux de mortalitÃ© et taux de mortalitÃ© infantile dans le monde], [http://www.insee.fr/fr/themes/tableau.asp?reg_id=0&amp;ref_id=NATnon02229 Evolution de l'espÃ©rance de vie Ã  divers Ã¢ges]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [[INSEE]]&lt;/ref&gt; There are 3.22 physicians for every 1000 inhabitants in France,&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.statistiques-mondiales.com/medecins.htm Nombre de mÃ©decins pour 1000 habitants]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Statistiques mondiales&lt;/ref&gt; and average health care spending per capita was US$4,719 in 2008.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.statistiques-mondiales.com/sante.htm DÃ©penses de santÃ© par habitants]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Statistiques mondiales&lt;/ref&gt;
{{As of|2007}}, approximately 140,000 inhabitants (0.4%) of France are living with HIV/AIDS.&lt;ref name =France /&gt;

Even if the [[Frenchmen|French]] have the reputation of being one of the thinnest people in developed countries,&lt;ref name = obesity&gt;[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/03/world/europe/03iht-obese.html Even the French are fighting obesity]&amp;nbsp;â€“ The NY Times&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=daily&gt;{{cite web|last=Wahlgren |first=Eric |url=http://www.dailyfinance.com/2009/11/14/frances-obesity-crisis-all-those-croissants-really-do-add-up/|date=14 November 2009 |title=France's obesity crisis: All those croissants really do add up, after all |publisher=Dailyfinance.com |accessdate=21 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name = Telegraph&gt;{{cite news|last=Lambert |first=Victoria |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/dietandfitness/3353715/The-French-children-learning-to-fight-obesity.html |title=The French children learning to fight obesity |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2010 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name = bloomberg&gt;[http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/jul2001/nf2001073_981.htm Why So Few French Are Fat]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Bloomberg Businessweek&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author=Mimi Spencer |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2004/nov/07/foodanddrink.features11 |title=Let them eat cake |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 7 November 2004|accessdate=21 July 2011 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.streetdirectory.com/travel_guide/24041/e_diet/the_french_diet___eat_drink_and_be_thin.html |title=The French Diet - Eat, Drink, and be Thin|publisher=Streetdirectory.com |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
Franceâ€”like other rich countriesâ€”faces an increasing and recent epidemic of [[obesity]], due mostly to the replacement of traditional healthy French cuisine by [[junk food]] in French eating habits.&lt;ref name=obesity /&gt;&lt;ref name=daily /&gt;&lt;ref name = obesity2&gt;[http://www.foodnavigator.com/Science-Nutrition/France-heading-for-US-obesity-levels-says-study France heading for US obesity levels says study]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Food Navigator&lt;/ref&gt; Nevertheless, the French obesity rate is far below that of the USA (for instance, obesity rate in France is the same that the American once was in the 1970s&lt;ref name = daily /&gt;), and is still the lowest of Europe,&lt;ref name = bloomberg /&gt;&lt;ref name = obesity2 /&gt; but it is now regarded by the authorities as one of the main public health issues&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.nutraingredients.com/Regulation/New-French-food-guidelines-aimed-at-tackling-obesity |title=New French food guidelines aimed at tackling obesity |publisher=Nutraingredients.com|date=14 September 2006 |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is fiercely fought; rates of childhood obesity are slowing in France, while continuing to grow in other countries.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=Petah Marian |url=http://www.just-food.com/analysis/france-urged-to-get-tough-on-child-obesity_id102509.aspx |title=France urged to get tough on child obesity |publisher=Just-food.com |date=23 May 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Education===
{{Main article|Education in France}}

[[File:Absolute BNUS 01.JPG|thumb|alt=BibliothÃ¨que nationale et universitaire at Strasbourg, stone building with portico by a park|The [[BibliothÃ¨que nationale et universitaire|National and University Library]] on the campus of the [[University of Strasbourg]].]]

In 1802, [[Napoleon]] created the [[lycÃ©e]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/352505/lycee |title=LycÃ©e |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nevertheless, it is [[Jules Ferry]] who is considered to be the father of the French modern school, which is free, secular, and compulsory until the age of 13 since 1882&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110605080546/http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/site-jeunes/laicite/fiche-dates/fiche-1881-1882/fiche.pdf 1881â€“1882 : Lois Ferry Ã‰cole publique gratuite, laÃ¯que et obligatoire]. AssemblÃ© Nationale&lt;/ref&gt; (school attendance in France is now compulsory until the age of 16&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.senat.fr/rap/l97-504/l97-5041.html II. L'Ã©volution du contenu de l'obligation scolaire]. SÃ©nat.fr&lt;/ref&gt;).

Nowadays, the schooling system in France is centralized, and is composed of three stages, primary education, secondary education, and higher education. The [[Programme for International Student Assessment]], coordinated by the [[OECD]], currently ranks France's education as the 25th best in the world, being neither significantly higher nor lower than the OECD average.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/42/8/39700724.pdf |title=Range of rank on the PISA 2006 science scale |format=PDF |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Primary and secondary education are predominantly public, run by the [[Minister of National Education (France)|Ministry of National Education]]. In France, education is compulsory from six to sixteen years old, and the public school is secular and free. If training and remuneration of teachers, and the choice of programs, are the state spring, the management of primary and secondary schools is the responsibility of local authorities. Primary education is made in two phases. The nursery school, which  welcome very young children  has as a main goal their awakening, their socialisation and the development of basic tools that are the language and the number. Then, around the age of six,  children are greeted by elementary school, whose primary objectives are: learning, writing, arithmetic and civics. Secondary education also takes place in two cycles. The first is offered to college and leads to the national certificate ({{ill|fr|DiplÃ´me national du brevet}}). The second is offered in high school and results in national exams and ends (the bachelor professional, technical or general) and the Certificate of Professional Competence (CAPA in agricultural education).

[[Education in France#Higher education|Higher education in France]] is divided between [[Universities in France|public universities]] and the prestigious and selective ''[[Grandes Ã©coles]]'', such as [[Sciences Po Paris]] for Political studies, [[HEC Paris]] for Economics, [[Polytechnique]] and the [[Ã‰cole nationale supÃ©rieure des mines de Paris]] that produces high-profile engineers, or the [[Ã‰cole nationale d'administration]] for careers in the great corps of the State. The ''Grandes Ã©coles'' have been criticised for alleged [[elitism]],&lt;ref name=&quot;gÃ©coles&quot;&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.lefigaro.fr/formation/2010/01/08/01015-20100108ARTFIG00525-les-grandes-ecoles-dans-la-tourmente-.php Les grandes Ã©coles dans la tourmente]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [[Le Figaro]]&lt;/ref&gt; nevertheless they have produced many if not most of France's high-ranking civil servants, CEOs, and politicians.

Since higher education is funded by the state, the fees are very low; the tuition varies from â‚¬150 to â‚¬700 depending on the university and the different levels of education. (''licence, master, doctorate''). One can therefore get a master's degree (in 5 years) for about â‚¬750â€“3,500. The tuition in public engineering schools is comparable to universities, albeit a little higher (around â‚¬700). However it can reach â‚¬7000 a year for private engineering schools, and some business schools, which are all private or partially private, charge up to â‚¬15000 a year. Health insurance for students is free until the age of 20.

==Culture==
{{Main article|Culture of France}}
[[File:ChÃ¢teau de Chenonceau - west view from Catherine de Medici Gardens 1a (4 May 2006).JPG|thumb|alt=ChÃ¢teau de Chenonceau in the Loire valley, the castle that spans the river with a round keep, and garden|[[ChÃ¢teau de Chenonceau]] in the [[Loire valley]]]]
France has been a center of Western cultural development for centuries. Many French artists have been among the most renowned of their time, and France is still recognized in the world for its rich cultural tradition.

The successive political regimes have always promoted artistic creation, and the creation of the [[Minister of Culture (France)|Ministry of Culture]] in 1959 helped preserve the cultural heritage of the country and make it available to the public. The Ministry of Culture has been very active since its creation, granting subsidies to artists, promoting French culture in the world, supporting festivals and cultural events, protecting [[Monument historique|historical monuments]]. The French government also succeeded in maintaining a [[cultural exception]] to defend audiovisual products made in the country.

France receives the highest number of tourists per year, largely thanks to the numerous cultural establishments and historical buildings implanted all over the territory. It counts 1,200 [[List of museums in France|museums]] welcoming more than 50&amp;nbsp;million people annually.&lt;ref&gt;MinistÃ¨re de la Culture et de la Communication, &quot;Cultura statistics&quot;, [http://www2.culture.gouv.fr/culture/deps/2008/pdf/minichiffrescles2010-en.pdf Key figures]&lt;/ref&gt; The most important cultural sites are run by the government, for instance through the public agency [[Centre des monuments nationaux]], which is responsible for approximately 85 national historical monuments.

The 43,180 buildings protected as historical monuments include mainly residences (many [[List of castles in France|castles]], or ''[[chÃ¢teau]]x'' in French) and religious buildings ([[List of cathedrals in France|cathedrals]], [[List of basilicas in France|basilicas]], churches, etc.), but also statutes, memorials and [[Gardens of France|gardens]]. The [[UNESCO]] inscribed 41 sites in [[Table of World Heritage Sites by country|France on the World Heritage List]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/fr|title=Official properties inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in France |publisher=Whc.unesco.org |accessdate=9 July 2015}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Art===
{{Main article|French art}}
[[File:Claude Monet 023.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=painting by Claude Monet of woman with parasol facing left in field from the MusÃ©e d'Orsay|[[Claude Monet]] founded the [[Impressionist]] movement (''Femme avec un parasol'', 1886, [[MusÃ©e d'Orsay]]).]]

The origins of French art were very much influenced by [[Flemish art]] and by [[Italian art]] at the time of the Renaissance. [[Jean Fouquet]], the most famous medieval French painter, is said to have been the first to travel to Italy and experience the Early Renaissance at first hand. The Renaissance painting [[School of Fontainebleau]] was directly inspired by Italian painters such as [[Primaticcio]] and [[Rosso Fiorentino]], who both worked in France. Two of the most famous French artists of the time of [[Baroque era]], [[Nicolas Poussin]] and [[Claude Lorrain]], lived in Italy.

The 17th century was the period when French painting became prominent and individualized itself through classicism. Louis XIV's prime minister [[Jean-Baptiste Colbert]] founded in 1648 the [[Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture]] to protect these artists, and in 1666 he created the still-active [[French Academy in Rome]] to have direct relations with Italian artists.

[[File:LE PENSEUR - Museo Rodin- PARIS.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=The Thinker bronze statue from 1902 from the MusÃ©e Rodin, Paris|''[[The Thinker|Le Penseur]]'' by [[Auguste Rodin]] (1902), [[MusÃ©e Rodin]], Paris.]]

French artists developed the [[rococo]] style in the 18th century, as a more intimate imitation of old baroque style, the works of the court-endorsed artists [[Antoine Watteau]], [[FranÃ§ois Boucher]] and [[Jean-HonorÃ© Fragonard]] being the most representative in the country. The French Revolution brought great changes, as [[Napoleon]] favoured artists of [[neoclassicism|neoclassic style]] such as [[Jacques-Louis David]] and the highly influential [[AcadÃ©mie des Beaux-Arts]] defined the style known as [[Academism]]. At this time France had become a centre of artistic creation, the first half of the 19th century being dominated by two successive movements, at first [[Romanticism]] with [[ThÃ©odore GÃ©ricault]] and [[EugÃ¨ne Delacroix]], and [[Realism (arts)|Realism]] with [[Camille Corot]], [[Gustave Courbet]] and [[Jean-FranÃ§ois Millet]], a style that eventually evolved into [[Naturalism (arts)|Naturalism]].

In the second part of the 19th century, France's influence over painting became even more important, with the development of new styles of painting such as [[Impressionism]] and [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]]. The most famous impressionist painters of the period were [[Camille Pissarro]], [[Ã‰douard Manet]], [[Edgar Degas]], Claude Monet and [[Auguste Renoir]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/learn-about-art/guide-to-impressionism/guide-to-impressionism |title=Guide to Impressionism |publisher=Nationalgallery.org.uk |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The second generation of impressionist-style painters, [[Paul CÃ©zanne]], [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Toulouse-Lautrec]] and [[Georges Seurat]], were also at the avant-garde of artistic evolutions,&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} RFI, [http://www.rfi.fr/actufr/articles/063/article_34792.asp Le nÃ©o-impressionnisme de Seurat Ã  Paul Klee] 15 March 2005&lt;/ref&gt; as well as the [[fauvism|fauvist artists]] [[Henri Matisse]], [[AndrÃ© Derain]] and [[Maurice de Vlaminck]].&lt;ref&gt;National Gallery of Art (United States), [http://www.nga.gov/feature/artnation/fauve/index.shtm The Fauves (dossier)]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} RFI, [http://www.rfi.fr/culturefr/articles/098/article_63189.asp Vlaminck, version fauve], 25 February 2008&lt;/ref&gt;

At the beginning of the 20th century, Cubism was developed by [[Georges Braque]] and the Spanish painter [[Pablo Picasso]], living in Paris. Other foreign artists also settled and worked in or near Paris, such as [[Vincent van Gogh]], [[Marc Chagall]], [[Amedeo Modigliani]] and [[Wassily Kandinsky]].

Many museums in France are entirely or partly devoted to sculptures and painting works. A huge collection of old masterpieces created before or during the 18th century are displayed in the state-owned [[MusÃ©e du Louvre]], such as [[Mona Lisa]], also known as La Joconde. While the [[Louvre Palace]] has been for a long time a museum, the MusÃ©e d'Orsay was inaugurated in 1986 in the old railway station [[Gare d'Orsay]], in a major reorganization of national art collections, to gather French paintings from the second part of the 19th century (mainly Impressionism and Fauvism movements).&lt;ref&gt;MusÃ©e d'Orsay (official website), History of the museum&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/history-of-the-museum/home.html From station to museum]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/history-of-the-collections/painting.html |title=History of the painting collection |publisher=Musee-orsay.fr |date=31 July 2007 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Modern works are presented in the [[MusÃ©e National d'Art Moderne]], which moved in 1976 to the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]]. These three state-owned museums welcome close to 17&amp;nbsp;million people a year.&lt;ref name=sites&gt;{{fr icon}} Ministry of Tourism, [http://www.tourisme.gouv.fr/stat_etudes/memento/2009/sites.pdf Sites touristiques en France] page 2 &quot;PalmarÃ¨s des 30 premiers sites culturels (entrÃ©es comptabilisÃ©es)&quot; [Ranking of 30 most visited cultural sites in France]&lt;/ref&gt; Other national museums hosting paintings include the [[Grand Palais]] (1.3&amp;nbsp;million visitors in 2008), but there are also many museums owned by cities, the most visited being the [[MusÃ©e d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] (0.8&amp;nbsp;million entries in 2008), which hosts contemporary works.&lt;ref name=sites /&gt;

Outside Paris, all the large cities have a Museum of Fine Arts with a section dedicated to European and French painting. Some of the finest collections are in [[MusÃ©e des Beaux-Arts de Lyon|Lyon]], [[Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille|Lille]], [[MusÃ©e des Beaux-Arts de Rouen|Rouen]], [[MusÃ©e des Beaux-Arts de Dijon|Dijon]], [[MusÃ©e des Beaux-Arts de Rennes|Rennes]] and [[Museum of Grenoble|Grenoble]].

===Architecture===
{{Main article|French architecture}}
[[File:Sainte chapelle - Upper level.jpg|thumb|alt=Sainte Chapelle interior showing painted stonework vaulting and stained glass|[[Louis IX of France|Saint Louis']] [[Sainte Chapelle]] represents the French impact on religious architecture.]]
[[File:Palais Garnier's grand salon, 12 February 2008.jpg|thumb|alt=OpÃ©ra Garnier interior showing chandeliers and gilded decoration|[[OpÃ©ra Garnier]], Paris, a symbol of the French [[Second Empire (architecture)|Second Empire]] style]]

During the Middle Ages, many fortified [[castle]]s were built by feudal nobles to mark their powers. Some French castles that survived are [[Chinon (castle)|Chinon]], [[ChÃ¢teau d'Angers]], the massive [[ChÃ¢teau de Vincennes]] and the so-called [[Cathar castles]]. During this era, France had been using [[Romanesque architecture]] like most of Western Europe. Some of the greatest examples of Romanesque churches in France are the [[Basilique de Saint-Sernin, Toulouse|Saint Sernin Basilica]] in [[Toulouse, France|Toulouse]], the largest romanesque church in Europe,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.europeupclose.com/article/toulouses-saint-sernin-largest-romanesque-church-in-europe/ |title=Toulouse's Saint Sernin, Largest Romanesque Church in Europe |publisher=Europeupclose.com |date=22 February 1999 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and the remains of the [[Cluny Abbey|Cluniac Abbey]].

The [[Gothic architecture]], originally named ''Opus Francigenum'' meaning &quot;French work&quot;,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/opus-francigenum-art |title=Opus Francigenum |publisher=Answers.com |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; was born in [[ÃŽle-de-France]] and was the first French style of architecture to be copied in all Europe.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.justfrance.org/france/architecture/001.asp |title=The Gothic Period |publisher=Justfrance.org |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Northern France is the home of some of the most important Gothic [[cathedral]]s and basilicas, the first of these being the [[Saint Denis Basilica]] (used as the royal necropolis); other important French Gothic cathedrals are [[Cathedral of Chartres|Notre-Dame de Chartres]] and [[Amiens Cathedral|Notre-Dame d'Amiens]]. The kings were crowned in another important Gothic church: [[Notre-Dame de Reims]].&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.cathedrale-reims.culture.fr/histoire.html Histoire et Architecture]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.cathedrale-reims.culture.fr/ Site officiel de la Cathedrale de Notre-Dame de Reims]&lt;/ref&gt; Aside from churches, Gothic Architecture had been used for many religious palaces, the most important one being the [[Palais des Papes]] in Avignon.

The final victory in the Hundred Years' War marked an important stage in the evolution of French architecture. It was the time of the [[French Renaissance]] and several artists from Italy were invited to the French court; many residential palaces were built in the [[Loire Valley]]. Such residential castles were the [[ChÃ¢teau de Chambord]], the [[ChÃ¢teau de Chenonceau]], or the [[ChÃ¢teau d'Amboise]].

Following the renaissance and the end of the Middle Ages, [[French Baroque architecture|Baroque architecture]] replaced the traditional Gothic style. However, in France, baroque architecture found a greater success in the secular domain than in a religious one.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} Claude LÃ©bedel&amp;nbsp;â€“ Les Splendeurs du Baroque en France: ''Histoire et splendeurs du baroque en France'' page 9: &quot;Si en allant plus loin, on prononce les mots 'art baroque en France', on provoque alors le plus souvent une moue interrogative, parfois seulement Ã©tonnÃ©e, parfois franchement rÃ©probatrice: Mais voyons, l'art baroque n'existe pas en France!&quot;&lt;/ref&gt; In the secular domain, the [[Palace of Versailles]] has many baroque features. [[Jules Hardouin Mansart]], who designed the extensions to Versailles, was one of the most influential French architect of the baroque era; he is famous for his dome at [[Les Invalides]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jLmFbEdqBDUC&amp;pg=PA86&amp;dq=Mansart+influential#v=onepage&amp;q=influential&amp;f=false |title=Architecture and the Politics of Gender in Early Modern Europe |first=Helen|last= Hills|page=86 |isbn=978-0-7546-0309-2|publisher=Ashgate Publishing |year=2003}}&lt;/ref&gt; Some of the most impressive provincial baroque architecture is found in places that were not yet French such as the [[Place Stanislas]] in [[Nancy, France|Nancy]]. On the military architectural side, [[Vauban]] designed some of the most efficient fortresses in Europe and became an influential military architect; as a result, imitations of his works can be found all over Europe, the Americas, Russia and Turkey.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1283 |title=Fortifications of Vauban |publisher=Whc.unesco.org |date=8 July 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://en.unesco.org/ |title=Official site of the UNESCO |publisher=Unesco.org |accessdate=9 August 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Tour eiffel at sunrise from the trocadero.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Tour Eiffel at sunrise from the trocadero|The world's most visited paid monument,&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&amp;type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&amp;objet_id=998920&amp;clef=ARC-TRK-D_01 Tour Eiffel et souvenirs de Paris]&lt;/ref&gt; the [[Eiffel Tower]] is an icon of both [[Paris]] and France.]]

After the Revolution, the [[Republicanism|Republicans]] favoured [[Neoclassicism]] although neoclassicism was introduced in France prior to the revolution with such building as the [[PanthÃ©on, Paris|Parisian Pantheon]] or the [[Capitole de Toulouse]]. Built during the first French Empire, the [[Arc de Triomphe]] and [[Ã‰glise de la Madeleine|Sainte Marie-Madeleine]] represent the best example of [[Empire style]] architecture.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book |title= Paris: City Guide |year= 2008 |publisher=Lonely Planet |isbn=1-74059-850-4|page= 48 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=OtabdzMdbboC&amp;pg=PA48}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Under [[Napoleon III]], a new wave of urbanism and architecture was given birth; extravagant buildings such as the neo-baroque [[Palais Garnier]] were built. The urban planning of the time was very organised and rigorous; for example, [[Haussmann's renovation of Paris]]. The architecture associated to this era is named [[Second Empire (architecture)|Second Empire]] in English, the term being taken from the [[Second French Empire]]. At this time there was a strong Gothic resurgence across Europe and in France; the associated architect was [[EugÃ¨ne Viollet-le-Duc]]. In the late 19th century, [[Gustave Eiffel]] designed many bridges, such as [[Garabit viaduct]], and remains one of the most influential bridge designers of his time, although he is best remembered for the iconic [[Eiffel Tower]].

In the 20th century, French-Swiss architect [[Le Corbusier]] designed several buildings in France. More recently, French architects have combined both modern and old architectural styles. The [[Louvre Pyramid]] is an example of modern architecture added to an older building. The most difficult buildings to integrate within French cities are skyscrapers, as they are visible from afar. For instance, in Paris, since 1977, new buildings had to be under 37 meters, or 121 feet.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://lci.tf1.fr/posez-vos-questions/2008-07/gratte-ciel-paris-pensez-vous-4872555.html|title=Urbanisme : Des gratte-ciel Ã  Paris : qu'en pensez-vous ?&amp;nbsp;â€“ Posez vos questions|publisher=MYTF1News|author=Henri SECKEL|date=8 July 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; France's largest financial district is [[La Defense]], where a significant number of skyscrapers are located.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.groupenci.com/uk/ile-de-france/defense.com-square.html In the heart of the main European Business area]&amp;nbsp;â€“ NCI Business Center&lt;/ref&gt; Other massive buildings that are a challenge to integrate into their environment are large bridges; an example of the way this has been done is the [[Millau Viaduct]]. Some famous modern French architects include [[Jean Nouvel]], [[Dominique Perrault]], [[Christian de Portzamparc]] or [[Paul Andreu]].

===Literature===
{{Main article|French literature}}

The earliest French literature dates from the [[Middle Age]]s, when what is now known as modern France did not have a single, uniform language. There were several languages and dialects and writers used their own spelling and grammar. Some authors of French mediaeval texts are unknown, such as ''[[Tristan and Iseult]]'' and ''[[Lancelot-Grail]]''. Other authors are known, for example [[ChrÃ©tien de Troyes]] and [[William IX of Aquitaine|Duke William IX of Aquitaine]], who wrote in [[Occitan]].

Much mediaeval French poetry and literature were inspired by the legends of the [[Matter of France]], such as ''[[The Song of Roland]]'' and the various [[chansons de geste]]. The ''Roman de Renart'', written in 1175 by Perrout de Saint Cloude, tells the story of the mediaeval character [[Reynard]] ('the Fox') and is another example of early French writing.

An important 16th-century writer was [[FranÃ§ois Rabelais]], whose novel ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel]]'' has remained famous and appreciated until now. [[Michel de Montaigne]] was the other major figure of the French literature during that century. His most famous work, ''[[Essays (Montaigne)|Essais]]'', created the literary genre of the essay.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.humanistictexts.org/montaigne.htm |title=Montaigne |publisher=Humanistictexts.org |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[French poetry]] during that century was embodied by [[Pierre de Ronsard]] and [[Joachim du Bellay]]. Both writers founded the [[La PlÃ©iade]] literary movement.

During the 17th century, [[Madame de La Fayette]] published anonymously ''[[La Princesse de ClÃ¨ves]]'', a novel that is considered to be one of the very first [[psychological novel]]s of all times.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.radiodramareviews.com/id438.html |title=La Princesse de Cleves by Madame de Lafayette, adapted by Jo Clifford |publisher=Radiodramareviews.com |date=28 February 2010 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Jean de La Fontaine]] is one of the most famous [[fabulist]] of that time, as he wrote hundreds of fables, some being far more famous than others, such as ''[[The Ant and the Grasshopper]]''. Generations of French pupils had to learn his fables, that were seen as helping teaching [[wisdom]] and [[common sense]] to the young people. Some of his verses have entered the popular language to become proverbs.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}

[[File:French literary figures.jpg|thumb|alt=see description|French literary figures. Clockwise from top left: [[MoliÃ¨re]] is the most played author in the [[ComÃ©die-FranÃ§aise]];&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.comedie-francaise.fr/histoire-et-patrimoine?id=525 Auteurs et rÃ©pertoires]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Official site of the ComÃ©die FranÃ§aise&lt;/ref&gt; [[Victor Hugo]] is one of the most important French novelists and poets, and is sometimes seen as the greatest French writer of all time.&lt;ref name = victor&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.lecavalierbleu.com/images/30/extrait_75.pdf |title=Victor Hugo est le plus grand Ã©crivain franÃ§ais |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=29 September 2013}}&lt;/ref&gt; 19th-century poet, writer, and translator [[Charles Baudelaire]]; 20th-century philosopher and novelist [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]. ]]

[[Jean Racine]], whose incredible mastery of the [[alexandrine]] and of the French language has been praised for centuries, created plays such as ''[[PhÃ¨dre]]'' or ''[[Britannicus]]''. He is, along with [[Pierre Corneille]] (''[[Le Cid]]'') and MoliÃ¨re, considered as one of the three great dramatists of the France's [[Louis XIV of France#Patronage o the arts|golden age]]. MoliÃ¨re, who is deemed to be one of the greatest masters of comedy of the [[Western literature]],&lt;ref&gt;&quot;Author of some of the finest comedies in the history of the theater&quot;. Hartnoll, Phyllis (ed.). The Oxford Companion to the Theatre, 1983, Oxford University Press, p. 554&lt;/ref&gt; wrote [[MoliÃ¨re#List of major works|dozens of plays]], including ''[[Le Misanthrope]]'', ''[[L'Avare]]'', ''[[Le Malade imaginaire]]'', and ''[[Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme]]''. His plays have been so popular around the world that French language is sometimes dubbed as &quot;the language of MoliÃ¨re&quot; (''la langue de MoliÃ¨re''),&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Randall |first=Colin |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/1475046/France-looks-to-the-law-to-save-the-language-of-Moliere.html |title=France looks to the law to save the language of MoliÃ¨re |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=25 October 2004 |accessdate=22 July 2011 }}&lt;/ref&gt; just like English is considered as &quot;the language of [[Shakespeare]]&quot;.

French literature and poetry flourished even more in the 18th and 19th centuries. [[Denis Diderot]]'s best-known works are ''[[Jacques the Fatalist]]'' and ''[[Rameau's Nephew]]''. He is however best known for being the main redactor of the ''[[EncyclopÃ©die]]'', whose aim was to sum up all the knowledge of his century (in fields such as arts, sciences, languages, philosophy) and to present them to the people, in order to fight ignorance and [[obscurantism]]. During that same century, [[Charles Perrault]] was a prolific writer of famous children's fairy tales including ''[[Puss in Boots]]'', ''[[Cinderella]]'', ''[[Sleeping Beauty]]'' and ''[[Bluebeard]]''. At the start of the 19th century, [[symbolist poetry]] was an important movement in French literature, with poets such as Charles Baudelaire, [[Paul Verlaine]] and [[StÃ©phane MallarmÃ©]].&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://users.skynet.be/litterature/symbolisme/symbolismefrancais.htm Le symbolisme franÃ§ais]&lt;/ref&gt;

The 19th century saw the writings of many renowned French authors. Victor Hugo is sometimes seen as &quot;the greatest French writer of all times&quot;&lt;ref name = victor /&gt; for excelling in all [[literary genre]]s. The preface of his play ''[[Cromwell (play)|Cromwell]]'' is considered to be the manifesto of the [[Romanticism|Romantic movement]]. ''[[Les Contemplations]]'' and ''[[La LÃ©gende des siÃ¨cles]]'' are considered as &quot;poetic masterpieces&quot;,&lt;ref name = hugo&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.enotes.com/victor-hugo-criticism/hugo-victor |title=Victor Hugo 1802â€“1885 |publisher=Enotes.com |accessdate=16 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; Hugo's verse having been compared to that of Shakespeare, [[Dante]] and [[Homer]].&lt;ref name = hugo /&gt; His novel ''[[Les MisÃ©rables]]'' is widely seen as one of the greatest novel ever written&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.adherents.com/people/100_novel.html |title=All-Time 100 Best Novels List |publisher=Adherents.com |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and ''[[The Hunchback of Notre-Dame|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' has remained immensely popular.

Other major authors of that century include [[Alexandre Dumas]] (''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' and ''[[The Count of Monte-Cristo]]''), [[Jules Verne]] (''[[Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea]]''), [[Ã‰mile Zola]] (''[[Les Rougon-Macquart]]''), [[HonorÃ© de Balzac]] (''[[La ComÃ©die humaine]]''), [[Guy de Maupassant]], [[ThÃ©ophile Gautier]] and [[Stendhal]] (''[[The Red and the Black]]'', ''[[The Charterhouse of Parma]]''), whose works are among the most well known in France and the world.

The [[Prix Goncourt]] is a French literary prize first awarded in 1903.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.academie-goncourt.fr/?article=1229174089 La premiÃ¨re AcadÃ©mie Goncourt]&amp;nbsp;â€“ [http://www.academie-goncourt.fr/? Site officiel de l'AcadÃ©mie Goncourt]&lt;/ref&gt; Important writers of the 20th century include [[Marcel Proust]], [[Louis-Ferdinand CÃ©line]], [[Albert Camus]], and [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]. [[Antoine de Saint ExupÃ©ry]] wrote ''[[The Little Prince|Little Prince]]'', which has remained popular for decades with children and adults around the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.completelynovel.com/books/50599 |title=The Little Prince |publisher=Completelynovel.com |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; {{As of|2014}}, French authors had more [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Literature Nobel Prizes]] than [[List of Nobel laureates in Literature#Laureates per country|those of any other nation]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Patrick Modiano&quot;&gt;[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/141009/modiano-strengthens-frances-literature-nobel-dominance Modiano strengthens France's literature Nobel dominance], [[Global Post]], 9 October 2014&lt;/ref&gt; The first Nobel Prize in Literature was a French author, while France's latest Nobel prize in literature is [[Patrick Modiano]], who was awarded the prize in 2014.&lt;ref name=&quot;Patrick Modiano&quot; /&gt; Jean-Paul Sartre was also the first nominee in the committee's history to refuse the prize in 1964.&lt;ref name=&quot;Patrick Modiano&quot; /&gt;

===Philosophy===
{{Main article|French philosophy}}
Medieval philosophy was dominated by [[Scholasticism]] until the emergence of [[Humanism in France|Humanism]] in the Renaissance. [[Modern philosophy]] began in France in the 17th century with the philosophy of [[RenÃ© Descartes]], [[Blaise Pascal]], and [[Nicolas Malebranche]]. Descartes revitalised [[Western philosophy]], which had been declined after the Greek and Roman eras.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.friesian.com/hist-2.htm |title=The Beginning of Modern Sciences |publisher=Friesian.com |accessdate=16 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; His ''[[Meditations on First Philosophy]]'' changed the primary object of philosophical thought and raised some of the most fundamental problems for foreigners such as [[Spinoza]], [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]], [[David Hume|Hume]], [[George Berkeley|Berkeley]], and [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]].
[[File:Frans Hals - Portret van RenÃ© Descartes.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Frans Hals painting of RenÃ© Descartes facing right in black coat and white collar|[[RenÃ© Descartes]], founder of modern philosophy.]]

During the 18th century, French philosophers produced one of the most important works of the [[Age of Enlightenment]]. In ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'', [[Baron de Montesquieu]] theorized the principle of [[separation of powers]], which has been implemented in all [[liberal democracy|liberal democracies]] since [[Separation of powers under the United States Constitution|it was first applied in the United States]]. In ''[[Du contrat social ou Principes du droit politique|The Social Contract]]'', [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] openly criticized the European [[Divine right monarchy|divine right monarchies]] and strongly affirmed the principle of the [[sovereignty of the people]]. [[Voltaire]] came to embody the Enlightenment with his defence of civil liberties, such as the right to a free trial and freedom of religion.

19th-century French thought was targeted at responding to the social malaise following the French Revolution. Rationalist philosophers such as [[Victor Cousin]] and [[Auguste Comte]], who called for a new social doctrine, were opposed by reactionary thinkers such as [[Joseph de Maistre]], [[Louis Gabriel Ambroise de Bonald|Louis de Bonald]] and [[Hugues FelicitÃ© Robert de Lamennais|Lamennais]], who blamed the rationalist rejection of traditional order. De Maistre is considered, together with the Englishman [[Edmund Burke]], one of the founders of European conservatism, while Comte is regarded as the founder of [[positivism]] and [[sociology]].

In the early 20th century, French [[Spiritualism (philosophy)|spiritualist]] thinkers such as [[Maine de Biran]], [[Henri Bergson]] and [[Louis Lavelle]] influenced Anglo-Saxon thought, including the Americans [[Charles Sanders Peirce]] and [[William James]], and the Englishman [[Alfred North Whitehead]]. In the late 20th century, partly influenced by German [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]] and [[existentialism]], [[postmodern philosophy]] began in France, with notable [[post-structuralism|post-structuralist]] thinkers including [[Jean-FranÃ§ois Lyotard]], [[Jean Baudrillard]], [[Jacques Derrida]], [[Jacques Lacan]], [[Michel Foucault]] and [[Gilles Deleuze]].

===Music===
{{Main article|Music of France}}
[[File:Gainsbourgb.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=head shot of Serge Gainsbourg |[[Serge Gainsbourg]], one of the world's most influential popular musicians.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|author=2003å¹´4æœˆ21æ—¥ (æœˆ) |url=http://www.hmv.co.jp/news/newsDetail.asp?newsnum=304080038 |title=The 100 Greatest Artists&amp;nbsp;â€“ No. 62 |publisher=Hmv.co.jp |date= |accessdate=25 January 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;]]
France has a long and varied musical history. It experienced a golden age in the 17th century thanks to Louis XIV, who employed a number of talented musicians and composers in the royal court. The most renowned composers of this period include [[Marc-Antoine Charpentier]], [[FranÃ§ois Couperin]], [[Michel-Richard Delalande]], [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] and [[Marin Marais]], all of them composers at the court. After the death of the &quot;Roi Soleil&quot;, French musical creation lost dynamism, but in the next century the music of [[Jean-Philippe Rameau]] reached some prestige, and today he is still one of the most renowned French composers. Rameau became the dominant composer of [[French opera]] and the leading French composer for the harpsichord.&lt;ref&gt;Girdlestone p. 14: &quot;It is customary to couple him with Couperin as one couples Haydn with Mozart or Ravel with Debussy.&quot;&lt;/ref&gt;

French composers played an important role during the music of the 19th and early 20th century, which is considered to be the [[Romantic music]] era. Romantic music emphasized a surrender to nature, a fascination with the past and the supernatural, the exploration of unusual, strange and surprising sounds, and a focus on national identity. This period was also a golden age for operas. French composers from the Romantic era included: [[Hector Berlioz]] (best known for his ''[[Symphonie fantastique]]''), [[Georges Bizet]] (best known for ''[[Carmen]]'', which has become one of the most popular and frequently performed operas), [[Gabriel FaurÃ©]] (best known for his ''[[Pavane (FaurÃ©)|Pavane]]'', [[Requiem (FaurÃ©)|''Requiem'']], and ''[[FaurÃ© Nocturnes|nocturnes]]''), [[Charles Gounod]] (best known for his ''[[Ave Maria (Bach/Gounod)|Ave Maria]]'' and his [[opera]] ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]''), [[Jacques Offenbach]] (best known for his 100 [[operetta]]s of the 1850sâ€“1870s and his uncompleted opera ''[[The Tales of Hoffmann]]''), [[Ã‰douard Lalo]] (best known for his ''[[Symphonie espagnole]]'' for violin and [[orchestra]] and his [[Cello Concerto (Lalo)|Cello Concerto in D minor]]), [[Jules Massenet]] (best known for his operas, of which he wrote more than thirty, the most frequently staged are ''[[Manon]]'' (1884) and ''[[Werther]]'' (1892)) and [[Camille Saint-SaÃ«ns]] (he has many frequently-performed works, including ''[[The Carnival of the Animals]]'', ''[[Danse macabre (Saint-SaÃ«ns)|Danse macabre]]'', ''[[Samson and Delilah (opera)|Samson and Delilah]]'' (Opera), ''[[Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso]]'', and his [[Symphony No. 3 (Saint-SaÃ«ns)|Symphony No. 3 (''Organ Symphony'')]]).

Later came precursors of modern classical music. [[Ã‰rik Satie]] was a key member of the early 20th century Parisian [[avant-garde]], best known for his ''[[GymnopÃ©dies]]''. [[Francis Poulenc]]'s best known works are his piano suite ''[[Trois mouvements perpÃ©tuels]]'' (1919), the ballet ''[[Les biches]]'' (1923), the ''[[Concert champÃªtre]]'' (1928) for [[harpsichord]] and orchestra, the opera ''[[Dialogues des CarmÃ©lites]]'' (1957), and the ''[[Gloria (Poulenc)|Gloria]]'' (1959) for [[soprano]], choir and orchestra. [[Maurice Ravel]] and [[Claude Debussy]] are the most prominent figures associated with [[Impressionist music]]. Debussy was among the most influential composers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and his use of non-traditional scales and [[chromaticism]] influenced many composers who followed.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/claude-debussy-mn0000768781/biography|title=Claude Debussy&amp;nbsp;â€“ Biography&amp;nbsp;â€“ AllMusic|author=Allen Schrott|work=AllMusic}}&lt;/ref&gt; Debussy's music is noted for its sensory content and frequent usage of [[atonality]]. The two composers invented new musical forms&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|last=Huizenga |first=Tom |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4957580 |title=Debussy's 'La Mer' Marks 100th Birthday |publisher=NPR |date=14 October 2005 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=92338564 |title=Debussy's Musical Game of Deception |publisher=NPR |date=12 July 2008 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.co.uk/music/composers/c-g/claude-debussy/ |title=Biography of Claude Debussy |publisher=Classicfm.co.uk |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.co.uk/music/composers/n-r/maurice-ravel/ |title=Biography of Maurice Ravel |publisher=Classicfm.co.uk |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; and new sounds. Ravel's piano compositions, such as ''[[Jeux d'eau (Ravel)|Jeux d'eau]]'', ''[[Miroirs]]'', ''[[Le tombeau de Couperin]]'' and ''[[Gaspard de la nuit]]'', demand considerable virtuosity. His mastery of orchestration is evident in the ''[[Rapsodie espagnole]]'', ''[[Daphnis et ChloÃ©]]'', his arrangement of [[Modest Mussorgsky]]'s ''[[Pictures at an Exhibition]]'' and his orchestral work ''[[BolÃ©ro]]'' (1928).

More recently, at the middle of the 20th century, [[Maurice Ohana]], [[Pierre Schaeffer]] and [[Pierre Boulez]] contributed to the evolutions of [[contemporary classical music]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|last=Boulez |first=Pierre |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126668117 |title=Composer-Conductor Pierre Boulez At 85 |publisher=NPR |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:DaftAlive.jpeg|thumb|alt=Daft Punk at O2 Wireless Festival, helmeted musicians at keyboard|[[Daft Punk]], pioneers of the [[French house]].]]
French music then followed the rapid emergence of pop and rock music at the middle of the 20th century. Although English-speaking creations achieved popularity in the country, [[French popular music|French pop music]], known as ''[[chanson franÃ§aise]]'', has also remained very popular. Among the most important French artists of the century are [[Ã‰dith Piaf]], [[Georges Brassens]], [[LÃ©o FerrÃ©]], [[Charles Aznavour]] and [[Serge Gainsbourg]]. Although there are very few rock bands in France compared to English-speaking countries,&lt;ref&gt;[[Radio France Internationale|RFI Musique]], [http://www.rfimusic.com/artist/rock/noir-desir/biography Biography of Noir DÃ©sir], March 2009: &quot;Rock music doesn't come naturally to the French. A Latin country, with more affinity to poetry and melody, France has very rarely produced talented rock musicians. Rock music has other, more Anglo-Saxon ingredients&quot;&lt;/ref&gt; bands such as [[Noir DÃ©sir]], [[Mano Negra]], [[Niagara (band)|Niagara]], [[Les Rita Mitsouko]] and more recently [[Superbus (band)|Superbus]], [[Phoenix (band)|Phoenix]] and [[Gojira (band)|Gojira]]&lt;ref name=frmusic&gt;France Diplomatie, [http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/france_159/culture-and-media_6819/culture_6874/music_5335/french-music-has-the-whole-planet-singing_13031.html French music has the whole planet singing], June 2009&lt;/ref&gt; have reached worldwide popularity.

Other French artists with international careers have been popular in several countries, for example female singers [[Dalida]], [[Mireille Mathieu]], [[MylÃ¨ne Farmer]]&lt;ref name=frmusic /&gt; and [[Nolwenn Leroy]],&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.irma.asso.fr/IMG/pdf/bureauexport_dossierdepresse_2013_fr.pdf &quot;Bureau Export&amp;nbsp;â€“ Les certifications export 2012&quot;]. IRMA. p.26. Retrieved 7 March 2015.&lt;/ref&gt; electronic music pioneers [[Jean-Michel Jarre]], [[Laurent Garnier]] and [[Bob Sinclar]], and later [[Martin Solveig]] and [[David Guetta]]. In the 1990s and 2000s (decade), electronic duos [[Daft Punk]], [[Justice (French band)|Justice]] and [[Air (French band)|Air]] also reached worldwide popularity and contributed to the reputation of modern electronic music in the world.&lt;ref name=frmusic /&gt;&lt;ref&gt;The Telegraph, [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/3669339/Daft-Punk-Behind-the-robot-masks.html Daft Punk: Behind the robot masks], 17 November 2007: &quot;Daft Punk were in many ways responsible for turning the spotlight on a new, cool underground of French music in the late 1990s, including bestselling acts such as Air, and have been a huge influence on the current generation of international star DJs&quot;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1721450.stm |title=The return of French pop music |publisher=BBC News |date=20 December 2001 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Among current musical events and institutions in France, many are dedicated to classical music and operas. The most prestigious institutions are the state-owned [[Paris National Opera]] (with its two sites [[Palais Garnier]] and [[OpÃ©ra Bastille]]), the [[OpÃ©ra National de Lyon]], the [[ThÃ©Ã¢tre du ChÃ¢telet]] in Paris, the [[ThÃ©Ã¢tre du Capitole]] in [[Toulouse]] and the [[Grand ThÃ©Ã¢tre de Bordeaux]]. As for music festivals, there are several events organized, the most popular being the [[EurockÃ©ennes]] and [[Rock en Seine]]. The [[FÃªte de la Musique]], imitated by many foreign cities, was first launched by the French government in 1982.&lt;ref&gt;Ministry of Culture of France, [http://www.fetedelamusique.culture.fr/site-2010/?page_id=550 About &quot;FÃªte de la Musique&quot;]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;France Diplomatie, [http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/france_159/culture-and-media_6819/culture_6874/music_5335/fete-musique-21 June 2007_9392.html FÃªte de la Musique], 21 June 2007&lt;/ref&gt; Major music halls and venues in France include [[Le ZÃ©nith]] sites present in many cities and other places in Paris ([[Paris Olympia]], [[ThÃ©Ã¢tre Mogador]], [[Ã‰lysÃ©e Montmartre]], etc.).

===Cinema===
{{Main article|Cinema of France}}[[File:Palmed'or.jpg|thumb|alt=Palme d'Or award in presentation case|A ''[[Palme d'Or]]'' from the [[Cannes Film Festival]], the world's most prestigious and publicized film festival.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url = http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/c/cannes_international_film_festival/index.html|title = Cannes International Film Festival |work=The New York Times | first=Manohla|last=Dargis}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url = http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/16/arts/16iht-lim16.html?_r=1&amp;ref=movies|title = They'll Always Have Cannes |work=The New York Times | first=Dennis|last=Lim|date=15 May 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url = http://www.forbes.com/2008/05/14/cannes-properties-luxury-forbeslife-cx_mw_0514realestate_slide.html?thisSpeed=15000|title = In Pictures: Chic Cannes Hideaways |work=Forbes | first=Matt|last=Woolsey}}&lt;/ref&gt;]]
France has historical and strong links with [[Filmmaking|cinema]], with two [[Frenchmen]], Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re (known as the [[Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re|LumiÃ¨re Brothers]]) having created cinema in 1895.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/personnage/LumiÃ¨re/130661 Les frÃ¨res LumiÃ¨re]&lt;/ref&gt; Several important cinematic movements, including the late 1950s and 1960s [[Nouvelle Vague]], began in the country. It is noted for having a particularly strong film industry, due in part to protections afforded by the [[French government]].&lt;ref name=&quot;NYT 1995-02-28&quot;&gt;{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/28/movies/the-birthplace-celebrates-film-s-big-1-0-0.html |title=The Birthplace Celebrates Film's Big 1-0-0 |work=The New York Times |date=28 February 1995 |author=Alan Riding}}&lt;/ref&gt;{{update after|2011|10|02}} France remains a leader in filmmaking, {{As of|2006|lc=y}} producing more films than any other European country.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx |title=Cinema: production of feature films |publisher=Stats.uis.unesco.org |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The nation also hosts the [[Cannes Festival]], one of the most important and famous film festivals in the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.cannesguide.com/basics/ |title=Cannes&amp;nbsp;â€“ a festival virgin's guide |publisher=Cannesguide.com |date=15 February 2007 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonwhen.com/sisp/index.htm?fx=event&amp;event_id=21731 |title=Cannes Film Festival &amp;#124; Palais des Festivals, Cannes, France |publisher=Whatsonwhen.com |date= |accessdate=22 June 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Apart from its strong and innovative film tradition, France has also been a gathering spot for artists from across Europe and the world. For this reason, French cinema is sometimes intertwined with the cinema of foreign nations. Directors from nations such as Poland ([[Roman Polanski]], [[Krzysztof KieÅ›lowski]], and [[Andrzej Å»uÅ‚awski]]), [[Argentina]] ([[Gaspar NoÃ©]] and [[Edgardo Cozarinsky]]), Russia ([[Alexandre Alexeieff]], [[Anatole Litvak]]), Austria ([[Michael Haneke]]), and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] ([[GÃ©la Babluani]], [[Otar Iosseliani]]) are prominent in the ranks of French cinema. Conversely, French directors have had prolific and influential careers in other countries, such as [[Luc Besson]], [[Jacques Tourneur]], or [[Francis Veber]] in the [[Cinema of the United States|United States]].

Although the French film market is dominated by [[Hollywood]], France is the only nation in the world where American films make up the smallest share of total film revenues, at 50%, compared with 77% in Germany and 69% in Japan.&lt;ref name = erudit&gt;{{fr icon}} Damien RousseliÃ¨re [http://www.erudit.org/revue/hphi/2005/v15/n2/801295ar.pdf CinÃ©ma et diversitÃ© culturelle: le cinÃ©ma indÃ©pendant face Ã  la mondialisation des industries culturelles]. ''Horizons philosophiques'' Vol. 15 No. 2 2005&lt;/ref&gt; French films account for 35% of the total film revenues of France, which is the highest percentage of national film revenues in the developed world outside the United States, compared to 14% in Spain and 8% in the UK.&lt;ref name = erudit /&gt; France is in 2013 the 2nd exporter of films in the world after the United States.&lt;ref name=&quot;unifrance.org&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.unifrance.org/actualites/11596/enquete-sur-l-image-du-cinema-francais-dans-le-monde|title=EnquÃªte sur l'image du cinÃ©ma franÃ§ais dans le monde|work=unifrance.org}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Until recently, France had for centuries been the cultural center of the world,&lt;ref name=exception /&gt; although its dominant position has been surpassed by the [[American culture|United States]]. Subsequently, France takes steps in protecting and promoting its culture, becoming a leading advocate of the [[cultural exception]].&lt;ref&gt;JoÃ«lle Farchy (1999) [http://www.scienceshumaines.com/la-fin-de-l-exception-culturelle_fr_10912.html La Fin de l'exception culturelle ?] [[CNRS]] ISBN 978-2-271-05633-7&lt;/ref&gt; The nation succeeded in convincing all EU members to refuse to include culture and audiovisuals in the list of liberalized sectors of the WTO in 1993.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/actualites/politique/diversite/wto-en2.htm The cultural exception is not negotiable by Catherine Trautmann]&amp;nbsp;â€“ Ministry of Culture&lt;/ref&gt; Moreover, this decision was confirmed in a voting in the [[UNESCO]] in 2005, and the principle of &quot;cultural exception&quot; won an overwhelming victory: 198 countries voted for it, only 2 countries, the U.S and Israel, voted against it.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} [http://www.fnsac-cgt.com/administration/upload/ARTICLE%20UNESCO%20CONF%201602_06%20(3).pdf La Convention UNESCO pour la diversitÃ© culturelle : vers un droit international culturel contraignant ?] {{wayback|url=http://www.fnsac-cgt.com/administration/upload/ARTICLE%20UNESCO%20CONF%201602_06%20(3).pdf |date=20110427020210 |df=y }}&amp;nbsp;â€“ http://www.fnsac-cgt.com&lt;/ref&gt;

===Fashion===
{{Main article|French fashion}}
[[File:Channel headquarters bordercropped.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Chanel's headquarters storefront window at the Place VendÃ´me Paris with awning|[[Chanel]]'s headquarters on the [[Place VendÃ´me]], Paris.]]

Fashion has been an important industry and cultural export of France since the 17th century, and modern &quot;haute couture&quot; originated in Paris in the 1860s. Today, Paris, along with London, Milan, and New York City, is considered one of the world's fashion capitals, and the city is home or headquarters to many of the premier fashion houses. The expression [[Haute couture]] is, in France, a legally protected name, guaranteeing certain quality standards.

The association of France with fashion and style ({{lang-fr|link=no|la mode}}) dates largely to the reign of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]]&lt;ref&gt;Kelly, 181. DeJean, chapters 2â€“4.&lt;/ref&gt; when the luxury goods industries in France came increasingly under royal control and the French royal court became, arguably, the arbiter of taste and style in Europe. But France renewed its dominance of the high fashion ({{lang-fr|link=no|couture or haute couture}}) industry in the years 1860â€“1960 through the establishing of the great [[couturier]] houses such as [[Chanel]], [[Christian Dior S.A.|Dior]], and [[Givenchy]]. The French perfume industry is world leader in its sector and is centered on the town of [[Grasse]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://about-france.com/tourism/french-perfume.htm |title=French perfume |publisher=About-France.com |date= |accessdate=13 January 2014}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In the 1960s, the elitist &quot;Haute couture&quot; came under criticism from France's [[May 1968 in France|youth culture]]. In 1966, the designer [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]] broke with established Haute Couture norms by launching a [[prÃªt-Ã -porter]] (&quot;ready to wear&quot;) line and expanding French fashion into mass manufacturing. With a greater focus on marketing and manufacturing, new trends were established by [[Sonia Rykiel]], [[Thierry Mugler]], [[Claude Montana]], [[Jean-Paul Gaultier]] and [[Christian Lacroix]] in the 1970s and 1980s. The 1990s saw a conglomeration of many French couture houses under luxury giants and multinationals such as [[LVMH]].

===Media===
{{Main article|Telecommunications in France}}
[[File:Le Figaro logo.png|thumb|alt=masthead of Le Figaro newspaper|''[[Le Figaro]]'' was founded in 1826; many of France's most prominent authors have written in its columns over the decades, and it is still considered a [[newspaper of record]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/206556/Le-Figaro|title=Le Figaro|work=Encyclopedia Britannica}}&lt;/ref&gt;]]

Compared to other developed countries, the French do not spend much time reading newspapers, due to the popularity of broadcast media. Best-selling daily national newspapers in France are ''[[Le Parisien]] Aujourd'hui en France'' (with 460,000 sold daily), ''[[Le Monde]]'' and ''[[Le Figaro]]'', with around 300,000 copies sold daily, but also ''[[L'Ã‰quipe]]'', dedicated to sports coverage.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} OJD, &quot;Observatoire de la Presse&quot;, [http://observatoire.ojd.com/report/visu/obs/20/do/GP_PQN/ Presse Quotidienne Nationale]&lt;/ref&gt; In the past years, free dailies made a breakthrough, with ''[[Metro International|Metro]]'', ''[[20 minutes (France)|20 Minutes]]'' and ''Direct Plus'' distributed at more than 650,000 copies respectively.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} OJD, [http://www.ojd.com/pgi/section/ Presse Gratuite d'Information]. November 2011&lt;/ref&gt; However, the widest circulations are reached by regional daily ''[[Ouest France]]'' with more than 750,000 copies sold, and the 50 other regional papers have also high sales.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} Observatoire de la Presse, [http://observatoire.ojd.com/report/visu/obs/20/do/GP_PQRD/ Presse Quotidienne RÃ©gionale et DÃ©partementale]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} OJD, &quot;Bureau Presse Payante Grand Public&quot;, [http://www.ojd.com/chiffres/section/PPGP/print?submitted=1&amp;section=PPGP&amp;famille=2&amp;thema=&amp;search=&amp;go=Lancer+la+recherche Presse Quotidienne RÃ©gionale et DÃ©partementale]&lt;/ref&gt; The sector of weekly magazines is stronger and diversified with more than 400 specialized weekly magazines published in the country.&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} Observatoire de la Presse, [http://observatoire.ojd.com/report/visu/obs/20/do/GP_PMAG/ Presse Magazine&amp;nbsp;â€“ SynthÃ¨se]&lt;/ref&gt;

The most influential news magazines are the left-wing ''[[Le Nouvel Observateur]]'', centrist ''[[L'Express (France)|L'Express]]'' and right-wing ''[[Le Point]]'' (more than 400.000 copies),&lt;ref&gt;{{fr icon}} Observatoire de la Presse, [http://observatoire.ojd.com/report/visu/obs/20/do/GP_NEWS/ Presse News]&lt;/ref&gt; but the highest circulation for weeklies is reached by TV magazines and by women's magazines, among them ''[[Marie Claire]]'' and ''[[ELLE]]'', which have foreign versions. Influential weeklies also include investigative and satirical papers ''[[Le Canard EnchaÃ®nÃ©]]'' and ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'', as well as ''[[Paris Match]]''. Like in most industrialized nations, the print media have been affected by a [[Newspaper crisis|severe crisis]] in the past decade. In 2008, the government launched a major initiative to help the sector reform and become financially independent,&lt;ref&gt;''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/3125110/Nicolas-Sarkozy-French-media-faces-death-without-reform.html Nicolas Sarkozy: French media faces 'death' without reform] 2 October 2008&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;French government portal, [http://www.gouvernement.fr/gouvernement/lancement-des-etats-generaux-de-la-presse Lancement des Ã©tats gÃ©nÃ©raux de la presse] 2 October 2008 [Launching of General State of written media]&lt;/ref&gt; but in 2009 it had to give 600,000 euros to help the print media cope with the [[Global financial crisis of 2008â€“2009|economic crisis]], in addition to existing subsidies.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|author=Angelique Chrisafis in Paris |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2009/jan/23/sarkozy-pledges-state-aid-to-newspapers |title=Sarkozy pledges â‚¬600m to newspapers |publisher=The Guardian |date= 23 January 2009|accessdate=21 June 2012 |location=London}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 1974, after years of centralized monopoly on radio and television, the governmental agency [[ORTF]] was split into several national institutions, but the three already-existing TV channels and four national radio stations&lt;ref&gt;Radio France, &quot;L'entreprise&quot;, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722004341/http://www.radiofrance.fr/lentreprise/reperes/statuts/ RepÃ¨res]. Landmarks of Radio France company&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=mediapol&gt;{{fr icon}} Vie Publique, [http://www.vie-publique.fr/politiques-publiques/politique-audiovisuel/chronologie/ Chronologie de la politique de l'audiovisuel] 20 August 2004 [Chronology of policy for audiovisual]&lt;/ref&gt; remained under state-control. It was only in 1981 that the government allowed free broadcasting in the territory, ending state monopoly on radio.&lt;ref name=mediapol /&gt; French television was partly liberalized in the next two decade with the creation of several commercial channels, mainly thanks to cable and satellite television.
